	<item>
		<title>Yahoo predictive search</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/02/yahoo-predictive-search/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 Feb 2008 19:43:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=7</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[Image missing]

Hard to believe, but Yahoo has something interesting.When you type something in the search field, it will guess what you are looking for.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>7</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2008-02-27 15:43:13</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2008-02-27 19:43:13</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>

		<title>Stretchy boxes</title>

	<item>
		<title>Tools</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/tools/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Sep 2009 15:36:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?page_id=860</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The following is a list of services &amp; tools that Soomo uses in an attempt to keep us all sane and organized. For more information you can read Lindrum's write ups <a href="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=844" target="_blank">here</a> and <a href="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=848" target="_blank">here</a>.
<h2><span style="font-weight: normal">General</span></h2>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Flowr</strong> - Internal twiterer (<a href="http://gke.flowr.com">http://gke.theflowr.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>Backstage</strong> - internal blog (<a href="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>PoliSilo</strong> - blog for poli sci instructors (<a href="http://polisilo.com">http://polisilo.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>Mite</strong> - Time tracking (<a title="mite" href="http://soomo.mite.yo.lk" target="_blank">http://soomo.mite.yo.lk</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>ProjectPath</strong> - Project managment (<a title="ProjectPath" href="http://soomo.projectpath.com" target="_blank">http://soomo.projectpath.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>MyEmma</strong> - HTML email tool (<a href="http://myemma.com/">http://myemma.com/</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>HighRise</strong> - record of all contacts with professors (<a href="http://highrisehq.com">http://highrisehq.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>Backpack</strong> - Group notes &amp; document collaboration (<a title="Backpack" href="https://soomo.backpackit.com" target="_blank">https://soomo.backpackit.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>Gmail</strong> - Company email (<a title="Soomo Mail" href="http://mail.soomopublishing.com/" target="_blank">http://mail.soomopublishing.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>Google Calendar</strong> - Collective calendar (<a href="http://calendar.soomopublishing.com">http://calendar.soomopublishing.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>Dropbox</strong> - File sharing &amp; cloud storage (<a title="Dropbox" href="http://getdropbox.com" target="_blank">http://getdropbox.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>Soomo on YouTube</strong> - Some released video (<a href="http://www.youtube.com/soomopublishing">http://www.youtube.com/soomopublishing</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>Vimeo Backlot</strong> - Not-yet-released video projects (<a href="http://www.vimeo.com/soomobacklot">http://www.vimeo.com/soomobacklot</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>DimDim</strong> - Online meetings &amp; conferences (<a title="DimDim" href="http://dimdim.com" target="_blank">http://dimdim.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>Glance</strong> - Screen sharing (<a href="http://soomo.glance.net">http://soomo.glance.net</a> / 2010)</li>
	<li><strong>TimeBridge</strong> -- a tool for scheduling meetings (<a href="http://timebridge.com">http://timebridge.com</a>)</li>
	<li> .....David Lindrum's <a href="http://www.timebridge.com/mytime/davidlindrum">Schedule</a></li>
	<li>.....Tim Grant's <a href="http://app.timebridge.com/user/availability/N0SRMBFKjoYojD">Schedule</a></li>
	<li>.....Tom Meek's <a href="http://app.timebridge.com/user/availability/NkrDwDdU0GAOGc">Schedule</a></li>
	<li>.....Rebecca Shelley's <a href="http://app.timebridge.com/user/availability/N1y8BGtKorrgFK">Schedule</a></li>
	<li>.....Matthew Bennink's <a href="http://meetwith.me/matthewbennink" target="_blank">Schedule</a></li>
</ul>
<h2><strong><span style="font-weight: normal">Development</span></strong></h2>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Lighthouse</strong> - Bug tracking (<a title="Lighthouse" href="https://soomo.lighthouseapp.com" target="_blank">https://soomo.lighthouseapp.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>github</strong> - Development repository (<a title="github" href="https://github.com/" target="_blank">https://github.com/</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>Heroku</strong> - Rails testing environment (<a title="Heroku" href="http://heroku.com" target="_blank">http://heroku.com</a>)</li>
</ul>
<h2><strong><span style="font-weight: normal">Other Useful Stuff</span></strong></h2>
<strong>Web Services</strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Evernote</strong> - Great note taking service that allows you to sync notes across multiple computers/devices (<a href="http://evernote.com" target="_blank">http://evernote.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>SimpleNote</strong> - Much, um, simpler. Great iphone integration. (<a href="http://simple-note.appspot.com">http://simple-note.appspot.com</a>)</li>
	<li><strong>TeuxDeux</strong> - simple, elegant todo list manager. (<a href="http://teuxdeux.com/">http://teuxdeux.com/</a>)</li>
</ul>
<strong>iPhone Apps</strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Dropbox</strong> - Access your Dropbox account (FREE - requires account) - <a href="http://itunes.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewSoftware?id=327630330&amp;mt=8">iTunes Link</a></li>
	<li><strong>Things</strong> - Task management app ($9.99) - <a href="http://itunes.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewSoftware?id=284971781&amp;mt=8">iTunes Link</a></li>
	<li><strong>Evernote </strong>- Create &amp; store notes online (FREE - requires account) - <a href="http://itunes.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewSoftware?id=281796108&amp;mt=8">iTunes Link</a></li>
	<li><strong>ProjectPath apps</strong> - Here's <a href="http://37signals.com/extras" target="_blank">a list</a> of various apps that let you access ProjectPath. Prices range from $3.99 - $12.99.</li>
	<li><strong>BeejiveIM</strong> - Probably the best IM app for the iPhone. Supports all IM protocols and has push notifications. It's a bit pricey at $9.99 but well worth it - <a href="http://itunes.apple.com/WebObjects/MZStore.woa/wa/viewSoftware?id=291720439&amp;mt=8">iTunes Link</a></li>
</ul>
<strong>Desktop Apps</strong>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Things (Mac)</strong> - Task Management ($49.95) - <a href="http://culturedcode.com/things/" target="_blank">http://culturedcode.com/things/</a></li>
	<li><strong>Mailplane (Mac) </strong>- Desktop app for Gmail ($24.95) - <a href="http://mailplaneapp.com/" target="_blank">http://mailplaneapp.com/</a></li>
	<li><strong>Evernote (Mac/PC) </strong>- Desktop app for Evernote (FREE - requires account) - <a href="http://www.evernote.com/about/download/" target="_blank">http://www.evernote.com/about/download/</a></li>
	<li><strong>Skitch (Mac)</strong> - Probably the best screencapture app ever made (FREE) - <a href="http://evernote.com" target="_blank">http://skitch.com</a></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Most Requested</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/mostrequested/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 04 Dec 2009 20:38:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>maureeny</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?page_id=1189</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This is a web page to keep track of the most common feature requests from professors.

Allow of prof to reset their own assignments:
&gt;Dolly Mullen

Allow a TA/GA or Prof to reset students assignments
&gt;Jeff Justice

Make it easier to notice more videos need to be watched under current assignments.
&gt; Lynne Bernier
&gt; Andrew Matthews

Improvement suggestion: flashcards. I link to other sources and eventually plan to write my own for the class use, but it would be nice to have them integrated into the site. Also, discussion boards for more social classes. Add some general places for me to have students post (and me grade) book reviews, essay submissions and weekly and review quizzes, Id switch to your site altogether.
&gt; Rachel Califf

Could there be a way to have the Reference answers appear to the students?  Could I as an instructor click on the reference and it be added to the Comments when I send them back to the students?
&gt; Tom Adams

Make the grades either all visible at once on a single screen or exportable to an Excel file (or both).
&gt; Carlton Henson

I would love it if there was an easier way for me to export all completed assignments by a student or by assignment into one Word, .pdf, or .rtf file that I could easily print.
&gt; Ali Yanus
&gt; Jocelyn Evans

Way to change grade as they appear in %'s to 4/5, 10/10, 0/4 etc.
&gt; Jessica Munday

It is actually difficult as an instructor to see if students answered correctly or simply didn't answer the multiple choice question. It would be helpful if that was more pronounced. Something like a simple green checkmark or red xmark next to the answer the students gave would be ideal.
&gt; Miguel Centellas

Is there any way you can set those to viable for graded exams? It makes sense to do that after grading, so students can know the correct answer w/o having to contact me individually (in a large class this would get tedious) or for me to have to retype the reference answer every time for a student.
&gt; Miguel Centellas

I would love to push assignments to my students Facebook timelines.
&gt; Miguel Centellas

It would be really cool if as a prof I could click on the question and see all student responses to that single question at the same time...
&gt; Jocelyn Evans

Way to reveal correct multiple choice answers after a certain point and not before.
&gt; TongFi Kim

Is there a feature where I can input what each question is worth, score them, and have it calculate the grade per student and the class average per assignment?
&gt; Miguel Centellas

Change the newsfeed
&gt; Stephen Morris

It would be so much easier if the box on the left moved with you as you worked further and further down the right side of the page on questions.  As it stands now, you just have to keep scrolling back up to the top of the page to be able to see the content in the box on the left-hand side of the screen.
&gt; Jocelyn Evans

Change Banner at the top to title of class:
&gt; A. Leigh Sink "Political Issues"
&gt; Stephen Morris "Latin American Politics"

No longer say AG with Dr. whoever but rather school and course info
(mind you I can change this already but just as an FYI)
&gt; Tyson King Meadows
&gt; Matt Hirshberg

Schedule Assignments to Close
&gt; Ralph Durham
&gt; Jonathan Eastvold
&gt; Paul Weizer
&gt; Adam Newmark
&gt; Tongfi Kim
&gt; Erik Rankin
&gt; Andrew Matthews
&gt; Melissa Neal Stewart
&gt; Elizabeth Kloss

Let the students see the key after I grade the assignment.
&gt; Chapman Rackaway
<strong> </strong>

Possible export the scores in the notebook as points rather than percentages?
&gt; Erin Richards

Way to visually suggest already graded assignment.
&gt; Brian Dille at Mesa Community College

Provide a way for the instructor to communicate with students.
&gt; Jim Barnes at App State
&gt; Brian Kupfer at TCC (not closed yet though)

Better Assignment Browser
&gt; Kimi King - one page to see all videos on, say, courts

Soomo State &amp; Local Content
&gt; Stacey Hecht
&gt; William Mello

CQ Press State &amp; Local Content
&gt; Lilly Goren

CQ Press California Politics Content
&gt; Tressa Tabares at American River

Alternate view of Notebook
<blockquote>Is there a way I could get a list (in chronological order) of all assignments submitted to the Notebook? It would make it much easier to keep things current if I did not need to mouse over every box to confirm that nothing has changed. My idea for how this might look is something like the following:

Friday 12/4, 1:30pm - John Q. Public - Chapter 14, Assignment 3 (Hyperlink to assignment) - Initial submission
Friday 12/4, 2:08am - Jane Q. Smith - Chapter 12, Assignment 2 (Hyperlink to assignment) - Revision (last submitted 11/30, 7:07pm)
Thursday 12/3, 4:30pm - John H. Doe - Chapter 15, Assignment 4 (Hyperlink to assignment) - Initial submission

[Additional bells/whistles: If there were an easy way to broadcast this list as a password-protected RSS feed (and/or a Google gadget), then professors would be able to keep tabs on what was going on from their Google home pages or RSS readers. I'd use this additional feature if it were available, but its impact on usability would probably be minor at best. If it's easy to do, however (and my instinct is that it would be), it would be worth another marketing bullet point, though...]

from Jonathan Eastvold</blockquote>
&gt; JEastvold at TLC: when an assignment is past due, the notebook shows a check mark if completed, but the box is a different color indicating it was turned in late.

Custom RSS Feed
&gt; Dave Garrison of Ohio Christian wants his FOX feed.

Sandbox for Looking and Building
&gt; Jonathon Eastvold is using grading term "curriculumBuild" as a work around

Forum
&gt; J Eastvold think it would be good for students to have a place to discuss amongst each other. Support could monitor and intervene on complaints. Also, a private for profs to discuss amongst themselves about scholastic issues related to our platform. How they teach / grade / manage students.

Peer Review of Short Answer Questions
&gt; Vicki Rast from Troy -- likes the idea of students writing for their peers and thinks that rhetorical criticism is an important life/career skill.

Rhetoric
Add a rhetoric text to teach students how to write and set a writing standard for class submissions.

Nobody wants to teach grammar, so maybe a self service site the prof would refer students and perhaps assign at the start of the semester.
&gt; Lilly Goren
&gt; J Eastvold

Short Answer plus Multiple Choice
&gt; Jan Steffensmeier OSU

Notebook Export
&gt; Vicki Rast of Troy Univ: Would like two types of notebook exports
-one for full answers from short answer questions
- so she can grade off line and another that just shows participation (we have this now).

Maps!
&gt; Dwight and Dolly Mullen from UNC Asheville want maps or links to maps on AG, CG and IR.

Use the CQ test questions (ok'd by CQ) / randomized to curtail cheating / test to be timed
&gt; Paul Weizer at Fitchburg State

Multiple choice quiz - lock answers when clicking Save to Notebook, not before
&gt; Erin Richards - deal breaker
&gt; J. Eastvold - sort of

Email all - a button that would allow a prof to email the entire class with one click
&gt;Erin Richards

Announcements
<h2>----------- ALREADY DONE</h2>
 Comment on Quizzes
Give professors the ability to comment  on a quiz in the system,  instead of through email.
Notified   David Slade (Culturas)
Notified  Druscilla Scribner
Notified   Jonathan Eastvold
&gt; Mary  Bierlo, Univeristy of South Dakota 605-677-6317
Notified  Steve  Meinhold, UNC - Wilmington
Notified  Brad Young, OCC, would like  to test drive it immediately  if it become live before Spring semester  ends.
Notified  Gary Copeland - U of Oklahoma
Notified   Chapman "won't use healthcare in big sections until he can  use a  comment box per assignment"

 Multiple Choice
Notified  Geoff Peterson
Notified  Tressa Tabares
Notified   Stacey Hecht
Notified  Chad Lupinacci

 Simple Grading
Notified  Chapman Rackaway -- can't use with larger classes until I   have (red, yellow, green) grading and a comment box

Notified   Yaloff -- need , -, + for quick grading

 Bb Building Block
Notified  Philip Crenshaw at ECCC in MS for use by students starting  Jan 11.
Notified  Scott Baily at Troy for use by students starting March 1
Notified  Ann Douglas at Troy for Dev Psych]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-12-04 20:38:47</wp:post_date_gmt>

		<title>Soomopedia</title>

Who we will and won't link to, how and why.

		<wp:post_id>1838</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-07-19 21:18:28</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-07-20 04:18:28</wp:post_date_gmt>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Policy / Editorial / Linking</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/policy-editorial-linking/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 22 Jul 2010 19:27:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://soomopub.com/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>

This document outlines Soomo's policies on linking and permissions.

We are a commercial service - people pay for access to our site. And if we host someone else's content in our site, we ensure that we have rights to do so. When we link to a publicly available web page, however, permission is neither required nor sought.

There was some controversy covered by media between 2000-2005 over the ethics of "deep linking." Deep linking means linking to a page within a site, rather to the site's home page. The problem arose because some sites wanted everyone coming through their home page first and to own the experience of getting to those deep pages. So NYTimes home first, then click, click, click to see an article.

A solid, succinct summary of the issue with a nice bibliography is, predictably, here:<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_linking">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_linking</a>

This controversy ended years ago and the widely accepted status is that people can link to other people's web pages. In fact, if you've posted a web page, you are probably hoping people will link to it and are glad when they do. If you don't want people to link to your web page, you don't post it, or put it behind a password, or use a session cookie to prevent people from getting to it without passing through some other page first -- for example, the 4th page of an Amazon checkout.

Back to today and Soomo, people are glad we link to them. If anyone ever complains about us linking to them we will certainly stop, but to date it hasn't happened. And I don't know of any case in which people would be disappointed to find out that we are linking to them.

That said, there are some unethical ways of linking and practices to avoid.

These are things we do not do:

- we don't use the url of someone else's resource (image, audio, pdf) direct from our site, unless they offer embed code (as at YouTube.) (e.g. we won't embed your picture on our site in our page as if we're hosting it.)

- we don't send people to a site in a way that prevents people from seeing their ads (by resizing the window or stripping html on the fly)

- we don't send people to a site in a way that obscures the identity of that site, or frames it to pass it off as our own. (e.g. we won't open a soomo frame and display all or part of someone else's page within it)

- we won't hack or subvert a site to present it in a way the site owner is trying to prevent. (e.g. Annenberg prevents their videos from being opened directly. Clearly they want viewers to land on the launch page first. So that's where we send them, even though it's an extra click for the student.)

- we won't use a third party site to strip a site in a way the original site isn't sanctioning (e.g. quiet tube)

All of these could probably be summarized by simply stating, "The rights holder has a right to determine the conditions in which the content is displayed. We will respect these rights."

But linking directly to a specific page on a public site, where people can read, watch or download files, is unambiguously legal and widely accepted. This is not a grey area, legally vague or shady. It is very simply how the web works.

Linking is not a crime. Publicly available websites want us to link to them. We are not selling their content -- we are selling our platform, our features, our editorial discretion in choosing this particular part of their site, the context and questions around it and support for those attempting to learn from it.

For example, we do not sell the commercials from Living Room Candidate. We sell access to and support for our platform, including a collection of assignments, including an assignment on campaign ads, which selected nine of those commercials, supplied context around them and questions to consider. When it's time to watch the ad, students go to the Living Room candidate and watch them as the museum intended.

We are not stealing other people's pages and charging for them. We are making the web assignable. And in the process purchasing permission for all we host, linking to many other reputable sites in ways they desire, and making our own original content freely available to others.

As new questions and new uses cases arise, please let me know.

David Lindrum
May 25, 2010

</div>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Policy / Editorial / Linking</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/policy-editorial-linking-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Jul 2010 05:04:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?page_id=1864</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This document outlines Soomo's policies on linking and permissions.

We are a commercial service - people pay for access to our site. And if we host someone else's content in our site, we ensure that we have rights to do so. When we link to a publicly available web page, however, permission is neither required nor sought.

There was some controversy covered by media between 2000-2005 over the ethics of "deep linking." Deep linking means linking to a page within a site, rather to the site's home page. The problem arose because some sites wanted everyone coming through their home page first and to own the experience of getting to those deep pages. So NYTimes home first, then click, click, click to see an article.

A solid, succinct summary of the issue with a nice bibliography is, predictably, here: <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_linking">http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_linking</a>


This controversy ended years ago and the widely accepted status is that people can link to other people's web pages. In fact, if you've posted a web page, you are probably hoping people will link to it and are glad when they do. If you don't want people to link to your web page, you don't post it, or put it behind a password, or use a session cookie to prevent people from getting to it without passing through some other page first -- for example, the 4th page of an Amazon checkout.


Back to today and Soomo, people are glad we link to them. If anyone ever complains about us linking to them we will certainly stop, but to date it hasn't happened. And I don't know of any case in which people would be disappointed to find out that we are linking to them.


That said, there are some unethical ways of linking and practices to avoid.

These are things we do not do:

- we don't use the url of someone else's resource (image, audio, pdf) direct from our site, unless they offer embed code (as at YouTube.) (e.g. we won't embed your picture on our site in our page as if we're hosting it.)

- we don't send people to a site in a way that prevents people from seeing their ads (by resizing the window or stripping html on the fly)

- we don't send people to a site in a way that obscures the identity of that site, or frames it to pass it off as our own. (e.g. we won't open a soomo frame and display all or part of someone else's page within it)


- we won't hack or subvert a site to present it in a way the site owner is trying to prevent. (e.g. Annenberg prevents their videos from being opened directly. Clearly they want viewers to land on the launch page first. So that's where we send them, even though it's an extra click for the student.)

- we won't use a third party site to strip a site in a way the original site isn't sanctioning (e.g. quiet tube)


All of these could probably be summarized by simply stating, "The rights holder has a right to determine the conditions in which the content is displayed. We will respect these rights."


But linking directly to a specific page on a public site, where people can read, watch or download files, is unambiguously legal and widely accepted. This is not a grey area, legally vague or shady. It is very simply how the web works.

Linking is not a crime. Publicly available websites want us to link to them. We are not selling their content -- we are selling our platform, our features, our editorial discretion in choosing this particular part of their site, the context and questions around it and support for those attempting to learn from it.

For example, we do not sell the commercials from Living Room Candidate. We sell access to and support for our platform, including a collection of assignments, including an assignment on campaign ads, which selected nine of those commercials, supplied context around them and questions to consider. When it's time to watch the ad, students go to the Living Room candidate and watch them as the museum intended.

We are not stealing other people's pages and charging for them. We are making the web assignable. And in the process purchasing permission for all we host, linking to many other reputable sites in ways they desire, and making our own original content freely available to others.

As new questions and new uses cases arise, please let me know.

David Lindrum
May 25, 2010]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Video Concepts</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/video-concepts/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Aug 2010 21:15:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>timaldengrant</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Holes in AG</strong>

 Foreign Policy  What is it? Who makes it? Who administers it? What is Americas role in the world?

 National Security / Defense / Terrorism  What is national security about? What are the threats on our security? What impact does our involvement in other nations have on our government?

 Domestic Policy  What is it? How is it made? What are the issues? I suggest we pick from the list below (the top three are most often mentioned in textbooks) to create multiple assignments in a Domestic Policy chapter from which profs can pick their favorites:

Environment / Energy  what environmental concerns does America face? whats the government doing to address those concerns?
Economy / Budget / Taxes  how does the economy work? what goes into making the national budget? where do our taxes go?
Welfare &amp; Poverty  whats the government doing to help poor people?
Health Care  what is the current debate about national health care issues? whats up with social security?
Immigration  what are the current questions about immigration? what are the implications of these issues in light of our democracy?
Crime  what is the status of crime in the US? what is the government doing to address it? this could also go in S&amp;L / local cops
Drugs  what is the status of the war on drugs? what is the government doing about it? how does this effect peoples lives?
Education  what is the current national debate about education? what are the needs/victories? whats the govts role?

 Globalization  The process by which nations are becoming more interdependent, and the implications of this process on technology, global resources, environmental concerns, etc. One way to explore this is how our foreign policy is informed by one of these elements.

The Check Rating System:

 One check indicates 1-3 correlations need this resource
 Two checks indicate 5-8 correlations need this resource
 Three checks indicate 9 or more correlations need this resource

<strong>Ideas for AG</strong>

The birth &amp; life of a road sign. How theyre written, designed, produced, and implemented.

Wheres the line? Junk food, pot, alcohol, tobacco, prostitution. Where/how does the line get drawn and who in the government draws it?

Ask an expert. A poli-sci expert/prof translates a complex conversation into understandable, entertaining/funny terms.

Greatest speechs ever given. Deliver famous speechs in broad public places with hidden cameras.

Graphic design a political add.

<strong>Ideas for NWLM</strong>

A comedian delivering subject(NWLM) geek jokes. her rhetorical triangle was a little askew. How do I know? Her pathos slapped me across the face! Note: This could work for severaldisciplines.

<strong>Ideas for Marketing Videos</strong>

Soomos Awesome! A textbook has 3 parts: Topic, Reference, Story. We do all of those things.

Soomo Garage]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2751</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-08-10 14:15:44</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-08-10 21:15:44</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<wp:post_name>video-concepts</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>Paper Editing Handbook</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/paper-editing-handbook/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Aug 2010 21:25:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>timaldengrant</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Documentary videos can be as simple as one talking head, but even that requires editing. These instructions will help you create what we are calling a "paper edit", a document that will guide a video editor on what cuts to make and where.

This instructional is based in MacsPAGESinterface.MirosoftsWORDhas a similarly titled tool set, so these instructions should translate fairly well.

Note: Please chime in with any suggestions on how to improve this document.

<!--more-->

1. Start by opening the source transcript. Click SAVE AS and name the file:(original transcript name)_(project name)_source

Note: If you want to include clips from several transcripts in your new paper edit, open each original source transcript in a separate window andSAVE AS.

2. Create a new document and name it:(project name)_edited

The content of the paper edit will be created by copying each clip you want to use from the source transcript(s), and pasting it into your new paper edit document. The key is supplying enough individual clip information, in both the new paper edit, and the source transcript, to make it easy to reference between the documents and find the clip you want in either document.

4. Select(highlight) the first clip you want from the desired source transcript.

5. Click theCOMMENTbutton near the top of the window.

This will open a new field to the left.

6. Put the following information into the field:

(original transcript name)  (closest time stamp(give a + or - if time stamp appears before or after selected text)) - (clip number(in numerical order within the source transcript))

7. Now select the same clip you attached your comment to. Choose&gt;COPY.

8. Activate your new paper edit document. Choose&gt;PASTE.

The comment is copied into the pasted clip as well. ClickCOMMENTand it will display the clip information.

Start creating your edit. Feel free to keep it simple and have only the clips in your intended sequential order, or add chapter headings, text slides, voice over suggestions, whatever you feel necessary to tell the story you are trying to tell.

Now we can easily reference between the two documents. This becomes very useful when creating complex paper edits that use clips in a non-linear fashion. By creating two documents, you as the paper editor can quickly review your work on the edited document, and supply enough reference information to locate each used clip in the source transcript. By locating the clip in the source transcript, the video editor can locate the source video clip for the video edit.

9. When delivering your paper edit to the video editor, remember to include your source transcript(s).

Note: If working inPAGES, please export aWORDformatted file.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2759</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-08-10 14:25:39</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-08-10 21:25:39</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>paper-editing-handbook</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>154</wp:comment_id>

	<item>
		<title>Slides</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/02/slides/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 Feb 2008 21:04:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=9</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[Image missing]

37 Signals noted that when you click on a thumbnail on<a href="http://www.apple.com/macbookair/" target="_blank">this page</a> at Apple's site for the new Macbook Air, the next image slides in from the right.Very cool.

Tim -- you talked about horizontal organization of artifacts for Disco, this is a bit of that. And for ages we've talked about a splash page the slides off, cubes away or dissolves to reveal a fully loaded TOC.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Publix</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/publix/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 08 Mar 2008 14:59:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=21</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[(<span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style:italic">I'm really liking WordPress, but can not figure out how to create linebreaks or get P tags to stick. Advice welcome.</span>) -------- I love the design of Publix generic products. And I'm not the only one. This<a href="http://www.flickr.com/photos/hyku/108460864/in/pool-publix" target="_blank" title="publix packaging">photo</a>is one of several tributes to Publix packaging in a flickr pool celebrating the grocer. The official, albeit decrepit,<a href="http://www.publixpackaging.com/" target="_blank">blog is here</a>.I'm not entirely sure why they work so well. A sense of<a href="http://flickr.com/photos/philsown/151533864/" target="_blank">humor</a>is often employed which is fabulous. But that's not what drew me to them.Most brands are represented by bags, boxes and bottles on shelves clamoring for attention and working perhaps too hard to build a reputation in a few square inches. Amidst the clamor the Publix packages come off as restful."Publix" appears in a small black circle. That's it for parent company branding. A small black circle that nods to the idea of "label" and to the tradition of "generic."The packages are mostly white with a strong color from a consistent palette and the colors chosen do not seem to correlate to the product -- they don't carry meaning.The simple, understated illustrations used are often nostalgic, humble and plain spoken. And the labeling is counter-intuitively thoughtful. A sack of All Purpose Flour, for example, emphasizes "All Purpose" instead of "Flour" which is exactly right for the searcher whether I'm searching the aisles or my pantry.<br class="webkit-block-placeholder" />Thoughtful. Consistent. Minimal. Humorous. Great use of color and illustration. Highly usable. Clean. Light. Simple. Attractive. I think part of the reason they have the freedom to do this is that they aren't having to work so hard for an identity. They don't need to say as much. Likewise, Soomo pages are somewhat unique. We don't display ads. We aren't exchanging links with others. We aren't trying to drive traffic to other pages or retain eyeballs. We have an opportunity to simply and directly meet the needs of a rather narrow audience. We know a lot about who they are, why they are here and what they are seeking. We can just serve it up - simply, thoughtfully, cleanly, without a lot of carnival barking. We can afford humility and white space. There are no constraints on our color or pressures against usability. And, for a lot of decision making professors and publishers it has in fact been professional, thoughtful, simple design that has made soomo stand out in the first three screens.(<span style="font-style:italic" class="Apple-style-span">granted, this dilutes the focus on ajax capabilities, so I'm adding a "graphic" tag to this one.</span>)]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Cool lightbox function</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/cool-lightbox-function/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 09 Mar 2008 01:27:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=37</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Like that method for displaying images that get clicked where it dims the screen and pops the image in a little box?  It works via a Wordpress plugin called Lightbox2.

Just add rel="lightbox" just after the href= portion of the html tag.  An example image is pasted below.
The code that makes it work is <pre>img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/blog-slide-show1.png" rel="lightbox" alt="blog-slide-show.png" border="0" width="610" height="425" align="left" /&gt;</pre>
<img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/blog-slide-show1.png" alt="blog-slide-show.png" border="0" width="610" height="425" align="left" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>37</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2008-03-08 21:27:27</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2008-03-09 01:27:27</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>cool-lightbox-function</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="wordpress"><![CDATA[wordpress]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Rate Me</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/rate-me/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 12 Mar 2008 04:45:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=45</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As an experiment last summer I ran a question at the bottom of some of the quizzes in Rackaway's course asking students what they thought of the assignment. We got some meaningful feedback, but it didn't feel entirely right sitting there looking exactly like all the other questions. Since then I've seen a couple interesting ways of doing it.This one is drop dead simple:<p style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/star-rating.png" height="48" width="133" border="0" alt="star rating.png" /></p>Two lines of code from <a href="http://js-kit.com/ratings/?wow">these folks</a>.It's pretty obvious what it's for and would at least show us which assignments attract 5's and 1's. But it doesn't really go with the site, so we might want to look a little further for a better looking version or build our own.Macworld has their own, I believe, and it simplifies the rating to up and down and provides a means of commenting. That might work better for us - just a simple "recommend this assignment?" with an option to comment on it. What do y'all think?<p style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/macworld-rating.png" height="86" width="258" border="0" alt="macworld rating.png" /></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Wiki Help</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/wiki-help/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 15 Mar 2008 15:06:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=51</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The folks at<a href="http://www.morphexchange.com/helpme">MorphMe had an idea</a>to create help pages on a wiki frame. They do the hosting in exchange for the ad revenue, which won't work for us. But I like the idea of making the support pages a wiki. Initially there'd be a design investment as we recast our help pages to fit. But thereafter, it might make it really fast to extend by creating new pages and updating links. Something to think about.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Fixed!  Sorting of reference links</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/02/fixed-sorting-of-reference-links/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 Feb 2008 20:38:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://skunkworks.soomo.org/?p=16</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last week we were stumped trying to change the order of reference links within a chapter.  Except for Chris - who found the genius workaround by deleting and recreating the whole list.David applied a fix to the code this week and we are now able to slide reference links anywhere we please.<br /><br /><span class="Apple-style-span" style="color:#0000ee"><img src="http://skunkworks.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/02/reflink.png" alt="reflink.png" /></span><a href="http://skunkworks.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/02/reflink.png" title="reflink.png"></a>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Washington Post news feed</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/washington-post-news-feed/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 Mar 2008 19:32:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://skunkworks.soomo.org/?p=42</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Friday afternoon we saw a rash of exceptions reporting that the newsfeed from The Washington Post was not loading.  David quickly moved The New York Times to the default position to quiet down the exception notifier.We reload the feed every time the page is requested, so our initial hypothesis was that we were generating too much traffic and they blocked us.We tested again today and found the feed healthy, so perhaps it was a momentary lapse on their end.<img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/washpost.png" height="224" width="243" border="0" alt="WashPost.png" />]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Monster in the house (eating books)</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/monster-in-the-house-eating-books/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 14 Mar 2008 17:01:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.delicious-monster.com/" target="_blank">Delicious Monster</a>has been employed to keep track of our growing library @Soomo.Asheville.It uses the Mac iSight camera to read bar codes on books and record them into the database.<p style="text-align:left"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/barcode.png" height="264" width="329" border="0" alt="barcode.png" /></p> We need to have a book scanning party to populate the database.  Once up to date, no more sleepless nights wondering who has what, where or when.  Finally..<p style="text-align:left"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/library.png" height="526" width="908" border="0" alt="library.png" /></p>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Blist</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/blist/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 19 Mar 2008 00:43:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=57</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://blist.com/demo.html">Blist</a> is web based database. Two things I like. One, it's an interesting way to track image permissions because you can do the permissions spreadsheet with cells that include images. Two, it provides yet another implementation of the increasingly common technique of showing a thumbnail of a site when you roll over the link to that site. That would work well for just about all of our links in AG I should think. (The following shot is from Guy's blog, not Blist)

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/snapshot.png" alt="snapshot.png" border="0" width="484" height="428" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/twitter-error/</link>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[So...I'm twittering again. <del>If you want to follow along with where my hours are going you are welcome to here: twitter.com/lindrum.</del> (All done trying that out, let's try <a href="http://lindrum.tumblr.com/">tumblr</a> instead.)I recently triggered an error and received this stylish page.<p style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/twitter-error-msg.png" height="679" width="812" border="0" alt="twitter error msg.png" /></p>To me it seems thoughtful, conveys a sense of humor and style, and is actually quite reassuring. I assume their guy has now received a notice that this thing, whatever it is, broke and they're on it. Quite reassuring actually. In the face of a world so clearly broken, here at least someone is paying attention and fixing things. Ahhh. It's going to be okay.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Real estate availability in Phoenix</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/real-estate-availability-in-phoenix/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 Mar 2008 18:02:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=67</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Who cares, right? The UI made me click it.

Grey = space available for rent
Black = rented space

<a href="http://www.collierscafe.com/_Skyline/skyline.html" target="_blank"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/phoenix.png" alt="phoenix.png" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Vimeo Roadmap</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/vimeo-roadmap/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 26 Mar 2008 12:42:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=75</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Thanks DP for the pointer to Vimeo. Lot's of nice touches there. Like <a href="http://www.vimeo.com/roadmap">this page</a> which offers a roadmap to imminent new features at Vimeo.
<br />
A couple things to notice:
1) I like the bars that clearly locate the information, then spring apart in an accordion style. I could definitely see constructing a TOC this way.
2) Mighty gutsy of them to post "coming soon" features, even more so to put release dates on the title bars, and even more so (if not sarcastic) to include percentage complete.
3) I like sketches. Anytime, anywhere and love that they put theirs up here. (in the video and through the thumbnails on the right.)

As for communicating with users, the video sets the bar pretty low, but does the job. I suppose it is nearly compulsory on this video site.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/vimeo-roadmap1.png" alt="vimeo roadmap.png" border="0" width="632" height="739" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The folks at Dragon have a product call <a href="http://www.nuance.com/audiomining/">AudioMining</a> intended to transcribe recorded audio in real time and index it. 	<item>
		<title>roll-over tour</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/roll-over-tour/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 29 Mar 2008 17:38:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=81</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.epiclearningsystem.com/about_epicTechnology.asp">This was one</a> I hadn't seen lately. The "links" at the top don't actually link, but do trigger rollovers which highlight and describe parts of the screen below. The screen is clearly not live in this angled mock-up on a laptop. It's in some ways modification of the <a href="http://www.basecamphq.com/tour">screen-part tours</a> (dissections) that basecamp does.  Could be far more complete, but an interesting move.

<img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/epic.jpg" alt="epic.jpg" border="0" width="369" height="407" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Green Room Video Selector</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/green-room-video-selector/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 31 Mar 2008 11:42:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=83</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The television show <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/ThisWeek/BehindTheScenes/">This Week</a> offers additional content online. It's interesting to see the different production style they offer for "web video" as opposed to broadcast. Far less polished and presumable "authentic." Hmmm.

They offer two ways to select clips -- a conventional list on the left or a 3-line, pop-up scrolling area right in the video. I'm not sure it's a good solution, but it's interesting to see others working through these issues.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/greenboxed.png" alt="greenboxed.png" border="0" width="517" height="322" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>hulu</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/04/hulu/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 05 Apr 2008 03:38:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=91</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In the blog of a friend, I find an <a href="http://web.mac.com/scottstewart2/Site_2/The_Stewart_Blog/Entries/2008/4/2_The_One-Upper.html">embedded hulu video</a>.

If I click the play button it plays in place. If I click the hulu bar it lets me watch at <a href="http://www.hulu.com/">hulu</a>.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/hulu.jpg" alt="hulu.jpg" border="0" width="586" height="266" /></div>

The flash-based player on the hulu site includes:
- grey bars right and left that populate with icons on rollover, then fade out on roll off
- code to embed and email, full screen mode and the "lower lights" trick.
- "share" makes it easy to share via 8 different major social spaces. Note that you can set start and end times and thus just share a clip with friends. Great model for asking students "select the section of video in which Cory Booker explains why he's running."

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/hulushare.jpg" alt="hulushare.jpg" border="0" width="593" height="276" /></div>



- details...sounds boring no matter how I write it, but I like the implementation and the metadata. (You know I crave more context most of the time.)

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/picture-1.png" alt="Picture 1.png" border="0" width="593" height="276" /></div>

- the Pop Out button opens a slightly smaller video in a new window with reconfigured controls, pulling a number of things (including the Direct TV ad) into the video frame.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/popout.png" alt="popout.png" border="0" width="593" height="276" /></div>

They have complete shows (e.g. Simpsons) and feature length movies (Monty Python's Meaning of Life). There are "limited commercial interruptions" indicated by glowing "beads" on the timeline and when the commercial plays it lets you know how many seconds until we go back to the video. I'm positive I'm not seeing everything here, but that's quite a lot already. Many nice choices.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Terrabytes in the house</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/terrabytes-in-the-house/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 26 Mar 2008 17:00:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://skunkworks.soomo.org/?p=56</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.lacie.com/us/index.htm" target="_blank">LaCie</a> and <a href="www.apricorn.com" target="_blank">Apricorn</a> delivered some new storage for us yesterday. Chris gets a 1tb LaCie to use for English video and her time machine backups. The BigMac will get another terrabyte LaCie to add to its storage array.

<a href="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/lacie.jpg" title="lacie.JPG"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/lacie.jpg" alt="lacie.JPG" /></a>

David and I will be testing these little Apricorn 250gb firewire drives.  Thanks DP for the heads up on this little beauty.  No power cord, firewire cable built in - nothing to lose or forget.

<a href="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/apricorn2.jpg" title="apricorn2.JPG"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/apricorn2.jpg" alt="apricorn2.JPG" /></a>

We are going to use <a href="http://www.shirt-pocket.com/SuperDuper/SuperDuperDescription.html" target="_blank">SuperDuper.</a>  to make a bootable backup of our mac onto the external drive.  Should the unthinkable happen, this drive becomes the parachute that will let us boot to our "Mac" from another working Mac.  It can also be used to restore our current environment to a blank disk if that every becomes necessary.

<a href="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/apricorn.jpg" title="apricorn.JPG"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/apricorn.jpg" alt="apricorn.JPG" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Safety net for our blogs - because every post is precious</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/03/safety-net-for-our-blogs-because-every-post-is-precious/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 27 Mar 2008 21:33:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://skunkworks.soomo.org/?p=63</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align:left">In pursuit of maintaining our blog presence in the face of server disaster, I put together some scripts to help protect our assets. All three blogs are organized under /home/blogs in their own tidy directories.</p><p style="text-align:left">Backups: Every morning at 4 AM a script will copy /home/blogs/wordpress* into a time stamped archive. It will be moved to Amazon's S3 vault and kept for a long time. That same archive will be copied to a different file name for use in the deployment process.</p><p style="text-align:left">Install: In the event that the host server needs to be rebuilt, a script is in place to grab the most recent backup file and install it during the server build process, bringing our blogs back to live without missing a post.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Evernote</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/04/evernote/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 22 Apr 2008 12:45:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=101</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Here's how Evernote, a web app to collect images and notes, solves a collection of image assets. Vertical collection of assets with an independent scroller on the right. I think we're headed in the right direction for disco but saw this as another example of trying to solve a similar problem.
<p style="text-align:center"><a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/evernote.png"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-102" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/evernote.png" alt="" width="300" height="239" /></a></p>]]></content:encoded>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The quicklook interface in Mail for messages with multiple images is quite a nice UI for image browsing.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/quicklook.png" alt="quicklook.png" border="0" width="500" height="323" /></div>

- next
- back
- index sheet
- full screen with disappearing controls.
and more. I like the "play" button and "add to iPhoto" for snapshots sent my way.]]></content:encoded>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[What do y'all think? Should we simply be responsible with data? Or should we formalize policies? I'm assuming we're all in favor of privacy and opposed to time spent on stuff that doesn't generate real value. So does this generate real value?]]></content:encoded>

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/vimeo-are-you-sure.jpg" alt="vimeo are you sure.jpg" border="0" width="583" height="265" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>WriteRoom</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/04/writeroom/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Apr 2008 00:30:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=121</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[WriteRoom offers, well:

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/writeroom.jpg" alt="Writeroom.jpg" border="0" width="597" height="145" /></div>

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/writeroom-color-screens.png" alt="writeroom-color-screens.png" border="0" width="648" height="143" /></div>

I keep coming back to this notion of "zen workspace" as exemplified in write room and in these clutter free views of other apps. However busy the apps are, just surrounding them with some empty space is pleasant.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/tech-spacesex.jpg" alt="TECH_spacesEX.jpg" border="0" width="648" height="141" /></div>

White space is rare on the web. We have a huge advantage in being allowed to create pages that are really about what is in the middle of the screen. No ads. Very little branding. No links to reciprocating sites, cross-branding, or other attempts to drive traffic and entice into tangents. It's a blessing.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>121</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2008-04-28 20:30:29</wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>writeroom</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>

		<wp:post_id>125</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>Cartoon = Milestone!</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/04/cartoon-milestone/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 18 Apr 2008 19:50:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://skunkworks.soomo.org/?p=79</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/cartoon.png"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-80" src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/04/cartoon.png" alt="" width="300" height="141" /></a>
Today's the first time a political cartoon has been featured on Americans Governing. As a truly valid means of political discourse, it seems appropriate that we would use them as artifacts. Historically it's proven difficult to get the rights to reprint a cartoon. <a href="http://cagle.com" target="_blank">Daryl Cagle's Professional Cartoonist Index</a> makes it easier than ever.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Introducting Dev.soomo.org</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/05/introducting-devsoomoorg/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 May 2008 17:08:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=187</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Hey, we are re-jiggering our blog structure a little bit. Skunkworks.soomo.org is dead.

Long live<strong> </strong>Dev.soomo.org, our new client facing blog of all things fresh and new at Soomo. I stripped some of the most appropriate posts from Skunkworks and dropped them into Dev. As we update our software, add staff, make big important changes - Dev is where we'll post it.

Others will be watching which begs the question - where do we post stuff for internal digestion? Well, we have ui.soomo.org. If we are going to change it's role, we probably ought to give it a new name. Here are a few to seed the process. Drop a comment to let me know your thoughts and ideas.
<ul>
	<li> Peat - where soomo grows</li>
	<li> Idea Farming - fresh soomo</li>
	<li> Fresh - never frozen</li>
	<li> Under The Hood</li>
	<li> Darkroom - developing soomo</li>
	<li> Sprout</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Database servers - upgraded</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/05/database-servers-upgraded/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 May 2008 21:22:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=188</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Thanks to Richard at RightScale and David, we got our database servers upgraded today in no time at all with no interruption at all. That feels great!

These two servers are configured in a fail over pair. That means if the main server takes a dirt nap, the secondary server will pick up without a hitch - no data loss, no service interruption.

Today, we get to say that these two servers are now physically separated as well. Amazon is now offering the opportunity to designate where your server lives. Both are on the east coast of the US but they are in different data centers. So if the building where our primary database server resides takes a dirt nap - or burns down - or some other bad thing, our secondary server will not be affected - nor will our customers.

(If you have read this far and are not glazed over thinking about your next meal, good for you - let me buy you a congratulatory latte.)

Anyway, we are in a better server spot today than we were yesterday and that is nice.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>database-servers-upgraded</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>The Transitions Are Coming</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/05/the-transitions-are-coming/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 04 May 2008 01:02:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://ui.soomo.org/?p=190</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Wireframing tends to focus on the basic states of our various screens. E.g.; here I'm logged in as a student, looking at my home page in week two.

But one of the ways we will make our site a pleasure to use and all kinds of snappy feeling is with transitions -- the things that happen between screens. A recent example is the fabulous way DP's new (Psych) video player resizes while playing as the questions move on and off the screen.

So in the name of thinking about transitions, I offer this one. On the <a href="http://textpattern.com/">textpattern homepage</a>, click any thumbnail. (Skip the first one which includes animation and thus confuses the issue.)

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://ui.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/05/textpattern.jpg" alt="Textpattern.jpg" border="0" width="432" height="471" /></div>

I like the two step zoom out and the layered load. Roll over and rightish and you'll see a next button. I like the smooth shift to the new size before the image loads.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>190</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>the-transitions-are-coming</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

	<item>
		<title>Full Screen</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/05/full-screen/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 15 May 2008 00:27:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=203</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A friend's blog pointed me to <a href="http://gallery.mac.com/philipp.brendel#100281">this video page</a>. Not Flash but Quicktime, so it can't do the "fullscreen" Flash trick. It gets almost the same effect by maximizing the browser and expanding the player, though that keeps the browser chrome on screen. Since you don't need to "press ESC to exit full screen" they created a un-maximize button which is a pretty effective little icon.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://shoebox.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/05/exit-full-screen.jpg" alt="exit full screen.jpg" border="0" width="190" height="57" /></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Timeline</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/05/timeline/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 15 May 2008 18:03:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=205</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Orange Peel offers one way to do a timeline.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://shoebox.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/05/orangepeeltimeline.jpg" alt="orangepeeltimeline.jpg" border="0" width="478" height="717" /></div>

I like the chaos which feels rich. The distinctive typography brings a lot of humanity to each event. I like the non-standard images and the way things spill over into each other and just take as much room s they need -- like life. Interestingly, I find it hard to read as a whole. Which might be a good thing. Each line has asserted its individuality.

One problem -- timelines map time -- they show time spatially. And if the spacing isn't proportional, then the map is not to scale. So that bugs me.

But overall, it reminds me a lot of one of the TOCs we floated for Disco. I'm seeing it as a kind of scrapbooky TOC.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<title>Video Lecture</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/07/video-lecture/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 18 Jul 2008 20:20:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We've been playing with how to make a lecture compelling on the web. <a href="http://www.pickensplan.com/">These people</a> have put some thought into it -- good delivery, heavy editing (I suspect) to make a concise delivery, strengthened with overlay graphics, jump cuts covered with stock photos. An interesting submission to this global conversation.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://shoebox.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/07/pickensplan.jpg" alt="PickensPlan.jpg" border="0" width="639" height="356" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Slow Connection?</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/07/slow-connection/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 18 Jul 2008 20:22:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=230</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Another note from the <a href="http://www.pickensplan.com/">Picken's Plan</a> video Tom sent to me -- I like the way they let slow connection folks opt out. For the vast majority of viewers, our 1000kbps stream rate is fine. Yet "painfully slow video" is a leading complaint because for the few who don't have the pipes, it's excruciating.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://shoebox.soomo.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/07/slowcnxn.jpg" alt="slowcnxn.jpg" border="0" width="672" height="438" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Switching Classes</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/09/switching-classes/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 10 Sep 2008 11:34:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=257</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Another cue from 37 -- this thin black meta-menu allowing switching between applications is reasonably unobstrusive.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/09/switching-for-classes.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-258" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/09/switching-for-classes.jpg" alt="" width="338" height="256" /></a>

Our drop down takes up less precious vertical space, can use larger text and is arguably even less obtrusive. But it hides some data, which is both good and bad, and has left more than one user confused as to where their class went. Applying the thin black meta menu strategy in a hasty mock up, I get this:

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/09/metamenu.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-259" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/09/metamenu.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="286" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Getting Started with Apple (for Schools)</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/10/getting-started-with-apple-for-schools/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 08 Oct 2008 17:41:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=267</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Here's an interesting solution to self-identifying before clicking. The self description is text, then the button is the verb.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/apple-getting-started.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-268" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/apple-getting-started.jpg" alt="" width="426" height="399" /></a>

If you choose to Select Your College, they don't bring up a map. Instead, they ask for zip or city. Interesting choice. I wonder if it's fewer clicks? In most cases I don't think I knew my school's zip -- but then I didn't live on campus.



<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/apple-school-finder.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-269" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/apple-school-finder.jpg" alt="" width="305" height="297" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Barbaripedia</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/10/barbaripedia/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Oct 2008 17:45:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=271</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Interesting way to do the <a href="http://www.barbariangroup.com/barbaripedia">timeline</a> from <a href="http://www.barbariangroup.com/">Barbarian</a>. All one screen, roll-over to explore, no reload time. And you get a sense that things really picked up in 05-06. Nice colors. I wonder how many people look at three and stop poking? The whole is a bit small for my eyes, but lovely.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/barbaripedia.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-272" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/barbaripedia.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="200" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Learn More? Or Get Started?</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/10/learn-more-or-get-started/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Oct 2008 11:00:31 +0000</pubDate>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[

<a href="http://disqus.com/">Disqus</a> has two options for you:

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/start-or-learn-1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-289" style="text-decoration:underline" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/start-or-learn-1.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="310" /></a>



When I grabbed that screen, I grabbed it because I really liked it. But evidently, the folks at Disqus weren't quite satisfied and they're not flying a simpler page. Not that "Learn More" has become a much quieter "next."

	<item>
		<title>These are the updates you are looking for.</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/10/these-are-the-updates-you-are-looking-for/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 20 Oct 2008 11:12:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=298</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Nice opt-in from the folks at DV magazine. They don't assume I'm wanting more email, but they explain why they'd like to contact me. I feel more important already.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/dv-opt-in.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-299" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/dv-opt-in.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="62" /></a>



At ARC90, I'm not sure if they're going to email me or not. I think maybe they can, but it doesn't look like they make a habit of it. So a clean crisp promise, with a little New York thrown in for free.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/spamhater.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-301" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/spamhater.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="198" /></a>





Meanwhile, over at Simba, I opted out. And they respect that. But they sent me an email asking me to please reconsider. Much bigger footprint than on most in/out selectors.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/simba_s-second-attempt.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-300" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/simba_s-second-attempt.jpg" alt="" width="482" height="490" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_id>304</wp:post_id>

	<item>
		<title>Join Vimeo</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/10/join-vimeo/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 23 Oct 2008 11:19:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=307</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://vimeo.com/">Vimeo</a> knows who Vimeo knows.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/vimeo1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-309" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/vimeo1.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="225" /></a>



Choose to join Vimeo, and the lights go dim while a spot light shines on a sunny place where everything is happy and simple.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/join-vimeo.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-308" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/join-vimeo.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="519" /></a>



And once you've confirmed your email, things remain just as simple. This little two box cloud floats above a landscape as big as your browser.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/vimeo-log-in.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-310" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/vimeo-log-in.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="359" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
