	<item>
		<title>The Soomos</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/10/the-soomos/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Oct 2008 11:24:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=317</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When we talk about giving out Soomos, I think first of the gold statue involved and possibly a dinner at APSA in which we announce them. But maybe there is a much, much better way to do it:
- one that makes available to anyone in the world humanizing stories of the winners and nominees,
- one that explains what we are recognizing sufficiently for the reader to apply it -- a bit like a virtual Teaching and Learning Conference; a bit like TED presentations by and for Poli Sci teachers.
- one that gets us on the campuses of those we are recognizing for some real get-to-know-you time with each of them and introductions to their peers, and a rich understanding of their situation, so that we can carry that message and really employ those tools.

<a href="http://www.creative30.net/">Volvo is sponsoring a contest</a> right now to celebrate the young and creative, and providing a nice illustration to accompany this vision of a library of profiles. I'm not sure profs would accept a "you choose who wins" approach, so we are thinking of an esteemed panel. But I love the idea of an array of thumbnails with rich rollovers. Click any one for a short profile on a successful teacher and some specific effective.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/creative-30.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-318" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/creative-30.jpg" alt="" width="242" height="300" /></a>

The reasons we want to award great teaching are to celebrate great teaching, spread the best ideas, encourage those doing great things, strengthen a culture which values great teaching and establish a reputation for Soomo as "all about the teaching." At it's most mature we become the first site instructors recommend to others as the place to learn how to teach better, and receiving a Soomo is ultimately a real and credible plus on your CV.

The best thing a prof can know about Soomo is that we cultivate and celebrate great teaching and we offer tools and content grounded in research and validated by the best professors.

[Thanks to Tim and Adam for the pointer.] ]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Why you need Mint.</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/10/why-you-need-mint/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Oct 2008 11:13:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=313</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Tim Grant pointed me to <a href="http://www.mint.com/">Mint.com</a>. They have two links on home for more info: "Features" and "Why Use Mint." If you are curious about why to use it, they break it down with four bullets, each with a paragraph and an image, to show how they deliver on their overarching promise. That's a nice model. (And if your use is not paying off debt, there are <a href="http://www.mint.com/solutions/">six other goals</a> to choose from.)

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/mint-1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-314" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/10/mint-1.jpg" alt="" width="470" height="496" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>HighRise Feature</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/11/highrise-feature/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 04 Nov 2008 11:00:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=325</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Taking a closer look at that announcement, it's a really nice, clearly stated, feature announcement. Not a new point release with a dozen bullets. Just one simple, compelling new feature. Briefly described with a link for more info if that's what you want. Excellent.



<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/11/highrise-feature-announcment.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-326" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/11/highrise-feature-announcment.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="100" /></a>



And the 37 Signals<a href="http://productblog.37signals.com/products/2008/10/new-in-highrise-faster-sidebar-search.html">accompanying video</a> is stripped down, but very clear. Maybe a little too long - especially on the front end. But by the time it's over I'm convinced those guys are thoughtful and I'm using a state-of-the-art app that is good and getting better all the time.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Gears (from Google)</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/11/gears-from-google/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 25 Nov 2008 11:54:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=342</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Y'all seen this? <a href="http://gears.google.com/">Google Gears</a> enables Web Apps to do more locally by, among other things, allowing oft-called assets to reside locally (the AG header for example, or a video perhaps) including databases (offline access to the gradebook?)

The goal? "To unlock the power of the local computer for use with web applications." Like many of these leading edge capabilities, it will be quite a while before we can rely on all students in most classes to be ready to make use of these without trouble. But it's neat to look ahead.

And it looks like it can be offered rather unobtrusively for those who have and crave gears functionality, as in this example from Word Press:

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/11/gears_wordpress.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-343" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/11/gears_wordpress.jpg" alt="" width="490" height="335" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Helpful?</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/11/helpful/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 26 Nov 2008 11:22:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=345</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[While reading about Gears, I came across <a href="http://gears.google.com/support/bin/answer.py?answer=79873&amp;topic=13192">this help page</a> which conveys some of it's helpful tone by asking me if the page was, in fact, helpful.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/11/helpful1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-347" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/11/helpful1.jpg" alt="" width="325" height="200" /></a>

I like that it asks. Though I must admit I had a hard time answering. "Was this page helpful?" Well, not to me, but I suppose it is answering the question it claims to answer. In the end I did not find what I needed in any of the help pages, but did in the video which I watched reluctantly as I did not really want to spend an hour on this (and didn't.) So maybe there is a better way to implement this. But still, I love a support page that asks if you, dear reader, did in fact get the support you needed.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Magazine Thumbnail / Light Table</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/12/magazine-thumbnail-light-table/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 01 Dec 2008 11:43:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=349</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Granted, this is a low quality still, but it illustrates a novel way of looking at the contents of a magazine.The cover page of each story is relatively large, the following pages adjacent and smaller.

<a href="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/11/light_thumbs.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-350" src="http://soomo-wordpress_ui.s3.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/11/light_thumbs.jpg" alt="" width="500" height="276" /></a>

I like the way it gives me a sense of the magazine as a whole and is perhaps the best format ever for sensing in a blink the length and character (text v. images) of a given article. Truly and innovative TOC. From a <a href="http://www.ted.com/index.php/talks/blaise_aguera_y_arcas_demos_photosynth.html">TED lecture on PhotoSynth</a>.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Alternative to Screencast</title>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Visit the Axure site and you find the obligatory link to Tour. But if you do so while your roommate is sleeping, or on low-bandwith, the screencast might not be an option. Never fear -- a small link in a red cap stands in the upper right corner offering an HTML (annotated slide) tour as a quieter, faster alternative.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-361" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/axure-tour.jpg" alt="axure-tour" width="657" height="441" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>pbwiki</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/12/pbwiki/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 17 Dec 2008 12:01:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=363</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This may not be our style, but it's a striking page.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-364" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/pbwiki1.jpg" alt="pbwiki1" width="758" height="539" />

A few things I like:

- The basic story in 3 words: "Simple, secure, collaboration." Putting grammar aside, I immediately have a basic understanding of what they are offering.

- But will it work for my situation? Judging by the user segmentation in the header and, in a more detailed way, in the footer, this is often the second question.

- An alternative second question might be, "What are the key features?" or "What can I do with this thing?"

- Quite a few calls to action and paths to moving off of this page and into a deeper relationship: Sign up, Create a Wiki, View a Demo, Buy Now, call, email...or click anything on this page for a better explanation.

- The manage docs starburst is doing some interesting things visually. The rest of the page is just so stable, so minimal and clean. I like how the bands get darker from the bottom to the top giving the page depth and pushing the screen shot toward me. And then, this starburst adds an inordinate amount of energy (albeit with a little bit of an as seen on tv tone) to the page.

Honestly, they had me at "NEW! MANAGE DOCS" because that's what I was looking for. So what did I click on next? Pricing. I am increasingly convinced we need this link on the first page -- what will this cost and who's going to pay it?

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-365" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/pbwiki2.jpg" alt="pbwiki2" width="749" height="546" />

Note that I'm not left in a cul-de-sac here. They're still giving me options left and right to take the next step. Because once I see the pricing, I'm in, right? Well, at least if I am I shouldn't waste anytime wondering where to click next. The phone might...]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>gaboogie</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/12/gaboogie/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 18 Dec 2008 12:24:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=367</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Another super simple home page. Enter phone numbers into this thing and when it's time for the conference call, it calls everyone, instead of waiting for everyone to remember, reach the appointed time on their clock, find the dial-in details etc. They boil this down to the core benefit in three words: Start on Time.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-368" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/gaboogie.jpg" alt="gaboogie" width="668" height="543" />

Essentially a hybrid between FAQ and bullets. On a page this simple, the balloons offer some nice energy, and depth with the addition of the shadows.

(Evidently the fine folks at <a href="http://gaboogie.com/">gaboogie</a> grew weary of this design. Less than 24 hours after I shot this the home page had been replaced by a Flash billboard of sorts.)

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-369" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/newgaboogie.jpg" alt="newgaboogie" width="606" height="471" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Code Copy</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2008/12/code-copy/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 19 Dec 2008 12:33:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=373</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Sometimes the simplest things make life so much easier. Embed code for video is increasingly common, but Vimeo is once again leading innovation. Click the "embed" icon on the upper right of the screen and you get this window:

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-374" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/vimeo.jpg" alt="vimeo" width="515" height="388" />

Click that big button in the middle, and you see this screen:

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-375" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/vimeo-1.jpg" alt="vimeo-1" width="514" height="386" />

All the code is on your clipboard and ready to be pasted into your blog or site. So clean. It's interesting to me that a head turning innovation can be created by replacing, what, "click, drag, cmd+v" with "click". That's enough to impress. There's something to the idea of backing down the complexity curve. Granted it saves only a gesture and a two key chord -- maybe three seconds. But it could also be seen as eliminating 75% of the complexity. And perhaps some decision making or at least action sequencing. It's closer to "think it and it happens" and further from "just follow these four easy steps." It's the basis of "Assign This" which I still think will be a huge success when we can market it.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Momentum is fun.</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/01/momentum/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 05 Jan 2009 11:24:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=384</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Past the arrogance and anger, there is often a good perspective behind the comments and commitments of the 37Signals team. It's not for everyone, but in this latest "<a href="http://www.boxesandarrows.com/view/idea-2008">Getting Real</a>" presentation I found a few intriguing work patterns that might be well worth exploring.

1) Investigate briefly. Give the most promising ideas 1-2 hours of investigation to see what might come of it, before making a bigger commitment.

2) Small bites. Look seriously only at the next step of a project in a size that 1-2 people can complete in 1-2 days. Do that, then think about the next step.

3) Ship it. Don't work on anything for more than 3 months. By the end of three months things feel like they're dragging on. Tie it off and get it out by the end of that third month. If you then want to start on another pass at the same thing, fine.

This doesn't work for everything we do. And they tend to say it in overly provocative ways that could be easily misunderstood. But it rings true for me in a number of ways. The bottom line driving these strategies is that momentum is fun.

So personally, I have a bunch of ideas to move to the "Please do investigate" list where I can see them as needing only 1-2 hours instead of looking like overwhelming projects, many of which I've been lugging from list to list for years.

And I would very much like to know the one or two big things I'm working on for the next day or two and then give myself permission to really do those, instead of switching quickly between a dozen projects that never seem to wrap. (Our Monday meetings suggest we think in terms of weeks, which may not be the most productive scale, but I have an idea there from Chouinard.)

And finally, I love the idea of wrapping things each quarter. Giving each three month stretch it's own agenda. We seem wired, deep in our code, for three month seasons. And the projects which get mentioned on Monday for more than 13 Mondays do seem onerous.

As always, I'm eager for input as we design not only new stuff, but new ways of making it. Very eager to see how this works out!

David]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Doc Review: A Perfect Candidate</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/01/doc-review-a-perfect-candidate/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 22 Jan 2009 12:00:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>timaldengrant</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=395</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>A Perfect Candidate</em> follows the race for a 1994 Virginia senate seat between Oliver North and Chuck Robb. It's easy, and common in my opinion, to highlight one candidate as an underdog, the other as a scoundrel. This film however appears to take the higher ground, resulting in a complex and interesting look at political personalities and the people behind them.

Some of the best moments surround a third candidate, L. Douglas Wilder, namely a debate where he brings to light with humor some obvious flaws in each of his opponents. His run serves to deepen the plot of North and Robb, giving the last 35 minutes a momentum that most 105 minute long poli-docs do not have.<span> </span>And of course how could we ever forget Mark Goodin, the North campaign manager. Paul Stekler        writes: <em>Fresh from the disgrace of his own dirty tricks campaign misdeeds in service of the Reagan White House, Goodin seeks redemption with the post-Iran Contra North. But it's Goodin's meltdowns and confessions in front of the camera that are nothing short of amazing. Playing the role of ultimate truth-teller at the end of an ugly losing race, he admits, "We provide entertainment, not solutions." </em><span>http://www.documentary.org/node/2490</span>

The narrative of the film is understated by the filmmakers themselves, not supplying any original commentary, but instead collecting radio clips and on-the-spot opinions from members of the media. The ultimate truth and/or greater good are not in question here, thank god. Instead the film focuses on the study of persona's and political strategies and powers, or lack there of, and never really concerns itself with specific issues in any great detail.

Top scenes
38:00 - A debate between North, Robb and Wilder bleeding into a debriefing by Goodin.
119:00 - A Church Service on "Voting Power &amp; The Perfect Candidate"

Tim Grant 1/13/09]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>395</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-01-22 08:00:13</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-01-22 12:00:13</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>doc-review-a-perfect-candidate</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="video"><![CDATA[Video]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="video"><![CDATA[Video]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Doc Review: Primary</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/01/doc-review-primary/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 15 Jan 2009 14:01:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>timaldengrant</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=399</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It's amazing to watch a documentary that was filmed before editorializing became a trend. No one would argue that <em>Primary</em> pioneered the political campaign documentary format, and yet it does not use notable devices or themes, it simply moves from shot to shot freely without a heavy hand or a conclusive opinion.

Watching JFK pose for a picture or sit nervously awaiting the vote count is remarkable. It is a rare chance to see past an icon and observe an actual man. It is here that I think most of <em>Primary</em>'s value lies. The viewer is a fly on the wall in a room with the innovator of modern politics. Humphrey, JFK's opponent, holds his own interests, proving his talent as a politician and drawing lines for us between himself and Kennedy. He speaks to rural Wisconsin, identifying himself with farming and small town America and pigeonholing his opponent as a metropolitan.

Top scenes:
45:00 +/- JFK waiting for the vote to come in.

Tim Grant 1/13/09]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Doc Review: Bill&#039;s Run: POV</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/01/doc-review-bills-run-pov/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 29 Jan 2009 13:19:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>timaldengrant</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=404</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I did not finish watching <em>Bill's Run</em>. This was a very convenient documentary for filmmaker Richard Kassebaum to have made, Bill is his brother. And while that fact is upfront and could have had it's own perks, it only results in agreeing with everything Bill says, at least in the first 30 minutes I watched. The only critique of Bill comes from his own party, but they are presented as stubborn old men that won't face the cold facts of their failing rural Kansas district. That maybe true, but I am given no trust worthy barometer to judge by.

Overall, or should I say over-half, this is a confusing, somewhat pointless documentary that doesn't deserve much attention.

Tim Grant]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Doc Review: Rabbit Hash</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/02/doc-review-rabbit-hash/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 05 Feb 2009 15:00:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>timaldengrant</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=406</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[What an interesting documentary...for about 20 minutes. We learn that the town of Rabbit Hash Kentucky elects a dog as honorary mayor. The story is perfectly suited for a solid short documentary film. It pokes fun at corrupt elections by having the most corrupt election possible, buy your way into office. Dogs, pigs, donkeys and "crazy men" are voted for with a dollar. The candidate generating the most money wins. A great fund raising idea plain and simple.

However, we continue to learn every microscopic fact of the small town and the surrounding area which happens to be exactly like any other small town and surrounding area. There's a painful attempt here at offering an explanation why a town would elect a dog as mayor. An answer I that was given by one of the random talking heads, "I came up with a fund raising idea". That, or the film assumes we want to know more about Rabbit Hash which is not true for me.

Top Scenes

0:00 - 20:00 I'll call it the first act, worth watching for something completely different.
Tim Grant]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>FAQ: Bookstores</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/faq-bookstores/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Apr 2009 12:51:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=419</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>FAQ: </strong>
Will students buy it in the bookstore?

<strong>Answer:</strong>
Students can subscribe directly from our site. They can pay with credit card, check or electronic funds transfer.

Usually, they just want to know how it works and that answer is fine. But sometimes what they mean is, "It is important that some students be able to buy it in the bookstore." I like to ask what drives that, just so we're not guessing. Often it's just curiosity but sometimes there is a real reason such as financial aid. Then I explain that "We can ship passkeys to the bookstore, who will then mark them up. What is $25 on our site is often $33-35 in the bookstore." Once the real cost is seen they either say that this would be a lot better on the website, or that it is well worth it for those students who have this real need.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Double Digit Growth in Distance Ed</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/double-digit-growth-in-distance-ed/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 08 Apr 2009 21:26:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=422</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Rise in Distance Enrollments</strong>
<a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/04/06/distance" target="_blank">http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/04/06/distance</a>

The top three challenges listed by distance education administrators...all relate to resources needed to expand distance programs while keeping them at high quality:
- support staff for training and technical assistance
- student services for distance students, and
- operating and equipment budgets.

I think Soomo can help on all three fronts.

Thanks for the pointer Dan!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Figuring Out Freshmen</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/figuring-out-freshmen/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 10 Apr 2009 12:28:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=426</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[from: <a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/03/18/sense">http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/03/18/sense</a>

<em>New report suggests community colleges need to engage and motivate incoming students more within their first few weeks.</em>

Dan says, "I found this interesting, especially the last three paragraphs."
<h1>Figuring Out Freshmen</h1>
<div class="attribute-coverdate">March 18, 2009</div>
<div class="attribute-bodytext">

A <a href="http://www.ccsse.org/sense/survey/SENSE_2008_National_Report_March_18.pdf" target="_blank">new report</a> suggests that many incoming community college students do not take advantage of valuable student resources simply because they are not aware of them. It argues that two-year institutions need to do a better job of personally assisting new students, especially within the "make or break" time period of their first few weeks.

The latest findings from the <a href="http://www.ccsse.org/sense/" target="_blank">Survey of Entering Student Engagement</a> (SENSE) were released today. The national assessment tool was launched in 2007 by the same group at the University of Texas at Austin that releases the <a href="http://www.cccse.org/" target="_blank">Community College Survey of Student Engagement</a> (CCSSE). Unlike that study, however, SENSE surveys only incoming community college students, asking them questions about their academic experience after the first three weeks of their initial semester. As the study is only in the field-testing stage, it features data from a limited sphere of 57,547 students from 89 community colleges around the country.

<!--more-->
<div class="attribute-bodytext">

The survey asks questions within six subjects or design principles, covering topics such as personal connections with instructors and awareness of important student services. Answers to these questions are compiled and provided to the participating institutions. The data for individual institutions and in aggregate are also available online for the general public.

Kay McClenney, CCSSE's director and head of the department of educational administration at the University of Texas at Austin, said the surveys data show the importance of the first weeks of a students college career. By analyzing student engagement at this point, she said community college administrators and instructors can make valuable changes to their approaches, applying proven techniques that make a difference in their students' academic outcome.

Most of the surveyed students reported that they felt welcome the first time they arrived on campus and that they were able to get the information they needed to register for class. Still, 76 percent of them noted that there was not a specific person designated for them to see if they needed information or assistance. The report suggests that more colleges should adopt personalized advising programs, matching students with mentors earlier.

Within this same short time frame, the report notes that most students adopt a number of bad habits that continue to plague them throughout their college career. For example, 32 percent of incoming students reported that they turned in at least one assignment late. Twenty-five percent said they failed to turn in one or more assignment, 47 percent said they came to class unprepared and 29 percent said they skipped class.

Students do these things, and there are often no consequences, said McClenney, noting that she believes students will respond to stricter guidelines. Most of the time, nobody notices that they stop coming to class. If there are no consequences for bad behavior, itll continue.

The report suggests that instructors may be to blame for some of this delinquent behavior. Only a quarter of students strongly agree that their instructors clearly explained the academic and student support services at the college. The report argues that, aside from spotlighting these services, instructors should also make clear their expectations for students and set them high. Indicative of a lack in this area, just over half of the surveyed students strongly agree that the faculty at their college wants them to succeed.

There are still a fair number of people at community colleges who say, We provide the services and the counseling. Now, its up to the students to take advantage of them,  McClenney said. In that world, its sink or swim. These people argue that if students dont make the right choices, they have the right to fail.

This philosophy, McClenney argues, is not only old hat but fundamentally harmful to students who need assistance. As most community college students are the first generation in their families to go to college, she said, they are likely to be unaware of student services such as academic advising or financial aid counseling. For example, 29 percent of students said they did not know their college offered the former and 27 percent the latter. Trips to make use of these services, McClenney argued, should be mandatory for the good of these students.

If you know these things work and you make them optional, then youre not exercising your responsibility as an educator, McClenney said.

Once students get help outside the classroom, the report argues that they need to work with advisers to establish a path with benchmarks along the way to their academic goal. Though 76 percent of students agree or strongly agree that an adviser helped them select courses, only 39 percent of them agree or strongly agree that that same adviser helped them to set academic goals and to create a plan for achieving them. Also, only 27 percent of students agree or strongly agree that someone spoke to them about their outside obligations to work and family when helping them consider which courses to take.

Academic planning is the most important service to students, said McClenney, citing data from <a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2008/11/17/ccsse" target="_blank">last years CCSSE report</a>. I know that three weeks into the semester, when you have 4,000 students who need help fixing their schedules, its hard to get this type of planning. But, some colleges are able to figure out how to do this. Students need to have a road map that has milestones that show them the way from where they are to some better, different place down the road. Honestly, its not about the courses, its about the goal.

Most new students need extra help before they can set out on that journey. According to national figures, nearly 63 percent of all community college students require some type of remediation before they can begin their coursework. Nonetheless, about 11 percent of surveyed students reported that their college did not require them to take this remedial coursework in their first semester.

The report also suggests that most community colleges are not teaching their students in engaging and experimental ways. Eighty-five percent of students said they had never participated in a required study group outside of class, 75 percent of them said they were not enrolled in a student success course and 96 percent of them said they were not enrolled in a learning community.

Were seeing major changes in the culture of teaching and learning, said McClenney, encouraging community college instructors to require that their students work with their classmates more often. Some teachers need to unlearn their bad habits. No one should be lecturing for an hour. Thats an absolute no-no.

SENSE will be nationally administered to a much larger sample this fall. A more comprehensive report will follow next year.</div>
<div class="attribute-byline">  <a href="mailto:david.moltz@insidehighered.com">David Moltz</a></div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Toward an All E-Textbook Campus</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/an-all-digital-future/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Apr 2009 12:05:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=429</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[from: <a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/01/14/ebooks">http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/01/14/ebooks</a>

<em>Forwarded by Kathi Prancan: Interesting article. </em>

<em>
</em>
<h1>Toward an All E-Textbook Campus</h1>
<div class="attribute-coverdate">January 14, 2009</div>
<div class="attribute-bodytext">

Many colleges are <a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2008/08/26/etextbooks" target="_blank">experimenting with e-textbooks these days</a>. But at Northwest Missouri State University, President Dean L. Hubbard hopes theyll be an e-book only campus (or close to it) soon -- as soon as the market will allow it. Well move as fast as the industry moves and theyre moving very rapidly, Hubbard says.

Northwest Missouri has long bought textbooks on its students behalf, renting them in exchange for a $6 per credit hour fee. The university is now piloting a move away from purchasing the paper kind. This spring, the 6,700-student university bought e-books for about 500 students in 10 different courses -- including College Algebra, Intercultural Communications, and the Enjoyment of Music. In addition, McGraw-Hill is making digital access codes available to up to 3,000 more Northwest Missouri students who are using texts available in both formats.</div>
<div class="attribute-bodytext">

The pilot actually began, on a smaller scale, this fall, when the university experimented with e-books and, specifically, the Sony PRS-505 e-reader model -- ultimately determining that the Sony model "was not necessarily designed for what we want to do, says Paul Klute, the assistant to the president. So this spring, students will primarily use their laptop computers, already provided to them by the institution, to read the e-books (although a smaller group of students will test out a newer version of the Sony e-reader, Klute explains).

Klute says print will probably always have some place at Northwest Missouri; for example, in the case of an older textbook that is considered definitive in a field. Still, print would be the exception, not the rule. In making this shift, university officials cite a desire to cut costs, and to be "on the cutting edge" of trends in learning and technology.

Citing the e-book's built-in interactivity, "I'm convinced," says Hubbard, "that students will read more and they will learn more, by using this medium."

The proposal to go (almost) e-book only does raise some questions, however -- including what the renters, i.e. students, will think. The university will be surveying students throughout the spring, but data from last fall suggest split opinion. "Our quantitative feedback suggested to us that about 50 percent of our students like the idea of electronic textbooks and 50 percent don't," Klute says.

He adds: "I do think that we'll see that 50 percent that don't like e-textbooks shift as they become exposed to the electronic textbooks."

"That's just a hypothesis of mine and one that we hope to realize as the project moves forward."

"I think there's a lot of interest, and I think a generally supportive attitude certainly among the members of the faculty that I visited with," says Doug Sudhoff, the Faculty Senate president and an assistant professor of mass communication. "There may be some faculty who will have a really hard time letting go of the traditional textbook. That's true anywhere. But I think, in general, as we see the results of the pilot project and if those results are positive, I think you'll see that faculty move pretty quickly to adapt their courses to online textbooks and adopt them for their courses."

President Hubbard also cites a hoped-for cost-savings of at least 50 percent. And that raises some questions given the college's current rental model: While e-books are cheaper, on average available at half the price of the printed version, the university currently replaces rental textbooks on three-year cycles -- getting three years' use out of a single bound book. By contrast, consumers typically buy timed subscriptions for the half-price e-books: 180 days for books to be used in semester courses, or 360 for those used year-long.

"We would have to better understand how our rental model would work with the current system of distributing e-textbooks," Klute says.

"We haven't made a deal yet, we're still piloting it," explains Hubbard. "But we've been very candid with the publishers that we are not going to spend any more than we're currently spending and we would expect over time to spend less."

That's a reasonable expectation, says Frank Lyman, executive vice president at <a href="http://www.coursesmart.com/" target="_blank">CourseSmart</a>, a digital textbook company started by five major textbook publishers. "It's a reasonable expectation that an institution pursuing digital aggressively should be able to save money for themselves and their students. Having not been involved with Northwest Missouri, I don't know what the dynamic is there," Lyman says.

Lyman says that with 5,029 textbooks now availability digitally, CourseSmart covers about 30 percent of the market. "For institutions that are going to be aggressive about pursuing this goal" -- of being all e-textbook -- "I think the opportunity exists for them to have 50, 60, 75 percent of their titles covered by e-textbooks within the next year."

He adds that a few for-profit colleges have already moved to e-book only in certain curriculum areas. "As with a lot of things, the non-profit colleges and universities are trying to see if there's something they can learn from the way the for-profits operate," Lyman says.

CourseSmart <a href="http://blog.coursesmart.com/" target="_blank">reports</a> that 72 percent of their customers say they would buy some or all of their textbooks in electronic format in the future. Likewise, "Our research shows that a very high percentage of students who actually use these digital textbooks have a positive experience. Most recommend it to their friends," says Jeff Ho, a product manager at McGraw-Hill, one of five publishers that Northwest Missouri is working with.

However, <a href="http://www.maketextbooksaffordable.org/course_correction.pdf" target="_blank">an August report</a> by the Student Public Interest Research Groups found that 75 percent of students surveyed said they'd prefer a printed textbook to a digital one. Thirty-three percent said they felt comfortable reading on a computer screen, 22 percent were uncomfortable and 45 percent were in the middle.

"It's a sentiment shared among a lot of educators that it's the 21st century; we should be using computers for all of education. As we wrote in the report, to some extent it's true," says Nicole Allen, the report author and the textbook advocate for Student PIRGs. "We've just got to remember that reading a Facebook profile is not the same thing as reading a textbook."

"Textbooks are necessarily disconnected from students' needs as consumers, because textbook sales are not driven by students; they're driven by faculty," she says. "It's important to remember that the consumer actually does have needs and desires and the students do have preferences as to whether they want to switch to a digital book or a print book, and they're different. The best thing is to give students options, and a lot of them can make that determination themselves. I'm not saying that switching to e-books is wrong. I'm not an educator; I don't know. But I represent students' needs as consumers and you can't rely on the market to address those needs."

In an e-mail, Abby Freeman, Northwest Missouri's Student Senate president, expressed support for the university's ongoing pilot.

"I think it demonstrates that NW is continually searching for methods to improve our university and the educational setting for the students. Though the original use intended for the [Sony] e-readers may not be the best option for the students of Northwest, the continued piloting and research into the programs and their benefit is great. I think students enjoy exploring new opportunities in their classrooms and discovering if those options are a benefit to the university."</div>
<div class="attribute-byline">  <a href="mailto:elizabeth.redden@insidehighered.com">Elizabeth Redden</a></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>E-Textbooks -- for Real This Time?</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/e-textbooks-for-real-this-time/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 11 Apr 2009 12:42:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=433</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[from: <a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2008/01/03/ebooks" target="_blank">http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2008/01/03/ebooks</a>
<h1>E-Textbooks -- for Real This Time?</h1>
<div class="attribute-coverdate">January 3, 2008</div>
<div class="attribute-bodytext">

It's the central paradox of 21st-century college students: Despite embracing radically new ways of communicating with each other and learning about the world, they still remain wedded to the old-fashioned, paper-bound textbook.

That steadfast commitment to the printed page isn't shared only by students. But sensing an opportunity among early adopters -- and possibly signaling a shift in people's preferences -- two companies recently bet that the time is ripe for nudging a change in reading habits. So far, it's too early to tell whether Amazon's Kindle and Sony's Reader Digital Book will be considered a success at luring customers willing to try out a new paradigm; like many promising technologies before it, e-books have perpetually remained on the verge of taking off. But those hardware devices, and other efforts sure to come down the pipeline in the near future, echo a broader attempt by companies across the publishing world to apply the technology and economics of iTunes to the written word.</div>
<div class="attribute-bodytext">

The textbook industry is no exception. Over the past year, a consortium of major textbook publishers and several competing ventures have been getting ready for a new push in what is becoming a small but steadily growing fraction of the overall market for college students. "Those efforts are starting to crack the surface of digital content being a serious growing enterprise in higher education, said Evan Schnittman, vice president of business development and rights for Oxford University Press's academic and U.S. divisions. McGraw-Hill Education, for example, offers almost 95 percent of its textbooks as e-books, and the publisher has seen a steady growth in interest over the past several years, albeit from a small base.

Their logic seems unassailable: With laptops now an ubiquitous presence on college campuses and textbook prices ever on the rise and suddenly a hot issue, technologically inclined students seem poised to change their study habits -- and save a lot of money -- by forgoing scribbles in the margin and trading in their highlighters for cursors.

Were not talking about a huge market at all at this point in time, said Will Moore, the director of marketing for <a href="http://vitalsource.com/" target="_blank">VitalSource Technologies</a>, a company that works with publishers and academic institutions to deliver digital textbooks online. Actual numbers focusing on electronic books in the higher education sector are scarce. Still, he said, he projects very rapid growth in the future.

Large publishing companies have their own reasons for embracing the new technologies before an entire industry gets upended, but they'll soon be competing with upstart ventures seeking to harness Facebook-style social networking to make e-textbooks widely available to the average student. Each effort represents a different approach to delivering what is now comfortably available in print via 1's and 0's, through computer screens and on portable readers.

In a September blog post titled <a href="http://blog.oup.com/2007/09/cafescribe/" target="_blank">"Is This It?"</a>, Schnittman, of Oxford, described <a href="http://www.cafescribe.com/" target="_blank">CafScribe</a> -- a downloadable service that offers an iTunes-like interface for browsing books combined with social networking features allowing students, for example, to share notes online -- as a potential "magic bullet solution" to students' rejection, so far, of "every effort to get them to use electronic textbooks."

It's a conundrum that many in the industry still scratch their heads over. "The joke that I like to tell is that e-books in college have been 2 years away for 10 years, but I think ... if you ask people, 'Will college students get their course content digitally?' ... everyone says yes," said Frank Lyman, the executive vice president for marketing at CourseSmart, a venture supported by six higher-education textbook publishers. "Why not now?"

<strong>The Social Networking Approach</strong>

Bryce Johnson dedicated a master's thesis to the question. As a graduate student earning his MBA at the University of California at Berkeley several years ago, he explored why digital books hadn't caught on as a viable medium. He "quickly realized that not a lot of people had really taken a plunge into universities," he said.

What he found, after numerous focus groups and surveys, was that students weren't interested in a flat interface that replicated what they already had between their textbook covers. "The predominant thing was, make it easy for me to highlight, take notes," Johnson recounted.

So the outgrowth of his thesis, and then business plan, became CafScribe, a company that launched to the general public in August. It uses a direct-to-consumer model in which users download a program that lets them browse, purchase and view books, and then annotate and share notes. Rather than working with bookstores or colleges, CafScribe is relying more on word of mouth.

Its strategy from the start has been to address issues that students say keep them from considering digital books as a viable alternative. That hard-to-pinpoint feeling that keeps people attached to their books? Check. Starting in September, the company <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/internetNews/idUSN2242895820070822" target="_blank">announced</a> that it would send each customer a scratch-and-sniff sticker with the "musty book" smell.

Anticipating students' learning styles, <a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2007/01/26/wiki" target="_blank">and possibly horrifying some professors</a>, the interface links directly to Wikipedia articles. It allows readers to annotate and "highlight" text with different colors. Words can be searched as easily as a Google query, and skimming is easier with navigation tools. Students who prefer collaboration can even collect the notes of their online classmates and see them in one place.

"I think its very close to the tipping point, at least from the reads were getting from our students," Johnson said.

Like iTunes, the model features a type of digital rights management that allows users to download individually purchased e-textbooks to three separate computers or laptops. But like Apple's digital music service, the success of ventures like CafScribe depend on the availability of content. Johnson estimated that the company would have some 15 publishers on board in the first quarter of 2008, including more content from Oxford. Still, he conceded, he receives hundreds of requests for titles each day. "Content is our biggest obstacle right now," he said.

Still, Johnson sees a lot of growth at community colleges and from non-traditional students. Not necessarily right away, though: "Its probably still a couple years out." (Johnson hasn't been making this prediction for 10 years; he received his MBA in 2004.)

<strong>The Publishers' Approach</strong>

Lyman, of <a href="http://www.coursesmart.com/" target="_blank">CourseSmart</a>, has another theory about the market for electronic textbooks: There isn't a critical mass of content in a widely available format. With that in mind, the venture -- backed by publishers including Wiley, Pearson, Cengage Learning and McGraw-Hill -- is an attempt to "jump-start" a market where it hasn't arisen spontaneously.

For students, that means a Web-based repository for PDF-style versions of popular textbooks -- although they're only online and can't be downloaded for offline reading. At the same time, Lyman said, the collaboration would allow professors to more easily review potential course materials online.

So far, the venture is still working out the best way to reach its customers. So, besides direct marketing, CourseSmart will start working with college bookstores and other retailers in an attempt to give students as many purchasing choices as possible. After all, in college, billing home to mom is an important payment option. And parents may approve of the savings: a 180-day online "subscription" to the ninth edition of <a href="http://www.coursesmart.com/9780324362084" target="_blank"><em>Marketing</em></a>, by Lamb, Hair and McDaniel, enough for a semester of work, sells for $80.99 on CourseSmart from a list price of $176.95 -- over a 50-percent discount. (Used versions sell upwards of $91.99 on Amazon.)

Still, CourseSmart's entry into the market has rankled the National Association of College Bookstores enough to cause it to look into potential antitrust issues raised by the consortium.

Individual publishers are also beginning to formulate their own strategies for electronic delivery. "We are starting to see ... interest by students in purchasing their textbook content in an e-book form in lieu of the print book," said Wendy Spiegel, the senior vice president for communications at Pearson Education. "We continue to see interest and growth."

The publisher offers at least 800 titles in electronic format, with prices about half of what they'd be in print. Spiegel, recognizing their appeal, sees e-textbooks as an important part of the company's overall strategy in the future.

Some have even considered the viability of portable readers as a potential way to deliver textbooks. "The development of Kindle validates our view that the development of digital content presents a major market opportunity for us. We are currently participating in a pilot program to evaluate the feasibility of higher ed titles being viewed via Kindle," said Tom Stanton, the director of communications at McGraw-Hill Education, in an e-mail.</div>
<div class="attribute-byline">  <a href="mailto:andy.guess@insidehighered.com">Andy Guess</a></div>
<div class="attribute-byline"></div>
<div class="attribute-byline">
<div class="story-left-block">
<div class="related-stories">
<h3>Related Stories</h3>
<ul>

<span class="date"> March 20, 2009 </span></li>
	<li class="headline"> <a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/03/12/laptops">Is the Laptop Love-In Over?</a>
<span class="date"> March 12, 2009 </span></li>
	<li class="headline"> <a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/views/mclemee/mclemee233">The Reader</a>
<span class="date"> March 11, 2009 </span></li>
	<li class="headline"> <a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/02/24/bruff">Writing the Book on Clickers</a>
<span class="date"> February 24, 2009 </span></li>
	<li class="headline"> <a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/02/05/juicy">Juice Runs Dry</a>
<span class="date"> February 5, 2009 </span></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>

	<item>
		<title>Battle Rages Over Textbook Prices</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/battle-rages-over-textbook-prices/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 18 Apr 2009 12:11:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=445</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Battle Rages Over Textbook Prices</h1>
<h2>Publishers and students vie to determine cost of books

<span class="author">By <a class="authorLink" href="http://www.carolinajournal.com/cjcolumnists/display_author.html?id=340">David J. Koon</a></span></h2>
<strong>September 09, 2008</strong>

<span class="copyStyle">RALEIGH  Textbook publishers have come under intense scrutiny because the prices of textbooks keep going up. Students have been hit by these prices and must pay hundreds of dollars for books from which only small portions are assigned. Yet innovations, from faculty use of online resources to students exchange of books through Facebook and online retailers, might soon change this industry.

There is no doubt that prices are high. In 2005, the U.S. Government Accountability Office reported that textbook prices had increased at an average annual rate of 6.14 percent from the 1980s through 2004, and recent updates to the Consumer Price Index indicate this trend is holding steady. A report from the College Board, <em>Trends in College Pricing</em>, states that an undergraduate in the South can expect to spend $852 annually on books and supplies at college, slightly lower than the $988 national average.

One response has been the expansion of the used-book market. Internet retailers Amazon.com and eBay.com and private used bookstores are selling used books at a fraction of the cost of new ones. Social networks are now in the distribution chain, as students consult others to find the cheapest texts, whether sold at local bookstores, online, or on Facebook.com and other networking sites.

Students often wonder why their school doesnt just rent textbooks, especially those for which the content doesnt change much from year to year. But textbook rental programs have been implemented at only about 25 colleges nationally, according to the Illinois Board of Higher Education. One of these is Appalachian State, where students pay a rental fee of only $87.50 in exchange for most of their books. Though the program is non-subsidized and popular with students, few schools have copied it.

High overhead and start-up expenditures would cost well into the millions said Cathy Marks, textbook rental manager at Appalachian State, whose program started in 1938. Also, faculty tend to dislike it because it requires everyone to teach from the same textbook.

Aware of the high prices, some professors have begun to post articles, chapters and other texts, formerly assigned in books, on Web sites operated by companies such as blackboard.com, aplia.com and others. These university-endorsed sites permit students to view copyright-protected readings without having to buy them.

UNC-Chapel Hill history professor Louise McReynolds is a proponent of the system. It saves students money because they dont have to buy so many books and it saves faculty money by not Xeroxing articles, syllabi, review questions and exams for distribution to the class, she said.

Unfortunately for students, publishers appear to be responding with tactics that force students to buy more than is necessary. One, called bundling, caused enough furor that Congress banned it in the recent Higher Education Act reauthorization. Bundling is the practice of combining a textbook and supplementary materials such as workbooks, CDs, and DVDs and selling them as one unit. Although ancillaries may make a textbook user-friendly, they are easily misplaced through the course of a semester. A student who doesnt keep them will not be able to resell the book to the bookstore, at least not at a normal resale price.

Publishers have also increased the frequency of new editions, according to the GAO report. It said that new editions come out every three to four years on average, instead of every four to five years as in the past. On the other hand, professors and students do prefer up-to-date texts for class.

A new practice of customizing books is also designed to strengthen publishers hold on the market. Textbook publishers delete or add content specifically for a particular university. Officially, this is an attempt to suit the course content to a schools approach, say, in a freshman composition class.

However, a <em>Wall Street Journal</em> article by John Hechinger (July 10, 2008) suggested that custom books are a way for publishers to make more money at students expense, and some practices may border on the unethical. Hechinger cited a customized writing reference book at the University of Alabama that merely adds a 32-page section about the universitys writing program to the generic text, yet it costs more and is hard to resell.

Furthermore, the writing department receives a $3 royalty  a kickback, Hechinger writes. Custom books are the fastest-growing segment of the U.S. textbook market, according to the Association of American Publishers. Time will tell, however, the significance of their impact.

Textbook publishers have implemented measures that may improve students educational experience, yet the greater effect might be to raise prices and impede book resale. As these companies attempt to remain viable in a competitive market, students, with the help of some faculty, are using their power as consumers to bring the prices down.

<em>David J. Koon, a senior at UNC-Chapel Hill, was a 2008 summer intern with the John W. Pope Center for Higher Education Policy.</em></span>

<span class="copyStyle">from:
<a href="http://www.carolinajournal.com/exclusives/display_exclusive.html?id=4980">http://www.carolinajournal.com/exclusives/display_exclusive.html?id=4980</a><em>
</em></span>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Flatworld gets $8M in funding</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/flatworld-gets-8m-in-funding/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Apr 2009 00:34:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=457</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The article suggests confidence in the market and the comments offer some insight into popular attitudes toward texts. The strange thing to me is that people seem to be taking Flatworld's claim of offering free books at face value, when they are saying their model is to sell upgrades to students. In other words, they're betting that the free products won't cut it for most students who will then buy upgrades. Nonetheless, an $8 million investment indicates substantial confidence that the digital text market will be growing very quickly, very soon.

<a href="http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/open_source_textbook_maker_flat_world_gets_funded.php">http://www.readwriteweb.com/archives/open_source_textbook_maker_flat_world_gets_funded.php</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

Squarespace takes an unusual but straightforward approach to the CSV:

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-462" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/04/wordpress-registration.jpg" alt="wordpress-registration" width="723" height="576" />

And Digg offers some spunky feedback as you fill in username, password and email:

	<item>
		<title>Builder Workshop</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/builder-workshop/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Apr 2009 12:35:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=476</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last year at APSA we had a luncheon. People came and sat quitely munching on boxed lunches while Jocelyn and I told them about Soomo.

At TLC this spring we had a roundtable where Kathi and I asked questions but mostly listened while professors told us about their experiences.

At MPSA last week we held one-on-one sessions in which we offered hand-holding on building a course. Though most peopel quickly said, "Oh, I get it." (and they did) "I can do this later." (And they might.)

What if we combined them all at APSA this year? A half day Builder Workshop. The email might look like this: (rough, sloppy first draft, but hopefully you get the gist)

<strong>Subject: Not Your Advisor's Workshop</strong>

Soomo publishing is hosting a 3 hour hands-on work session on Saturday morning at APSA. Bring your own laptop, syllabus and ideas. We'll provide internet connection, peers to swap ideas with, and our support team of instructional designers, copy editors, web researchers and videographers.

Things you might do in this work session:
- finally create those five new assignments you've been meaning to make
- find those elusive links for Federalism, Bureacracy, or Nigeria
- customize one of our 48 collections just for your course
- create an upper level collection: con law, leg process, presidency, etc
- write an assignment in your research area, have it copy edited and peer-reviewed, revise and post it for sharing with colleages (in one morning!)
- swap ideas with other profs on engaging students
- merge all your favorite links with one of our collections to create a resource reflecting your particular teaching style and emphasis
- fill in the holes so that a collection of links (ours, yours or both) are more robust, engaging and challenging for students

At noon, we will be serving lunch, will open the room to curious professors and will give each participant a chance to share what you you've built this morning, your past experience with technology in coursework and what you're trying out this semester.

Our hope is:
- you get all your questions answered
- you finally have a few hours with everything you need to do what you've been meaning to do
- you make some new connections with peers also exploring the potential of web-based resources

And maybe, just maybe, with all that creative energy, we'll see a few bold efforts are begun which might be reported upon at next Spring's TLC conference.

We are limited to 20 workbenches, so please reserve your space today.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>20 cents per page</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/20-cents-per-page/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 10 Apr 2009 01:42:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=479</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HP's MagCloud prints custom magazine(s) for 20 cents a page with no minimum order. Novel way to do a reader for class. The first example customer is a professor who uses the mag in journalism class. Later on they discuss similar efforts to print books. This kind of on-demand printing is very likely how we'll ultimately provide our print copies.

NY Times: <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/30/technology/internet/30mag.html?_r=1">Do-It-Yourself Magazines, Cheaply Slick</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<title>Word Cloud</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/word-cloud/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Apr 2009 17:31:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Tim and I were writing copy today to explain Soomo. Again. He asked if I didn't already have a copy of this somewhere and I pulled up six pages of attempts to explain Soomo over the past 5 years. We pasted all those attempts into <a href="http://www.wordle.net/">wordle</a> and this pops out. It's not a bad likeness.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-483" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/04/wordle1.jpg" alt="wordle1" width="840" height="549" />]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Evangelist</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/evangelist/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 10 Apr 2009 15:14:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=487</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When we were kicking around titles for our team of follower-uppers, one we floated was "Evangelist" -- a term which is now far more commonly associated with software than religion. Evangelists create fans. They differ from traditional (mis)conceptions of sales in that they focus on building relationships, creating fit and facilitating communication between those inside the organization and those outside.

Here's a very brief but revealing bit of insight into the composition of one evangelists routines:

On being a chief evangelist
Betsy Weber has been chief evangelist of software company TechSmith for six years. Her role is to listen to customers, determine their needs, sift that data and put it into context for TechSmith's software developers.

At the same time, she's also building a passionate fan base for TechSmith by meeting customers and being the warm, caring person she is naturally.

We asked her to put her six years of work into numbers:

* Met 7,000 customers in person
* Attended nearly 200 conferences (30 per year)
* Picked up 3,000 followers on Twitter
* Maintains regular, personalized contact with about 1,000 people

Has it paid off? TechSmith has done well in that time: double-digit revenue growth every year, totaling 259%. It's one thing for your company to say, in blog posts and email newsletters, that it loves customers. It's another thing to go out and do the hard work of brand grassroots-building and demonstrate it face-to-face.

<a href="http://www.churchofcustomer.com/2009/04/a-few-numbers-of-a-company-chief-evangelist.html">source</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>College Textbook Affordability Act</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/college-textbook-affordability-act/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 25 Apr 2009 12:12:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=447</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>HR 3512 introduced into Congress in October of 2007, but it has not passed yet.</em>

<strong>H.R.3512</strong>
<strong>Title:</strong> To ensure that college textbooks and supplemental materials are available and affordable.
<strong>Sponsor: </strong><a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/?&amp;Db=d110&amp;querybd=@FIELD%28FLD003+@4%28%28@1%28Rep+Carson++Julia%29%29+01473%29%29">Rep Carson, Julia</a> [IN-7] (introduced 9/10/2007)  <a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HR03512:@@@P">Cosponsors</a> (20)
<strong>Related Bills:</strong> <a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:SN00945:">S.945</a>
<strong>Latest Major Action: </strong>10/23/2007 Referred to House subcommittee. Status: Referred to the Subcommittee on Higher Education, Lifelong Learning, and Competitiveness.

<hr /><!--font size="-1"-->Jump to: <a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HR03512:@@@L&amp;summ2=m&amp;#summary">Summary</a>, <a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HR03512:@@@L&amp;summ2=m&amp;#major%20actions">Major Actions</a>, <a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HR03512:@@@L&amp;summ2=m&amp;#status">All Actions</a>, <a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HR03512:@@@L&amp;summ2=m&amp;#titles">Titles</a>, <a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HR03512:@@@L&amp;summ2=m&amp;#cosponsors">Cosponsors</a>, <a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HR03512:@@@L&amp;summ2=m&amp;#committees">Committees</a>, <a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HR03512:@@@L&amp;summ2=m&amp;#rel-bill-detail">Related Bill Details</a>, <a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HR03512:@@@L&amp;summ2=m&amp;#amendments">Amendments</a><hr /><strong><a name="summary">SUMMARY AS OF:</a></strong>
9/10/2007--Introduced.

College Textbook Affordability and Transparency Act of 2007 - Requires publishers informing teachers at institutions of higher education about available textbooks or supplements to include written information concerning: (1) the price the publisher would charge the bookstore associated with such institution for such items; (2) the full history of revisions for such items; and (3) whether such items are available in other formats, including paperback and unbound, and the price the publisher would charge the bookstore for items in those formats.

<a href="http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d110:HR03512:@@@L&amp;summ2=m&amp;">read more</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Dip</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/the-dip/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 20 Apr 2009 11:14:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=492</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Seths book <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Dip-Little-Book-Teaches-Stick/dp/1591841666/ref=sr_11_1?ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1240229766&amp;sr=11-1"><em>The Dip</em></a> is well summarized in the subtitle: "A little book that teaches you when to quit (and when to stick.)"

Hes offering a range of questions to ask when the going gets tough, when your efforts are not bearing fruit, when things are getting steadily worse or, even more frightening, plateauing in mediocrity.

The question scales quite well -- from the very largest questions:<em>
What is life really all about and which activities do I just need to stop?</em>
to the smallest:<em>
Are these little posts to the team really helping anyone or moving anything worthwhile forward?</em>

So we can ask the question of stick or quit? about  Soomo's major efforts such as <em>upper level poli sci courses or English</em> minor tactics such as <em>having a booth at APSA, having an ad in the program</em> and so on.

The bottom line of this book, frequently repeated throughout, is this:

<strong>Stick</strong> with those things that you believe will bear incredible fruit more than worth the pain.
<em>and</em>
<strong>Quit</strong> (without delay) everything unlikely to pay off in remarkable ways.

All of which begs the questions:
- Where are we in dips?
- Where do we need to quit?
- Where do we need to stick?

I anything comes to mind, please leave a comment...]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>What if we made it through the dip?</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/what-if-we-made-it-through-the-dip/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 21 Apr 2009 11:50:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=496</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>Consider what would happen if [we] managed to get through the dip and win in the market were already in. (p.29)</blockquote>
Lets take Soomo itself as an example. And lets further focus on just American Government, for the moment. Last summer we looked at the market for a $25 ancillary and decided thats not a market worth winning over the long term, so lets refine it even further to consider just a $50 textbook replacement for American Government.

What would it mean to win that market for best etext available for Political Science?

What would it mean to be the best option for:
- eager teachers ready to try a promising alternative OR
- those looking for ways to save their students money OR
- profs who have been building digital stuff and see this as an easier way OR
- profs who are not digital at all and see this as an easy way to become so?

Digital resources appear to be inevitable at this point and, simultaneously, not yet invented. What would happen if were the inventors? What will happen for the team that first offers a viable alternative to the print text; a legitimate alternative for every professor saying textbooks are too expensive or my students wont read the text or theyre all the same and none work well for me?

What if there was something on the market seen as having everything a textbook has, but at less than half the price and far more engaging?

What will happen if a platform comes on the market that is easier to use than Blackboard, charging the school nothing and students a lot less?

What if it became possible for hundreds of gifted teachers to simply modify a basic open core text to create a highly customized text that presented their personal passion for how to present American Government?

What if sales reps with shallow knowledge, enormous book bags, and too much reliance on cupcakes and pizza were replaced by informed people eager to assist professors; replacing a door-to-door sales persona with one more akin to a concierge, Apple genius, someone from Nordstoms, Prescriptives or Patagonia?

If the market gets a good look at all of this, from an independent publisher, respecting professors, authors and students, charging less, offering more with web 2.0 technology and a service 2.0 attitude, what would that mean for the provider?

And what if it expanded beyond American Government....

(Please add comments below as they come to mind.)]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Word-of-Mouth</title>

		<title>Cartel Busting</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/cartel-busting/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 21 Apr 2009 20:38:33 +0000</pubDate>

	<item>
		<title>Scarcity</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/scarcity/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 23 Apr 2009 11:30:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=510</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The dip creates scarcity; scarcity creates value.

Our problems create our dip. By solving our problems we get through our dip to the other side. Thats where the value lives.

By definition, if you are in the dip things are getting hard. You are trying to accomplish something and its not paying off right away. And its only wise to stick where you can become the worlds best solution.

Consider our effort to create presentational media to deliver the facts that textbooks provide in a different and more effective way. We created a few prototypes last fall, presented to a focus group, and got panned. (Im not sure what panned literally means, but in this case Im imagining a 12 cast iron skillet upside the head.)

So heres the question: If we go back to the drawing board, revise these and come up with more alternatives, keep thinking and making and testing, can we become the worlds best at providing a new voice, form and style for presentational content?

Answer: Yes we can.

This is a dip worth pushing through. Most people assigning, using or making textbooks believe that interactive new media and web distribution hold great potential for learning. But there are precious few models of it working really well. Its a real problem. Whoever contributes to the solution will do so by pushing through a big dip, a large struggle, a major effort to solve a difficult problem. And that creates incredible value.

But the problems are much bigger than how to present the facts of American government. We need to reinvent not only the presentation of content, but also how it is created, sold and supported.

This is where the real value of Soomo is derived. Were working on really hard problems -- finding the potential of new media for college education. These are our problems. These are our dips to push through. This is where we must stick. And pushing through them to other side is where we find value.

Where are we most up against the wall today? Where might we need to add resources in order to solve the next little problem in the quest to solve the big problem?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>510</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-04-23 07:30:27</wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>scarcity</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
