	<item>
		<title>New Blogs</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/new-blogs/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 22 Apr 2009 12:53:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=513</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Great questions below from Mary (in bold) about the new blogs:
AG for <a href="http://americansgoverning.wordpress.com/">people teaching American
</a> PoliSilo for <a href="http://polisilo.wordpress.com/">people teaching CG &amp; IR</a>

<strong>What is focus or bent? Why were they created?</strong>
If one of the key things we provide to professors is "a way to keep up with the web" then these link-a-week blogs (one for AG and one for CG/IR) are one way we can help with that. For people who aren't using us yet, they may sign up for a link a week, no charge, and see the word "soomo" every week for a year. If people are looking for links to use in teaching I want them to find us. And my hope is that the informed (opinion leading sneezers) will all know we are the world's best source for such links and will direct the searchers to us.

And we come across more good links than we can use. In fact, most cool links are not usable for us. This gives us a way to share all that great stuff with far less overhead than creating an assignment for each.

<strong>How is info about their existence be disseminated/shared? Will there be links out to them from our website(s)</strong>
Great question! Lemme think....
You should find out about these blogs if you....
- find our site
- create a course
- stop by our table at a conference
- attend a presentation or workshop
And hopefully, over time, you will not be able to read any of the major web pages, link lists or related blogs without hearing about these sites. That of course will require us to be consistent, persistent and extraordinary.

We'll publicize them to everyone we talk to and count on word of mouth and being the world's best to carry them further than we can. Any ideas on how to kickstart that process and hit the tipping point are welcome!

<strong>Who are authors?</strong>
Initially Rebecca and I will salvage some content from meta.soomo.org to quickly set a pattern. Our hope is that as soon as next week our new poli sci editor will also be working on them and she'll likely take the lead. But with our backlog of good stuff to share I think the first half year or so is close to written.

<strong>Who can be authors-not just respondents?</strong>
I suppose anyone with an interest. We don't plan to recruit authors, but I'd love for people to send us suggestions. Joc does this all the time. Jerry Goldman could do it. Miguel could do it without blinking. My hope is that it becomes the best way to get a link out to all those professors who are link hungry and after a while, the people who like links will know that we are a great place to share those with their peers.

<strong>They are accessed via Wordpress at present...intended audience?</strong>
We may well move them to ag.com/blog or /links or something. But today we just wanted to get something up and start looking at it, banging on it, figuring out what's realistic and useful.

<strong>What is the intended business purpose/usage?</strong>
To get everyone who cares about links for teaching poli sci to 1) know that soomo is the best source for such links and 2) to spread the good news about soomo to other professors who care about links for teaching. This is a way to offer a core benefit at no charge to build an audience of the very people who most want to know we exist. It's a version of free samples. It's something to forward to your peers if they care about links.

<strong>What are the subject parameters if any?</strong>
Short entries. Written for teachers -- not about political science or scholarship, but about teaching and learning political science with a strong bias toward good links. One idea per post. One post per week (to start.) The thesis is, "we'll help you keep up with the web."

This has been a long time coming and it's really exciting to see them coming to life!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Godin&#039;s Stuff is Good!</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/godins-stuff-is-good/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 22 Apr 2009 15:30:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dan</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=519</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!--StartFragment-->
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>As you might imagine, at my age, Ive been involved in numerous business endeavors. Most were startups, but some others were almost-defunct operations and were acquired as turnarounds. Every one was a learning experience.</span></strong><span> </span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>Only two of those businesses were in the same space. Those, Metatext and Soomo, were/are ventures into cyberspace with David as the founder and operating partner.</span></strong><span> </span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>When, through repeated trial and error, youve made as many mistakes as I, you allegedly gain wisdom. Wisdom tells us that modern-day technology and new-age thinking dictate major changes and paradigm shifts; but, fortunately, some proven ingredients for success never change. <span> </span>Those are as valid today as they were five, ten or 20 years ago.</span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>Ive been enthralled with Permission Marketing and grateful to David for sending me a copy. If you havent read it, I urge you to do so.<span> </span>Seth Godin has formulated a recipe for marketing and sales which folds new ideas and old standards into a proven system for selling virtually anything.<span> </span>Hes a marketing genius. </span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>He leans heavily on trust as an imperative for successful relationships.<span> </span>One of my favorite books, written by Stephen M. R. Covey, The Speed of Trust, validates Godins premise. Coveys single statement says it all:<span> </span>Nothing is as fast as the speed of trust.</span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>I also like Godins approach because it concentrates on doing more business with fewer, high-quality customers  a salespersons dream.<span> </span>This model will function best in a company with unwavering integrity and a commitment to excellence  a high calling to which all of us at Soomo aspire.</span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>Godin's credibility with me was immediate because he espouses<span> </span>many of the very principles and guidelines which have guided me through a reasonably successful career.<span> </span>Yes, after all these years theyre still valid! An abbreviated, paraphrased version of a few of them follow:</span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>* Its much wiser to retain an existing customer than to find a new one;</span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>* We should always <em>under promise</em> and <em>over deliver</em>;</span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>* Trust is a key to any successful, lasting business relationship, and that trust cannot be earned without first  demonstrating competence and integrity;</span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>* Lasting relationships, whether business or personal, must be nurtured on a regular basis;</span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>Finally, not from Godin's book but from Broughtons trial-and-error experience: <span> </span>There are three personal characteristics which must be present to assure long-term business success: Integrity, humility and a sense of urgency. </span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span>I look forward to our meeting next week in Charlottesville. </span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span> </span></strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span> </span></strong><strong> </strong></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><strong><span> </span></strong></p>

<!--EndFragment-->]]></content:encoded>

		<title>The Language of Interaction</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/the-language-of-interaction/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 23 Apr 2009 18:01:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rebeccasmithshelley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=521</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I've been working on populating our new blogs this week, and stumbled on this slideshow (and <a href="http://www.pushclicktouch.com/">this website</a>, which might be a great one to link to from our learninginteractions blog - eventually). This really put into perspective the kind of brain-work that's already behind us, and yet really never ends. In a way, this is a salute to David, Tim Jones, and all the designers who have brought our site this far. Here's to them, and here's to those who carry it forward.
<p style="text-align:center">[slideshare id=424908&amp;doc=languageofinteraction052308-1211590324384200-8]</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Why blog?</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/why-blog/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 24 Apr 2009 11:23:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=529</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>One more time, why are we creating blogs?</strong>

Part of the reason it's coming up right now is, no surprise, Seth Godin. We can spam (send unrequested interruptions) people as often as we like, or we can give them an opportunity to subscribe to a steady flow of helpful message from us. These blogs are meant to be provide that steady flow of messages.

Professors can go look at the blog, subscribe via RSS or subscribe via email. We will post helpful stuff every week and can share news and reasons to use Soomo along the way. This is what professors give us permission to send to them.

And in the process, we should created the world's best collection of links to use in teaching political science. This should be a treasure trove for "our people" (those wanting help in teaching with the web) and they will, we hope, share it with anyone and everyone they bump into who is also interested in links. It's the most contagious thing about our site -- at least until you're assigning it, seeing your kids light up and interacting with Tom.

It's free of charge, commitment free, works with how you teach now and should, with every message, increase our credibility and your desire to use the web in teaching.

This is meant to be a very helpful thing, a very viral thing and to ultimately drive people to adopt a Soomo product whenever appropriate.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The Problem With Infinite Customers</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/the-problem-with-infinite-customers/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Apr 2009 12:49:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=535</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Seth's <a href="http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2009/04/infinitythey-keep-making-more-of-it.html">post yesterday</a> reminds us that when we think the supply of customers is inexhaustible -- or at least that we will never get to all of them with our available resources -- we are tempted toward <em>bigger</em> instead of <em>better</em>.

He ends by reminding us that "big enough" is big enough. The implication throughout is that the people in front of you are more important than the anonymous masses beyond them. And it's likely very true that we'll never reach the masses beyond until we are focusing primarily on serving those right in front of us. He's not saying "stay small." He's saying "don't let bigger call you away from better."

And today, right now, that means I need to care more about Sally, the Ph.D. candidate I just spoke with wanting to use us this summer, than about the 3000 similar people I haven't connected with yet.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Nutty David</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/nutty-david/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 29 Apr 2009 16:39:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=539</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Nuts Online is a Service 2.0 company. Check out this email confirming delivery and asking for feedback, investment, celebration and endorsement. Back in the day we used to "presume the sale" -- these folks are presuming we're in the tribe!
<blockquote>Begin forwarded message:

From: NutsOnline.com &lt;customerservice@nutsonline.com&gt;
Date: April 29, 2009 12:35:05 PM EDT
To: purchase@soomopublishing.com
Subject: NutsOnline.com order #453702 delivered!

Hip hip hooray! Hey there nutty David! According to the galactic delivery powers that be (aka UPS), your order has been delivered. Yippee! We certainly hope it deliciously smashes expectations with enough force to crack a macadamia nut in the shell!!!

Uncle Sandy, Cousin David, Dad, and I would love to hear from you, so what are you waiting for?
http://www.nutsonline.com/submit_testimonial.html

Again, thank you, and remember:
Enjoy, have a great day, and smile away!

~Jeffrey and the NutsOnline Family</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Non-traditional is the new norm</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/04/non-traditional-is-the-new-norm/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 30 Apr 2009 18:34:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=542</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>Only about 17% of the higher education population in the U.S. meets the stereotype of the traditional 18-22 year-old full-time undergraduate student residing on campus  the majority are a combination of working adults, part-timers, commuters, and transfer students who attend multiple institutions and stop out and re-enroll over the course of their lives.</blockquote>
from an <a href="http://highereducationmanagement.wordpress.com/">interview</a> with the director of Eduventures focusing on the growth in people going back to school and the need for distance learning among these non-traditional students.]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Friending v. Selling</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/friending-v-selling/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 02 May 2009 03:08:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=544</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://copylicious.com/2009/02/how-to-go-on-a-marketing-diet/">This post</a> (from my new favorite blogger) provides a nice take on the difference between messages trying to buy sales (with discounts) and messages which move the process forward by addressing the real concerns in credible ways.

A key section:
<blockquote>None of these sales emails is ever going to make me buy from them. Even though I really want to buy. And tell all my friends about them.

Why not? Because price isnt the reason I havent bought in the first place.

If I was ready to buy, I would have bought already. A sale isnt going to make me flip the switch. Instead, Im mulling over practical concerns like whether Id really be able to use it enough, if I could lift it up the stairs every day, and what I would do if I needed to use it after dark.

What would be some better ways for them to encourage me to buy?</blockquote>
Which leads me to wonder about the practical concerns some of our people might be thinking through between the day they get interested and they day they assign. And what would be a better encouragement for them?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>friending-v-selling</wp:post_name>

			<wp:comment_id>20</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Dan]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>dhb@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://dhb@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>24.196.24.203</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2009-05-02 12:48:16</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-05-02 17:48:16</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Profound questions, indeed, David.  And I'll probably compound the puzzle even more by offering a comment which was an eye-opener for me years ago:  A consultant named Larry Wilson of Counselor Selling said, "People do things for THEIR reasons, not mine."

That obviously begs the question, "If I don't currently know their reasons, how do I find out?"

Wilson also used two terms which were alluded to in Charlottesville.   He was a strong proponent of using "fact-finding questions" and "feeling-finding questions".  In that order.

The common denominator is  "asking questions".  Relevant questions.   Doing so sends a clear message that we truly want to understand the issues which clients face.  A deeper level of permission follows.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Customer Share</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/customer-share/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 04 May 2009 12:40:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=547</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA["Market share" is the percentage of all professors using the product. If every professor who could teach with Soomo does, we have 100% market share. (We all know this, I know. Hang with me.)

"Customer share" is a measure of how completely a given professor uses Soomo. If a particular professor uses Soomo in every suitable class and gets the full potential out of Soomo in each of those classes, then we have 100% customer share. But if she uses it in only one of five courses and gets only half the potential out of it, we are at roughly 10% customer share.

To grow, we could find 10 more like her, or just help her to use us 10 times as much. If we get her to 100% we're delivering 10 times the value and receiving many times the revenue. (And most likely inducing more sneezing than we'd see from 10 profs at 10% each.)

Talking with Mary Jane over the weekend I realized how much of our discussion in Charlottesville was really about customer share. That is, we talked about ways of helping people who are already "sold" on Soomo to be able to effectively get more out of Soomo:  start using it, get the most out of it for each class, use it in most of your classes and see it as the easiest way to make a web assignment.   The roundtable at TLC was a real wake up call for me on this front. It was clear that even our most involved professors felt like they were merely dipping a toe in AG. They all expressed a long-standing desire to "really look at the assignments when I have a chance." At least one didn't know we had collections for IR &amp; CG. At least one didn't realize we would customize to match his text. And these were among our most involved professors!

This continued at MPSA where the one-on-one sessions each resulted in a person coming to see us as more than they had thought we were, and at the table and in campus visits since.

This is probably the defining element of our conversations with the market right now: explaining what we are at an ever deeper level and explaining in an ever more personalized way, driven by probing questions (as Dan says, 'fact' questions and 'feeling' questions.)

Training and explaining appear to be the shortest path to real usage.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Conversations with the Masses</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/conversations-with-the-masses/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 May 2009 12:43:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=549</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[From the 1:40 ratio of the TLC workshop to meeting with one professor at a time during a campus visit, it seems every conversation I've had with professors this year is furthering their understanding of how we can help them and what we offer. It's just not obvious to them.

Over time, we are learning what needs to be on the websites. And we will be adding to it weekly for months to come. But because schools, courses, and professors vary there will never be one explanation for everybody. We will always be able to increase our usefulness to an interested professor with a conversation about how they teach and how we might help. Always.

And we're not unique in this way. An afternoon with someone from Apple would increase the amount of utility I derive from my Mac. That's the thinking behind the genius bars: if I know more, I use more and my Mac is more valuable. They are increasing the value of their product with education.

Our concept of "office hours" (aka: one-on-ones) at conferences can be very much like that: a time and place where you can opt-in for one-on-one training, get your questions answered and increase the utility of these products you want to know more about.

In Charlottesville, we talked a lot about Mass Communication as the key to letting people know we exist, helping them get started on knowing what we offer and helping them self-select into a group of individuals who are interested in what we are doing.

From there, every strategy we listed is about helping them get an ever more complete picture of how we help them:
- Gaining permission (subscribe to the blog) is the means to continue the explanation and start delivering value.
- Increasing their commitment or engagement (review or write) is about helping them take a closer look and delivering real value to them in the process.
- Lowering the hurdles to adoption (we'll set up for you) is about making it easier for them to act on the intellectual commitment they've already made to using this.
- And the strategies for increasing involvement are all about helping them get more out of what we offer.

This is why our "sales" effort is all about "support." People who self-select as interested in Soomo are already sold. But they aren't making full use of the product. In fact many aren't making any use of it. They aren't finding time to review the assignments. They aren't leading discussions on this stuff and so the students quit paying attention. They're unsure how to grade efficiently. They don't understand how to use it with the LMS being imposed upon them. They aren't using it in upper level courses. They have yet to notice it's the easiest way to create a web assignment.

The answers can be provided in case studies, workshops, screencasts, how to's, peer advising, office hours and so on. But they can also be provided in individual phone calls. And individual phones calls are the cheapest, easiest, most personal way to to do it.

After having the same conversation with 10 different profs, we are usually ready to make a canned version - a write up or screen cast or whatever. But even then, we may find that emailing a link to the canned version does a lot less than a conversation would to increase their understanding, the value they derive, the personal fit to them, our understanding of their needs, their relationship with us, and their commitment to Soomo.

We need to have these conversations; to help the people; to find the patterns; and to create the self-help resources. (Geoff Peterson for one says he would rather watch a screen cast than talk to someone.) And we need to keep working to build relationships, to make the paths straight to getting the most out of Soomo.

We have what much of the market is looking for. But they aren't quite sure what to do with it yet. Ultimately they will learn the optimal practices from each other. But it's up to us to jumpstart that process. One conversation at a time.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>ADP</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/adp/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 May 2009 12:56:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=552</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[MJ recently signed up for ADP to do our payroll. They invited her to a scheduled class for everyone who signed up that week/month or whatever. It wasn't required, but was available. In that class (something like webex) they offered an overview then opened it up to questions. Following the class, she received subsequent calls and emails offering additional services and forms of help. They may have gone a little overboard on trying to increase the number of services sold. But for us, the idea of offering professors a range of kinds of help might make a lot of sense.

Just created a course? Great! Here are some screen casts.
Two days later, here are some case studies.
A week later, here are some ways people use our tools.

Signing up to create a course gives us some permission to teach you about the course. And we know every single professor needs it. The "tip on the splash page" is a time honored training technique. But it requires a log-in to launch. And they too often become trivia.

I signed up for two services this past week that I honestly wish would help me figure out how to use them. Let's not be that company that gets someone intrigued by their promises, and then fails to give them the support they need for those promises to become true.

Or perhaps I should say, let's stop being that company. I've left too many professors out in the cold to fend for themselves. Let's bring them in.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The New Norm</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/the-new-norm/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 May 2009 11:08:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=554</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Sometimes you want to go where everybody knows your name. For us, that's APSA. 10,000 political scientists. What would it take to ensure that every one of them knows
1) that soomo is a publisher,
2) that we create web stuff,
3) that we are all about teaching and
4) that we are a support 2.0 company?

They won't all become users. They don't all teach for one thing and many of those who do aren't looking for better ways to do so. But hundreds of them know of problems today that we can help them solve. And all of them can tell others about us.

How can we make sure that every attendee leaves being able to explain to anyone who asks that Soomo is a digital publisher, creating resources for instructors to assign to students and providing exceptional support?

Some of our answers so far:
- roundtable of users (with invitations to all who know us)

- focus group of potential users on new material from summer (invitations even to those who don't know us)

- workshop / lunch for all comers (invitation to all attendees)

- office hours for all comers (invitations to all we know and all who come by the booth)

- sponsor the email station, with a huge sign, maybe smaller signage changing daily, maybe staff nearby offering exceptional service

- wear something distinctive. t-shirts. soomo loin cloths. something.

- give away replica campaign buttons

- distinctive ad in the program, touting our key characteristics

- display our new Tom Helped Me shirts and distribute to any who will let Tom help them in office hours.

- new website, logo, identity making a debut

- new content from many different authors debuting. Perhaps something distinctive on the table top -- like many books -- explaining the many new collections.

What else? What says "publisher" of "web media" for "instructors" and "support freaks"?]]></content:encoded>

What if we present a Soomo to a professor (work with profs to find 4 nominees, take votes beforehand via the web to determine the winner) at this banquet? A Soomo could be like the Oscar for best use of the web in your class. Or something else... there are lots of possibilities for recognition. Good teachers are so often under-recognized, and we are in a position to do something about that.


Rebecca]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>Case Studies</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/case-studies/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 May 2009 12:59:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=557</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Apple posted four (stunning) short video case studies <a href="http://developer.apple.com/wwdc/iphone/#culturedcode">here</a>. In each case, someone is telling how us how easy the iPhone SDK (Software Development Kit) made it for them to do something extraordinary.

If you think of Soomo titles as a platform, a place for professors to engage in the art of teaching, it's easy to imagine similar case studies from innovative teachers who used our platform to make something really interesting for their students and to share that thing in our store for other professors to find and use.

Tim Grant can make videos in this style. Jamie Parker can design pages in this style. Now we just need to know of some professors doing amazing things on our platform. Have they done it already? Might they be doing it this summer? Are there any who would do it if we gave them an encouraging nudge?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>557</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="filmmaking"><![CDATA[filmmaking]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="marketing"><![CDATA[Marketing]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="site-enhancements"><![CDATA[Site Enhancements]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[25]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[25]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>Kindle / Textbooks</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/kindle-textbooks/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 05 May 2009 14:25:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=564</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div class="qtstory">
<div class="headline">
<h2>Amazon Reportedly Plans Textbook-Friendly Kindle</h2>
</div>
[<a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2009/05/05/qt#198107">source</a>]

Buzz began building last week that Amazon was planning a major announcement in New York this week, potentially with a higher education theme. Reports in <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/04/technology/companies/04reader.html?scp=2&amp;sq=kindle&amp;st=cse" target="_blank"><em>The New York Times</em></a> and other publications Monday about the prospect of a bigger, newspaper-friendly third iteration of the Kindle culminated late Monday in a <a href="http://online.wsj.com/article/SB124146996831184563.html#mod=testMod" target="_blank"><em>Wall Street Journal</em> article</a> saying that the new Kindle, to be released Wednesday, was designed specifically to attract the interest of academic and textbook publishers. The <em>Journal'</em>s article said that Amazon's unveiling of the new Kindle in New York would be accompanied by news of joint projects with six colleges and universities, apparently designed to experiment with students' use of online textbooks. Officials at Amazon and at several of the colleges identified in the article -- Arizona State, Case Western Reserve, Pace and Princeton Universities, Reed College, and the University of Virginia's Darden School of Business -- declined to comment on the relationship with Amazon, except to say that they would have news Wednesday. (Note: <em>Inside Higher Ed</em> and Amazon have struck an agreement for <em>Inside Higher Ed</em> to be available through the Kindle.)

via Danielle</div>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Way to cut to the chase Rebecca. Today the kindle offers almost no interactivity, as I understand it. No links, no web awareness, no ability to play video. So today I would say, "nope, you can't put soomo on a kindle."

But as we're seeing with Eastvold, it might be that students enroll in a course and choose their format for the text: used print, new print, PDF, HTML, Kindle -- that's all easy today. We might add "mp3" or "video lectures" to the list, depending on how much we like the text.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[This article from the economist:
http://www.economist.com/opinion/displaystory.cfm?STORY_ID=13109596

offers a nice assessment of why the time might finally be right for kindle. Interestingly, the author emphasizes periodicals, which a new larger display would help with.

And in the last paragraph he talks about How Apple could kill the Kindle -- with some kind of hybrid between an iPhone and the Air -- a tablet with a touch screen. Now that would have net awareness, links, color, play videos, store user data and much more. Apple is expected to make an announcement early next month.

As Kevin says, we're all waiting for the thing. The thing will come. One of these might just be the thing.]]></wp:comment_content>

		<title>GradeGuru</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/gradeguru/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 May 2009 01:12:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=566</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[From Jamie comes this news about a McGraw backed service for sharing classnotes.
<blockquote><strong>Genius Idea:</strong> GradeGuru is a simple idea that solves a nagging problem for college students. The core of GradeGuru is the ability to upload, share, read, and rate class notes. If you have a group of friends in organic chemistry (ouch), and you want to compare notes to make sure nothing is missed, GradeGuru is useful. But the websites real strength is the ability to organize a library of class notes for future students.</blockquote>
[<a href="http://mashable.com/2009/05/05/gradeguru/">source: Mashable</a>] // <a href="http://www.gradeguru.com/">GradeGuru</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Kindle DX</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/kindle-dx/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 May 2009 21:03:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=571</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As expected, Amazon announced a new larger Kindle today.

<a href="http://amazon.com/">Amazon</a>

<a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/05/06/kindle-dx-college-plans-revealed-only-300-students-total/">300 Students in pilot</a>

<a href="http://online.wsj.com/article/SB124162110396691937.html">WSJ</a>

<a href="http://www.engadget.com/2009/05/06/engadget-on-the-kindle-dx/">Engadget Editorial</a>

Jon Schmidt, one of Dan's contacts at Troy pointed us to the article in the Chronicle of Higher Education, which is the most thorough and accurate consideration I've seen of what this means for etextbooks. <a href="http://chronicle.com/temp/email2.php?id=hh84jbq4xyHpxHR5qyBgQbgmwkRb4pNc">The Chronicle</a>

<strong>from Emily:</strong>
<blockquote>I read about this on a tech website yesterday. One of the questions they raise is possible competition from Apple who is rumored to be developing a super-sized I-Pod Touch. If Apple does come out with this product, not only can students read the screen (same size as new Kindle or larger), but they can also surf the web and have access to the app store.

Check out the article: <a href="http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2346545,00.asp">PC Magazine</a></blockquote>
<strong>Kathi offers this from Publisher's Lunch:Here's the latest from "Publisher's Lunch" </strong>
<blockquote><strong>SuperKindle Is Here; "DX" Must Mean Didn't Explain...?</strong>
Today's SuperKindle press conference unfolded essentially along the planned/leaked script. (Except that we were amused to note Jeff Bezos had to read his expansive "mission statement" for Kindle from the monitor.) It's better than a piece of plain paper, it studies better than a textbook, and starting this summer it swoops in to try and save three newspapers--except that it lists for $489. The new model, now positioned as the second member of the Kindle "family," is....a bigger version of the current Kindle.

The actual news that was not already leaked is that this summer, the New York Times, Washington Post and Boston Globe will pilot offering SuperKindle "for a reduced price in exchange for long-term commitments for subscriptions." In a brief speech, NYT chief Arthur Sulzberger clarified that his company's marketing trials are focused on "areas where home delivery is not available."

Textbook partners for SuperKindleCollege are higher ed giants Pearson, Cengage and Wiley, though the extent of their participation was not quantified, except that they "will being offering textbooks...beginning this summer." The pilot program college partners are those already noted earlier in the week (plus today's hosts at Pace, though they were not mentioned onstage), but they will be distributing mere "hundreds" of SuperKindles to student to study usage.

The new reader does offer auto-rotation, just like the unmentioned iPhone/iPod, to show text in portrait or landscape mode.

In updated fake statistics, at the beginning of the presentation Bezos noted that "Kindle sales are now 35 percent of books where we have Kindle editions," and he claimed the jump was "coincident with the launch of Kindle 2." Total Kindle books available are now 275,000.

The display of SuperKindle is said to be 2.5 times as large as regular Kindle. In other specs, it has a 9.7-inch display; 3.3 gb of storage; and native pdf support.

The company still insists on calling the unit Kindle DX, though as far as we could tell, DX stands for "didn't explain." As in, didn't explain the name; didn't explain when it's available (except for "this summer"); didn't explain any of the details of the textbook pilots; didn't explain the incentive pricing to newspaper subscribers; and so on.</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>10 Years of Permission</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/10-years-of-permission/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 May 2009 03:23:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=579</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Seth's post today looks back on the 10 year anniversary of his book Permission Marketing.

He ends with this:
<blockquote>There's a lot of updating that the book could use, because when I wrote it there was no Google, Facebook, Twitter, universal email access, widespread high bandwidth connectivity, browsers that rarely crashed or iPhones. But I'm going to let it stand as is, because keeping it up to date is a never ending task. I hope the general concepts stand the test of time. The biggest thing I'd change is the emphasis on games and prizes over promises and connection and information. I think the latter end up scaling better and are more universal and reliable.

Short version: Don't be selfish. You're not in charge. Make promises and keep them. It's like dating. It's an asset, it's expensive and it's worth it.</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The value of a good complaint (and what to do about it)</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/the-value-of-a-good-complaint-and-what-to-do-about-it/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 May 2009 19:11:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=588</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Not that we've had many, but here is <a href="http://zingtrain.com/ontrack/may2009/" target="_blank">an article</a> that highlights the good that comes when a customer takes the time to offer their complaint. <a href="http://www.zingermansdeli.com/content/pages/home.php" target="_blank">Zingerman's </a>is a deli in Ann Arbor, MI that has made customer service their primary product. They happen to sell a whole lot of food stuffs as a result. Interesting joint.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Great article-- step 5, especially, was a revelation: the difference between proactive and reactive. Makes me think of the time that Rebecca Ruth's Candies in Frankfort, KY, failed to deliver some goods to my sister's house in time for Christmas. They are a small operation with amazing bourbon ball chocolates-- a Mashburn family tradition. I left a sad little e-mail on Christmas eve saying we were really disappointed not to have received the chocolates. The afternoon of Christmas Day, the owner of Rebecca Ruth called my sister's, asked to speak with me, and made it right. I was so moved that he would take time from his holiday to make things right on behalf of his company. Yep, I tell a lot of people this story-- and talk up the company every chance I get!]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>About PoliSilo</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/about-polisilo/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 May 2009 02:59:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=599</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[To minimize reader confusion (especially among profs unsure of exactly what a "blog" is) and maximize our exposure (without tipping into salesy) we need a little explanation on the first page. Something between a tagline (such as "plenty to share") and a full on "about us" page.

I need your creativity and marketing acumen!

Here are some options to get the juices flowing:

Links for professors from the rogue publishers at Soomo.

A list of links, sites and tools useful in teaching Political Science, from professors around the country, supported by the teaching and learning wonks at Soomo Publishing.

A growing collection of the best links for teaching political science from the overflowing files of soomo publishing.

How do you teach political science <em>now</em>?

We had so many links, we didn't know what to do.

Using the web to teach polisci.

Links and tools for teaching polisci.

Web-fu to use on your students.

How are <em>you</em> using the web to teach?

Keeping up with the web so you don't have to.

Links for instructors, from Soomo and friends.

Gudferteechin.

Cream of the crop for teaching polisci.

Official totem pole for a scholarly tribe studying the teaching and learning of political science.

A pipeline of links for engaging students.

Artifacts, tools and data for teaching political science.

This is PoliSilo: a weblog by the editors at Soomo, and some of the most inspiring instructors we know, sharing links to cool tools and interesting websites for engaging students of political science. Since 2004 Soomo has been creating compelling, digital resources for political science. To learn more, visit our <a href="http://soomo.org">site</a>.

Any favorites? Any suggestions? Judges will select a winner by noon....]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Too Much Free</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/too-much-free/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 May 2009 21:42:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=602</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I'm not entirely sure why Seth's post are so relevant to us so often. I'm sure I'm quoting him too much. But...how can I not <a href="http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2009/05/too-much-free.html">point to today's</a>?

When something that used to be notoriously expensive (say, textbooks) becomes free (say, through flatworld) that's a really exciting thing. But the excitement of free will fade and in the end, I think professors will chose the resource that's good. The one that meets the needs for which they've assigned a textbook.

And it would be logical to conclude that of several such options, they might choose the least expensive. So if Flatworld can be as good as they non-free alternatives they win. But it's not historically true that professors choose the least expensive option. The market leaders are consistently among the most expensive, which also makes sense from a supply &amp; demand perspective.

This suggests that contary to conventional discussion about prices being "too high" and polisci textbooks being "all the same" most professors behave as if some are better than others and a good book is worth a high price.

In all of this I am not trying to downplay Flatworld's pitch. (btw: they have no polisci titles. Yet.) But I am trying to say that we aren't on a free-to-students model and so we can't out-free Flatworld. Instead we have to provide a better product. We won't out textbook teh textbooks either, and while a lower price is key to our story it's not enough to ensure wide adoption and long-term success.

Our hope is on creating something of genuine value. Something that does what professors and students hope textbooks will do in a way that is far better and, as gravy, much cheaper.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>A complaint well handled</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/a-complaint-well-handled/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 May 2009 19:01:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=604</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I bought a some network equipment from cableorganizer.com.  There was a problem - a manufacturing issue really - but I made it work.  I gave the product a 1 of 5 star review on their site.

Got this email today from somebody who A. noticed, B. cared and C. acted.  A good model for us.



<blockquote>Good Afternoon,

Thank you so much for taking the time to review the Kendall Howard Hinged Wall Rack.  I have contacted the manufacture regarding the issues on this product to see if this was an isolated incident or if they have had a problem with this.

From what I understand the screws that were provided with it had paint on them?  I ask because these typically do not come with any hardware, and I want to make sure we are talking about the right product.  We would defiantly like to send you another unit, or issue a refund because you were not satisfied.  Please let me know, so that we can resolve this matter, and prevent it from happening to you or someone else in the future.  Thanks



CableOrganizer.com
Stephanie Kingslien
Customer Service / Product Specialist
Stephanie@cableorganizer.com
5610 NW 12th Ave
Suite 214
Fort Lauderdale, FL 33309
Phone: 1-866-222-0030 Ext 6348
Fax: 954-861-2001
</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>a-complaint-well-handled</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>Following</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/following/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 08 May 2009 22:17:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=608</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This is huge:

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-609" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/chapman.jpg" alt="Chapman" width="478" height="303" />

We have now entered this professor's social space. Every time Melissa tweets a juicy link to something remarkable, or we post a blog entry to a solid teaching resource, Chapman will see it in his preferred interface for keeping up with folks. Every week, 2-5 times, he'll see a link to some Soomo goodness.

Even better he can forward these links to any colleague he thinks will be interested in any one of them. He can let his link-finding friends know to follow us easily, no cost, no commitment. And anyone who checks out his twitter page can see that he's following us. For that matter, anyone who checks out our twitter can see that he's following us. We have, in effect, been endorsed as worth listening to by <a href="http://twitter.com/DocPolitics">twitter.com/DocPolitics</a>.

And my hope is that he will quickly come to see the kind of things we share and begin to contribute. And others will contribute. And he will see that. And the entire community becomes a safer place to be because no one is here alone...there are others, like-minded people, pursuing this together.

If attention is our most precious resource, Chapman has just given us his. And he's done so publicly, saying in effect that we are worth listening too. That makes me want to post something really quite fabulous. And soon.

Thanks all for getting this blog/twitter presence up and out so quickly! More Monday on how we can pull people in most effectively.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Those Who Give Permission Are In Our Tribe</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/those-who-give-permission-are-in-our-tribe/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 May 2009 12:16:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=615</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Why in the world would someone give us permission to stay in touch with them?

Looking at my email subscriptions I see organizations I love, companies Im rooting for, people whom I want to see succeed. I enroll in email from companies that have made so much stuff (or music, or events) I like that Im eager to see what they do next, cause I know its going to be good. I opt-in when I think Im going to miss out on something if I dont.

These are the companies who get their logo stuck on bumpers. When two people meet who are into Patagnoia, or Apple, or the Red Sox, they know they are talking to a kindred spirit. They know they are in the same tribe.

In Seths book Tribes he takes a deeper look at these groups, why we join, how they work, why we need more and what it takes to create one.

Not every company has a tribe. Macintosh and Linux are both far more tribal than Windows. Tribal companies are more than preferred providers. If Im opting-in to email, its because I want more of whatever they are doing. Sure I go to Starbucks, and fly US Air, eat Outback, and wear Levis. But I dont let them send me email. They have good products, but I dont find their messages compelling. And to get permission to email me, you need to be an organization with a strong voice. You need to be about something, to have a perspective so inline with mine, so compelling, that I want to hear what you have to say. And these subscriptions reliably say something other than buy from us.

Our tribe begins with those who give us permission to stay in touch. The progression from interested to advocate is one of increasing engagement with the tribe. It requires us to say what we are about and to back it up with our actions, products and policies. It requires us to be more than just another option, the newest option, or the cheapest option.

It pushes us to be remarkable, memorable, something to write home about.

Soomo is already a radical alternative to a textbook. If people get a hold of the potential for impacting a classroom, this may just be the kind of thing theyll want a bumper sticker for. Keep me on your list Soomo. Youre doing good stuff and I want to make sure I have a chance to get in on whatever you do next.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>615</wp:post_id>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Empowering Our Tribe</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/empowering-our-tribe/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 12 May 2009 12:20:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=618</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Soomo is set up to be the leader of a tribe. This is tribe of people Ive been calling eager teachers. They are always looking for a better way to reach their students. They use the web, or wish they did. They try out new stuff every semester. They do more than their dean requires because they care, a lot, about lighting students up. They are often operating in isolation without support from peers or professional recognition. Often they have a spouse who says they work on this stuff too much. But they are compelled to reach these kids. They dont need encouragement to teach. And they dont need to be told how to teach. What they need is some help.

Soomo can empower these teachers. We can save them tons of time in finding links and making assignments. We can save them time in setting up the online part of a course. We can offer original media perfect for engaging their students, which cant be found anywhere else. We offer more effective resources, at a much lower cost, with exceptional service.

And to go even further, we know they have a unique voice and we have tools to amplify it. They can start with our collection, tweak to the needs of their kids, incorporate their scholarship, add assignments as needed and, when they are ready, we can help them get that unique collection out to the world.

And when we do that, we make it ever easier for the less ambitious teachers to look awesome. They can leverage the work of their over-achieving peers and in just a few clicks provide hours of great assignments every week.

Who cares about new and better ways of teaching political science? Our tribe does. And these are the people who are willing to take a chance on digital resources instead of playing it safe with a textbook. These are the people other profs ask for guidance on all things digital or pedagogical. Even if we became the default tool for all courses, these would still be the people who got the most out of it, contributed the most too it and to whom we should listen most closely.

They have a conference in TLC, and they are true fans of that unique gathering. But they havent had a publisher until now.

Its time to introduce ourselves to our Tribe.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Tribes: The Movie</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/tribes-the-movie/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 May 2009 12:41:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=620</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[How To Create a Tribe:
- find a group that has a yearning but is disconnected (those dissatisfied with textbooks?)
- rally them around the need they share
- connect them to each other (case studies, polisilo, breakfasts)
- give them a way to pursue their passion (soomo titles)

Just in time for Tribe week at Soomo, Seth comes to the <a href="http://www.ted.com/index.php/talks/seth_godin_on_the_tribes_we_lead.html">TED screen</a>.

[ted id="538"] ]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Processing Email</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/processing-email/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 19 May 2009 12:18:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=626</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Merlin Mann is the guy behind <a href="http://www.43folders.com/">43Folders</a>, a popular life-hacking site with a big debt owed the <a href="http://www.davidco.com/what_is_gtd.php">Getting Things Done</a> (GTD) movement. In a lecture given at google, he offers a GTD approach to email called InBox Zero.

I agree with a lot of what he says, but not all. He's PG, but entertaining. I'm not seeing a way to grab only the audio, but I just listened to this without watching it and don't feel I missed anything. My favorite take aways from this talk are:
- figuring out how to do everything flowing in is a real challenge
- one key is figuring out the next action on any given thing
- another key is sometimes closing your email door and just working
- remembering that email serves us, we don't live to serve it

If you give it a listen, let us know what you dig. And if you'd rather read than listen, you can skim through this <a href="http://www.43folders.com/izero">collection of articles</a> and get a very similar message.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>SoomoSphere</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/soomosphere/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 18 May 2009 12:29:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=678</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In some ways we have no competition. In otherways, we are competing with every textbook on the market. And Blackboard. And any other digital resource a professor likes such as Flickr, Google, FaceBook, Amazon, etc.

For professors we live in a world, or in a part of the world, where we are far from being the only inhabitant. This world might be called the SoomoSphere. Recently Kelly asked me to put together a list of related companies and this is what came together:

My favorite related site: <a href="http://www.aplia.com/">Aplia</a>

The biggest of the ebook providers: <a href="http://www.coursesmart.com/">Course Smart</a>

Great PR right now: <a href="http://www.flatworldknowledge.com/">Flat World Knowledge</a>

We are most often compared to: <a href="http://mypoliscilab.com/">mypoliscilab</a>

The giant among course management players (which is not our space): <a href="http://blackboard.com/">Blackboard</a>

Work for hire in this space, but a nice vibe: <a href="http://www.sixredmarbles.com/">Six Red Marbles</a>

George Mason U is creating the stuff you crave in History. They're probably the best ed tech folks in any discipline. Some sites:
<a href="http://chnm.gmu.edu/">Center for History &amp; New Media</a>
<a href="http://scholarpress.net/">Scholar Press</a>
<a href="http://www.zotero.org/">Zoter0</a>
<a href="http://omeka.org/">Omeka</a>

Some growing companies:
<a href="http://www.smarthinking.com/">SmartThinking</a>
<a href="http://turnitin.com/static/index.html">TurnItIn</a>
<a href="http://webassign.com/">WebAssign</a>
<a href="http://www.tegrity.com/">Tegrity</a>
<a href="http://www.vistahigherlearning.com/">Vista Higher Learning</a>
<a href="http://www.thinkwell.com/">ThinkWell</a>
<a href="http://wimba.com/">Wimba</a>

And a few more:
<a href="http://www.quia.com/">Quia</a>
<a href="http://www.blurb.com/">Blurb</a>
<a href="http://classjump.com/">Class Jump</a>
<a href="http://edublogs.org/">EduBlogs</a>
<a href="http://www.freereading.org/">FreeReading</a>
<a href="http://www.nextext.com/">Nextext</a>

As we learn to talk about Soomo, learn to describe it and contextualize, learn to surprise and reassure, we need to know professors often have a few of these folks in mind as they try to figure us out. And, in many ways, their marketing sites define the landscape in which we stand as we develop the site for <a href="http://soomopublishing.com">Soomo Publishing</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>What can we ask?</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/what-can-we-ask/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 20 May 2009 12:12:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=682</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Two days ago Seth reminded us <a href="http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2009/05/it-doesnt-hurt-to-ask.html">you can ask for too much too soon</a>.

What lesser requests can we make? Some we've asked in the past are:
- would you like to us to stay in touch, let you know what we create next?
- would you like to review?
- to contribute? (oddly, it's easier and less work to author than to adopt)
- to participate in a class test?
- in a focus group?
What else have invited people to do short of adopting?

Of course, there should always be an easy way for someone to say, "let's dispense with the baby steps -- I'm ready to adopt." But for everyone else, that is most people, offering something that makes it easy to say "yes," something worth surrendering their anonymity, is a big step in the right direction. The email address of someone who has opted in is worth many times the value of one who just happens to teach.

This is all about moving from "open to the idea" to "interested in trying out what Soomo is offering."

How might we invite people to start receiving value from us before they are ready to adopt?
- visit polisilo and, if it seems useful, subscribe
- attend a workshop at a conference that will help you even if you don't use us
- invite us to your campus or small conference to present a workshop
- request a free copy of the slides from our 10 things you couldn't do 10 years ago presentation
- request a free copy of our list of the 50 most useful sites for teaching political science
- request a free copy of our ebook: Creating Effective Web Assignments
- join our study group on best practices for teaching political science at distance
- add your blog to our list of blogs related to teaching and learning political science

What else could we do to
1) genuinely help profs teach and
2) find those people most open to trying new digital things?]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Cupcake! Stop!</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/cupcake-stop/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 20 May 2009 19:22:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=697</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[That is what you need to yell in New York City to get the mobile cupcake truck to woah it up and deliver you some goodness - Cupcake! Stop!
Apparently an NYU Law School grad realized that the job market was bleak and decided to take matters into their own hands. Volia - Cupcake!Stop! A modern culinary telegram?..cupcake!stop!

The coolest part, from a tech perspective - they are twittering their location so weak on the willpower New Yorkers can get a sugar hook up. http://twitter.com/CupcakeStop

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-698" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/cupcake-stop.jpg" alt="Cupcake Stop" width="446" height="310" />]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Changing the Rules</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/changing-the-rules/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 22 May 2009 12:33:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=702</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Tom recently yammered a link to this New Yorker Article by Malcolm Gladwell: <a href="http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/05/11/090511fa_fact_gladwell?printable=true">How David Beats Goliath</a>.

Spoiler Alert: <em>If you'd like to read the article, you might do so before reading further here. I'm posting it on a Friday because it's a good read and the weekend is upon us. The rest of this post will still be here on Tuesday....</em>

Gladwell talked at length about how a full court press in basketball is very effective but rarely used because it is so labor intensive. But through the full court press, a team with less talent, can win against taller, better shooting, more experienced players. By changing the way the game is played, a team can train for stamina and heart and prevent a team that trains for offensive plays and shooting from ever reaching their half of the court.

In the full-court press example and several others Gladwell uses, the underdog changes the rules of the game to take away the advantages of the stronger opponent. Soomo is changing some rules. Our sales efforts are surrendering the zone offense to the big publishers with 100's of reps, and instead going man-to-man. Our reach is shorter, but much more focused. They carry hundreds of books in dozens of disciplines. We carry three products in one discipline and support options the big two have never even considered. They will reach far more professors but very shallowly. They are Lands End. We are more like Joeseph at the men's clotheir in Laurel Park who knows my name and that I like Nat Nast.

We will reach out to far fewer profs but our close rate will be staggering. Where a traditional publisher needs only to provide sample copies and a follow up call, (I'm overgeneralizing a bit) we need to provide an entire training program. But the traditional publisher is playing for 5 out of 100 profs (any profs will do) while we are focusing only on those who've indicated an interest and very likely to see adoptions from 80 out of 100 interested.

More than an adoption, we're creating a tribe of contributors and innovatoers. While the big two sell once and are then pummelled by used books for three semesters before coming out with a resented "new" edition, we are selling once, receiving income over all four semesters and releasing welcomed new additions every six months. We're changing many rules. And that's our only hope. We can't out-textbook the textbooks. But if we choose a viable strategy and work it tirelessly, with relationship building from our first meeting through support during our eighth semester (I'm thinking Chapman here) we will win with our profs.

The most important thing I'm taking away from this article is not that we should work twice as many hours as a traditional rep. It's not about quantity of work. It's about a revolution; changing the rules of the game so that we are playing on our own terms. We have learned a ton in the past six months about these changes and what our natural advantages are. The army Gladwell describes was highly mobile. We are highly relational. The full court press meant the other team couldn't even in-bound the ball. For us, we're supporting profs from the moment their heads are turned by a digital option. We're helping them start up so smoothly that they will wonder why they haven't been teaching with the web all along.

This happened yesterday at Wake Tech. One of the professors Emily and I have met with three times (and Emily's met with him more) finally realized that "with this, I won't need to assign a textbook." And his eyes lit up. He looked liberated. He began encouraging Emily to please double check to make sure this is cool with the department chair because there was a time many years ago when he tried to drop the text and was scolded. He is feeling liberated today. He was open to our message when we walked in in January - we didn't persuade him. We just invited him and Emily has followed up faithfully. We've been working on his behalf for months now to get ready for a digital fall. And yesterday, it hit him. I can not imagine what a traditional publisher could say to pull him back right now. We do not have the majority of the professors at Wake Tech. But we have four with growing relationships, and deep commitments. I honestly don't think the big two can compete with that -- not with the profs who opt in to working with us. And I really think that when this product is done, more at Wake will join in. And after a successfull Fall, more will join in. And more at other community colleges around the state. Not all. Not everyone has problems we solve. But for all that do, we're going to hook up.

Gladwell begins with the question of how underdogs ever win. He ends with the conclusion that the giants play by rules and to slay them, you have to change the rules. We do not exist to bring down the big two. I hope they continue to solve problems well for professors everywhere for many years to come. But we are doing something different -- and we are doing a lot of things differently. Our aspiration is not to become ever more like the traditional giants, but to create an ever stronger version of ourselves, understanding how to find our people, bring them in, support them well, and build realtionships that are virtually unbreakable. This is how we usher in the next age. This is how we rejuvinate out-of-class education. This is how we extend to students an invitation to wake up, see, care, engage and participate. This is our strategy for revolution.]]></content:encoded>

It's consistent with a business philosophy which has been proven time and again:  Irrespective of actions of your competitors, determine your own strengths, commit to them, tack as necessary, and stay the primary course.  Then, let your competitors worry about you.]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>Blue Monster</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/blue-monster/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 May 2009 12:30:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=705</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Gaping Void humbly offers a vision of the future of marketing<a href="http://www.gapingvoid.com/Moveable_Type/archives/004705.html"> here.</a> <em>(I'm just referencing the very top post -- down to the "But what if I fail?" cartoon, no further.</em>)

What I think Hugh is saying is that he found the heart of what motivated many people at Microsoft, and created a succinct statement of that attitude. He gave it the form and feel of a tribal totem (in the Seth Godin sense of tribe) so it could easily be an email signature, a bumper sticker, t-shirt or poster. It embodied the sentiment of the tribe.

What would be the blue monster for our professors? What drives our tribe? Would it be "Change the world or go home"?
Would it be "use the web or retire"?
"Fine, don't pay me. I'm going to teach well anyway."
"Time to ensure the future of democracy"

What would their slogan be?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Mantra</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/kawasaki-on-the-art-of-innovation/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 29 May 2009 12:53:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=708</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://blog.guykawasaki.com/">Guy Kawasaki</a> gave <a href="http://itc.conversationsnetwork.org/shows/detail1867.html">the keynote address at mySQL</a> last year hitting on some of his favorite topics. A good listen. Lot's of relevance for us right now.

In his 2nd point he suggests each organization needs to know it's mantra.

The corporate mission statement of Wendy's is:
<blockquote>To deliver superior quality products and serivces for our customers and communities through leadership, innovation and partnerships.</blockquote>
But this can't really drive effort on a daily basis. They would get more mileage out of a mantra such as: "Healthy Fast Food."

FedEx's mantra should be "Piece of Mind." That's what they really provide. It explains much of their behavior.

He raises the point so that we'll think about it. Why do we exist? In 2-3 words, why do we appeal to professors? To students? What is our mantra, or what should it be?

Some candidates to get the ball rolling:
Easy, reliable web.
We get you online.
Better web assignments.
Cool political videos.
Reliable web stuff.
My custom course.
Cheap book replacement.
Useful web stuff.
Rich digital textbooks.
Content and questions.

How would a professor summarize us to a friend? Soomo...
lets me customize
gives me web assignments
does cool interviews
finds nifty links
hooks my students
...what would they say?

What should we be saying in the first breath? What should we be thinking? What's our thesis?

If the answer is "We help professors use the web" then we know distributing materials that help them do in-class exercises isn't really our gig. If the answer is "Changing the way people teach" then we probably shouldn't redistribute anything a prof makes unless we confirm that it fits with our vision.

What do you see as viable candidates for our mantra?]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Screencasts</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/screencasts-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 26 May 2009 12:30:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=720</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[<em>This one is really wide - you might want to stretch your browser window.</em>]

Things has a lovely home page and a small but unambigious icon linking to their screencast.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-721" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/screencast.jpg" alt="screencast" width="977" height="340" />

Jute's screencast has chapters, which provide something of an outline as well as a means of navigation. Might work well for an overview of Soomo.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-722" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/jute-intro.jpg" alt="Jute intro" width="830" height="562" />

Apple handles this in a different way (and with so much style) by breaking the clips up into very short segments and requiring you to select which one is next. I like that I can see the duration of each before I click. This might work well for "how to" videos: how to edit, review grades, create an assignment, etc.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-723" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/apple-quick-tips.jpg" alt="Apple quick tips" width="1004" height="614" />

While it carries less data, this is by far the most attractive. Incredible images. Sparse layout. This is an inviting way to post our case studies of professors.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-724" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/apple-developer-connection-worldwide-developers-conference-2009-iphone.jpg" alt="Apple Developer Connection - Worldwide Developers Conference 2009 - iPhone" width="1024" height="586" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Staying in Touch</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/staying-in-touch/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 28 May 2009 12:41:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=730</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<em>More screen shots -- broaden your browser!</em>

These are some interesting ways sites are seeking to stay in touch with folks.

If you're a fan of this site you know it by the time you get to the bottom of the home page. Here's the answer to the question of "how can I stay up to date on all you're doing?" Several options so you can use the one that fits your style.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-732" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/follow-us1.jpg" alt="follow us" />

37Signals knows if you're reading the case studies there's a chance you want to be in one. So they fish for leads right on that page. Tell us why we should tell the world about you. What makes you special?

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-733" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/let-us-know.jpg" alt="Let us know" width="679" height="194" />

Cultured Code gives a little more weight than most to the "opt-in to our newsletter" step. This is a friendly little screen, already filled in for me. It's easy, respectful and inviting. And again, I get my choice of email, or other means of being contacted.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-734" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/stay-in-touch-with-cultured-code.jpg" alt="stay in touch with cultured code" width="517" height="346" />

Imagine coming back to <em>Americans Governing</em> after a summer (or a semester) off from teaching to find a banner announcement describing our improvements and new content. Right when they need to know (upon log-in) we can share this information with them. I also really like the option to join the beta team. Letting users decide if they want new stuff sooner, or only rock-solid stuff. No matter which way I go, I'm thankful for the opportunity.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-735" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/we_ve-changed-annc.jpg" alt="we_ve changed annc" width="747" height="475" />

One idea that's come up lately is asking professors before the semester starts to either 1) verify your course information to make sure it's accurate in the store or 2) please remove your course from the store if you aren't going to use it. This will let us know when someone thinks they're using it but isn't successfully getting students to sign up. As opposed to someone who was just checking it out. And if we add an option to give us feedback when you opt out, we might learn something.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-736" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/05/why-not-survey.jpg" alt="why not survey" width="571" height="408" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>730</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-05-28 07:41:47</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-05-28 12:41:47</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>staying-in-touch</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="marketing"><![CDATA[Marketing]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="site-enhancements"><![CDATA[Site Enhancements]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="social-marketing"><![CDATA[Social Marketing]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[25]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[25]]></wp:meta_value>
