			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[25]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[25]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Number One in a Growing Market</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/06/number-one-in-a-growing-market/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 01 Jun 2009 12:13:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=741</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It is well within our reach to be the single best digital textbook replacement in American Government. In fact, we may well achieve that distinction this fall with the KTR deal. CourseSmart has many more titles available for American government (80?) but at higher prices and with no new media. FlatWorld is threatening to release free ones (sort of) at some point, but nothing yet. Cengage is releasing through ichapters but again no new media included.

So today we may be number one in a very small market. Now we need to grow that market radically.

Previously I asked how many professors are
- eager teachers ready to try a promising alternative OR
- looking for ways to save their students money OR
- have been building digital stuff and see this as an easier way OR
- are not digital at all and see this as an easy way to become so?

These are our people. How do we get to them? What would it take for it to be true that every professor knew enough about us to know that we are the market leader, offering something very interesting, and likely the way things will go?

To get to that point, we might need to ensure that our titles:
- are well known in political science
- are widely regarded as the best available digital content
- are known as the easiest to use and best supported
- include collections for many political science courses

What else should be on that list? And what can we do to make them all true?]]></content:encoded>

Pearson custom, the largest college publisher will not bother to talk to anyone or help anyone unless they have a minimum enrollment of 300 students a semester. Your conversation today with Dr. Bohrer regarding working on helping with customizing his Eastern European Politics course is a fine example of how we are truly different in our approach to taking care of customer's needs.

Your willingness to work with Sally Anderson, develop her International Development course for a trial summer to make sure she is happy before adopting for fall is another stunning example.

These are thee types of projects which really make me happy I'm at Soomo!]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>Evangelizing</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/06/evangelizing/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Jun 2009 12:50:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=744</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.techsmith.com/company/management.asp#sectiona-3">Betsy Weber </a>is an evangelist for <a href="http://www.techsmith.com/">TechSmith</a>, a software company. She recently gave <a href="http://www.eventbrite.com/event/317286011">a talk</a> for the <a href="http://www.theswom.org/">Society of Word of Mouth</a>. I purchased access, listened <a href="http://swom.na3.acrobat.com/p17669057/">here</a>, and took the following notes.

[<em>NOTE: She calls herself an evangelist and her main job is creating evangelists from users. To disambiguate the two uses of the term, I'm going to call the evangelical users "fans."</em> ]

Essential to creating fans:
- you have to have a great product to create evangelists
- and everywhere you connect with a customer you have to be awesome

We already had fans. One of my jobs is to make sure we hear from these people, and vice versa.

My job is to create deep, ongoing customer relationships.

What's in it for the customer?
- They get a voice and thus a stake.
- Many of these people have become my friends.
- We don't promise anything, but every now and then we do something remarkable.

These relationships lead to some interesting projects with our fans.
They tend to be opinion leaders and mention us.

How do I do this?
- communicate with customers, lots and lots of email
- go where people are talking about us; virtually and otherwise [for them it's twitter, blogs, facebook, flickr, digg, etc]
- share what I hear internally - the team needs to know what the world is saying
- share the stories of your fans with the world
- break bread and drink coffee with people
- forums, advisory boards, meet ups - any possible face time
- invite people to your office - virtually or physically
- give freely and often - help your fans know the product, free training, support, etc
- exclusive info to followers [preview APSA interviews, one per month, before all are released]
- swag - a way to show your allegiance to the tribe
- write thank you notes

Measuring Success
- [adoptions]
- links, comments, people who ask for stuff [shirts, DVDs]

Characteristics of an Evangelist
- personality open to connecting with people
- creative in seeking solutions for people
- power listener -- more listening than talking
- love what the product enables, the customers, and the products -- you should use them because you like them
- some willingness to help with tech problems, some curiosity
- juggler -- lot's of people working on their schedule, not yours

This is not a quick fix. It's long term. It's about building relationship and trust. This is not marketing or sales. We don't run campaigns. It doesn't happen over night.

What not to do:
- don't outsource
- don't go part time
- don't go big (start small and focused)
- don't go lightly (take seriously the need to help your fans succeed)
- don't forget you audience (all about making your customers happy)]]></content:encoded>

		<title>How can I see my students&#039; work?</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/how-can-i-see-my-students-work/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 May 2009 14:01:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=755</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[More than one professor asked, upon having signed up, "how will I see the work of my students?" Tom put the screencast on using the notebook right into the blank notebook. So now when a professor has just created a course, but doesn't have any students yet, she'll see explanation including this video. Once a student signs up, this goes away, to be replaced by actual students and their work. Very nice.

To see it in action: <a href="http://americansgoverning.com/testdrive">click here</a> &gt; then on <strong>test drive</strong> &gt; then on <strong>notebook</strong>.

	<item>
		<title>Maybe twitter?</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/05/maybe-twitter/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 May 2009 15:12:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=759</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Interesting story about the power of twitter for direct marketing from Guy Kawasaki, master internet marketing exploiter.

<a href="http://blogs.openforum.com/author/guykawasaki">Guy Kawasaki of How to Change the World</a> <span><span><span> </span></span></span>

In a few years, people may read this posting and wonder, What was Guy worried about? (Remember when Googles sponsored links were a crime against humanity?) However, in the near future, many people will scream bloody murder that I am going to ruin Twitter by telling you about a service called <a href="http://www.twitterhawk.com/">Twitterhawk</a>.

So be it.

Twitterhawk is a real-time, targeted-marketing toolor the ultimate spam machine. First, let me tell you why Im telling you about it: Because it can help you use Twitter as a marketing tool. Second, let me tell you how it works. You create keyword searches like what you can do at <a href="http://search.twitter.com/">Search.Twitter.com</a>. For example:
<ul>
	<li><a href="http://search.twitter.com/search?q=fashionweek">Fashionweek</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://search.twitter.com/search?q=homeschooling">Homeschooling</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://search.twitter.com/search?q=+seo+near%3A94301+within%3A50mi">SEO within 50 miles of 94031</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://search.twitter.com/search?q=&amp;ands=&amp;phrase=&amp;ors=audi&amp;nots=&amp;tag=&amp;lang=en&amp;from=&amp;to=&amp;ref=&amp;near=94301&amp;within=50&amp;units=mi&amp;since=&amp;until=&amp;rpp=15%E2%80%9D%29%20to%20monitor%20people%20talking%20about%20%E2%80%9CSEO%E2%80%9D%20within%20fifty%20miles%20of%20Palo%20Alto%E2%80%99s%20ZIP%20code,94031">Audi within 50 miles of 94031</a></li>
</ul>
Then you compose up to five responses to the tweets that it finds for each search condition and schedule the search intervals. An Audi dealer in Palo Alto, for example, can use this to find sales or maintenance prospects on Twitter. Twitterhawk will then tweet your responses for when it finds the right keywords in the right area.

Essentially this is a way to monitor public conversations for keywords without being the NSA while Dick Cheney was running things. In other words, this is as good as it gets for targeted marketing. The closet analogy I can think of is how Gmail searches your email and inserts ads based on the words it finds in your messages.

<span> </span>

This is when the panic ensues: Holy kaw, if many people started using Twitterhawk, it would mean the death of Twitter as a means of social networking and communication! Let me tell you why this isnt true:
<ol>
	<li>Twitterhawk charges $.05 for each tweet that it sends. What spammer can afford to pay $.05/tweet in order to ask you to help get money out of Nigeria or to sell you penis-enlargement products? By the way, Twitterhawk tracks how many times people clicked on the link, so that you can determine your per click cost.</li>
	<li>There is a blacklist of terms that Twitterhawk will not respond to. I dont know whats on the list, but I suspect words like the are probably on it to prevent too many matches.</li>
	<li>There is a limit of twelve fully-automatic tweets per day per search. At this rate, it will take a long time to find someone to help get money out of Nigeria or a man who wants to get his aforementioned penis enlarged.</li>
	<li>You cannot send the same person more than one tweet based on the same search. This means that the Audi dealer cannot send you a tweet every time you mention the word Audi. The dealer gets one shot at you.</li>
	<li>You can edit each outgoing tweet when you set Twitterhawk to manual approval. This means that you can use Twittehawk to find tweets to respond to and queue them up for individual answers. (The reason to manually approve each tweet is that you wouldnt want to send a tweet such as Were an Audi dealer located in Palo Alto. Wed love your business, in response to a tweet like, Im so glad I just sold my 1970 Audi. Its given me nothing but trouble.</li>
</ol>
At this price and at this rate, Twitterhawk is hardly a spam tool. It is, however, a very powerful marketing tool if you use it sparingly and precisely. The Audi dealer, for example, might find that it sent out 100 tweets at a total cost of $5 and got one oil change customer out of it. Thats probably worth itparticularly if the customer returns for more expensive work or buys a car.

Looking at it another way: How else can you find people within driving distance of your dealership who are interested in Audis? Radio, TV, and newspaper advertising? Dont make me laugh. Its certainly worth tryingalthough, in truth, you can try Twitter targeted-direct marketing without Twitterhawk by simply using Twitters search capability or most Twitter clients anyway.

I close with an interesting story. When I first heard of Twitterhawk, I went nuts and set up searches for mentions of text like Fashionweek which resulted in automatic tweets to visit <a href="http://fashion.alltop.com/">Fashion.alltop</a>. After sending a few thousand tweets like this (perhaps TwitterHawk created the twelve/day limit in my honor!), my @alltop account was suspended, so Ive cooled it. Clearly, there is some danger in pushing the edge of marketing, and Im figuring that out too.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>759</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>maybe-twitter</wp:post_name>

	<item>
		<title>Core Value</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/06/core-value/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 05 Jun 2009 12:12:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=715</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>What would it take for someone to out soomo soomo?</strong>
If a digital text that was even cheaper came out, would we be undone? What if someone came out with something much richer, but not customizable? Or 100's of high-end original videos but a cover price of $125? If Pearson released an all-digital product for $50 in partnership with CNN video? If Amazon offered every textbook in print on the Kindle DX? Wikipedia's free textbooks?

<strong>A related question is: What need do we really fill well? </strong>
Assume there will be many digital textbooks for political science. Amidst 12 of them, what would you most want to distinguish our offering? By teachers for teachers. Easiest to customize. Simplest. Best original video. Most current. Most niche TOCs. Best service and support. The most content. Just the content you need. Cheapest. Most respected advisers and authors. Coolest t-shirts at APSA.

On what vector does our real value lie?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>51</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Dan]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>dhb@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://dhb@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>12.150.140.156</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2009-06-05 09:31:32</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-06-05 14:31:32</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[David's comments and questions are strikingly relevant.   Success in any business requires that the "What if?" questions be boldly asked, and answered, day after day.

When a group of entrepreneurs like Soomo is racing to bring innovation and excellence into the marketplace, we must be ever mindful that the competition has similar goals.   Most of our competitors are large, long-established publishing companies and "Amazons" with virtually unlimited resources.  That fact requires us to concentrate on our strengths:  Innovation, speed, having Raving Fan service support and the insatiable desire and ability to create superior content which inspires teacher and student.

Back in April, I made a comment which becomes more and more relevant as the competitive landscape changes:  "There are three personal characteristics which must be present to assure long-term business success:  Integrity, humility and a sense of urgency."   While each is necessary, that one about "sense of urgency" jumps out at us today.

It's great to have team members like you!]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>Unfettered</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/06/unfettered/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 08 Jun 2009 12:17:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=752</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Steve Heller's <a href="http://blog.printmag.com/dailyheller/2009/05/25/VintageInteriors.aspx">recent post</a> celebrated what is p0ssible when designers are given freedom and license to do great work. We are in a similar situation as we invent what comes next in tools for learning. Interface, graphics, key functions, short documentaries, conveying the facts, enabling a sense of mastery; providing the customized, localized and current; connecting instructors to students and students to others learning in this course, across campus and across the country.

Someday there will be glacier-like genres of "how everybody does this." But we have a chance to 1) influence what becomes the standard and 2) create some phenomenal work before compromise and half-steps water it all down.

These magazine covers from the 50's still look extraordinary to designers (their target audience) five decades later. Let's make some of that.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Apture</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/06/apture/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 04 Jun 2009 12:31:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=778</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.apture.com/">Apture</a> explains itself in <a href="http://blip.tv/file/1036840">this screencast</a>. Their tagline is "add multimedia to your website in one click."

Once you've installed Apture, you can access it on any page on your site. Select text while Apture is enabled, and apture assumes you want to search on that phrase. Further, it makes some assumptions about the few sites you are most likely wanting to search: youtube, flicker, wikipedia, amazon, etc. Click again to preview the media, and again to add it into your page. That's it. Three clicks and you never left your page.

That's pretty cool all by itself. What does it mean for us?

Our goal is solidifying as "<strong>we help you use the web</strong>." It would be more accurate to say "<em>we help college instructors to use the web to more effectively educate</em>" but what the shorter version lacks in nuance it makes up for in punch.

Finding and integrating other tools, such as apture, vimeo, or blogs may be central to what we do. Not everyone (not anyone?) will want them all. But by making it easy to find good tools, easy to think about how to use them well, and actually making it easy to use them, we more fully achieve our goal -- "we help you use the web."

Making the web easy to use in teaching will sometimes mean building our own (e.g. blog) and other times just means leveraging (single sign on with Blackboard).

For the content we build, we probably wouldn't use Apture much as it conflicts with out commitment to "have as much as possible local." But for a professor creating an assignment, it might be a superb way to create very rich assignments quickly. What phenomenal case studies could be created by permitting profs to build their own pages with this tool. If you're going to reference Johnson, or Tip or Cokie, include some video, audio or at least an image. For a Jocelyn or Chapman, this would lead to richer assignments in much less time.

Apture's usefulness is tied to the credibility of web media. If you don't find wikipedia or user posted video credible, you might not use it much. In poli sci it might be most useful in citing mainstream press and sound bites of politicians.

Or perhaps we can cobble together a mash up with google scholar to create a tool for just-in-time research, affordances that enable professors to learn while they write, with rich assignments remaining as a useful residue. Maybe we can spec which sites it searches so that the Apture "media browser" becomes the Soomo "scholarship browser" when searching from one of our authoring pages. Highlight the name of a country and you'll see a list of credible sources for maps of that country and information about it. Highlight the name of a Poli Sci scholars and see links to journal articles and books by this person.

Maybe we can permit student use of Apture to create well-sourced multimedia essays and responses. This would require students to evaluated sites for credibility and put them behind the scenes of constructing multi-media arguments so they can discover you can string a series of clips together to make any case you'd like.

The genius of Apture appears to be that while you are writing web content you can search, find and embed related web content without code. And your reader can see a "rich link" (preview screen shot) and often view in page or after the jump with additional functionality. That's a new way (for me) to use the web. And whether we ever connect with Apture or not, it's worth noting and thinking about for how it might help instructors and students.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Customer service to apire to.</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/06/customer-service-to-apire-to/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 05 Jun 2009 10:30:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=780</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Zappos.com has legendary customer service. I have never needed it but word on the street is that they do a lot of great stuff that is over the top. They sell shoes and other stuff but mostly shoes. They have a 365 day return policy - for shoes!

Anyway, some internet marketing geek did a live chat with Zappos support under the pseudonym 'Timmy'. The transcript tells the rest of the story - really funny, sort of bizarre but most of all, a great demonstration of the Zappos attitude by the customer service rep. Enjoy.
<div>

The narration is from the marketing guy at <a href="http://www.sitelead.com/blog/zappos-live-chat/2009/06/01">Todd's Blog </a>

Zappos is known for serviceand for letting their service agents be themselves. I put this to the test tonight and threw a curveball or two at the guy helping me in a Live Chat. I used the name Timmy as my alias and asked a totally random question about a random product. See actual chat log below. Zappos rocks! I could not even make this stuff up, I swear.

You are now chatting with Jonathan
Jonathan: Hello Timmy. How can I help you?
Timmy: do you know how wide the G-Shock Atomic Solar - AWG101 SKU #7403774 is?
Timmy: i mean, how big a wrist it would fit?
Timmy: Timmy has a big fat wrist
Timmy: Timmy need watch grande
Jonathan: Ill see what I can find out for Timmy.
Timmy: awesome. and can we please continue to talk about Timmy in the 3rd person? Timmy likes to boost Timmys ego by talking about Timmy that way
Jonathan: Jonathan would be happy to neglect the use of pronouns for the duration of this conversation.
Timmy: Jonathan and Timmy shall get along just fine
Jonathan: Will Timmy be able to measure Timmys wrist?
Timmy: Timmys wrist is big, but not Biggie-Smalls big. Timmy doesnt have the required measurement instruments.
Timmy: Timmy is 64 220lbs if that helps Jonathan
Jonathan: Luckily, that is roughly the size of Jonathans brother, so that does help.
Jonathan: Jonathan thinks that this watch will work out well for Timmy. The watchs circumference is 9 inches, so it will probably fit around Timmys wrist.
Timmy: Ok cool
Timmy: Do your watches and stuff have free return shipping like your Zapatos?
Timmy: in case Timmy wants another one or something
Jonathan: And if it doesnt work out, as long as the watch is in its original condition and in the original packaging, Timmy has 365 days to return Timmys order. We will even pay for the return shipping! As always, our shipping to Timmy will be free.
Timmy: Timmy thanks Jonathan for good help
Jonathan: Jonathan welcomes Timmy.
Jonathan: Its Jonathans pleasure!
Jonathan: Can Jonathan do anything more for Timmy?
Timmy: no that is all timmy needs
Timmy: timmy happy
Jonathan: Good. Does Timmy have an account se up with Zappos yet?
Jonathan: Jonathan will upgrade Timmys account.
Timmy: yes timmy is repeat shopper
Timmy: but Timmy is my alter ego and not my actual name
Jonathan: Well, what is Timmys email address? Ill hook you up.
Timmy: Timmy has placed orders using txxxxxx@gmail.com in the past
Jonathan: Alright TODD!
Jonathan: :)
Jonathan: Im going to upgrade your account to VIP status! This will ensure that all future orders go out with 1-business day shipping free of charge!
Just place your future orders at <a href="http://vip.zappos.com/">http://vip.zappos.com</a>.
Timmy: Timmy Likey!
Jonathan: Good. Good
Jonathan: Let Jonathan know if there is anything else that Jonathan can do for Timmy.
Timmy: Ok, Timmy ok now. Timmy time to go shopping!
Jonathan: Have fun!</div>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I hate getting behind on Shoebox because I learn so much and am always left with so much to think about and apply after using it. What I love about this string is the ease with which the employee just falls into the groove with his faceless customer. A former dear boss and mentor used the term "unconditional positive regard" when talking about how an editor deals with authors. That phrase has always stuck with me. 			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Hmmm...moving fast w/ coffee this am. Do we use blogs? Well, in this case...yes.]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>Disrupting the Market</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/06/disrupting-the-market/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 10 Jun 2009 12:17:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=775</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This (terse and rather hideous) <a href="http://www.12manage.com/methods_christensen_disruptive_innovation.html">summary of a key argument</a> from <em>The Innovator's Dilemma</em> is interesting for us. It points out that traditional businesses will, reasonably, continue to cater to their core customers, adding ever more value. Meanwhile the disrupters come underneath, initially offering less value and finding a following among those customers least likely to be high-profit core customers of the traditional providers.
<blockquote>By doing what good companies are supposed to do - cater to their most profitable customers and focus investments where profit margins are most attractive - established industry leaders are on a path of Sustaining Innovations and leave themselves open for disruptive technologies to bury them. This happens because the resource allocation processes of established companies are designed to maximize profits through sustaining innovations, which essentially involve designing better and better mousetraps for existing customers or proven market segments. When Disruptive Innovations (typically cheaper, simpler to use versions of existing products that target low-end or entirely new customers) emerge, established companies are paralyzed. They are almost always motivated to go up-market rather than to defend these new or low-end markets, and ultimately the disruptive innovation improves, steals more market share, and replaces the reigning product.</blockquote>
In other words, huge, must-have-the-book adoptions are the best customers for traditional publishers and the worst for us. Our best options are likely those who are already on the fence, not using a text, not caring about the text, doing their own reader, etc. These people are looking for an alternative.

And as we grow on the strength of these early adoptions, we become ever more functional to an ever broader group, ultimately providing something new that meets most needs for most people. We do this without ever out-textbooking the textbooks. But by doing something else that ultimately does what textbooks are purchased to do, in a different but better way.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>785</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-06-10 07:17:59</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-06-10 12:17:59</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>disrupting-the-market</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>

Of that, $3B is represented by those who are using customized product, no product or product that students are not buying because they have found work- arounds to buying expensive texts.  $3B!!!  It's ours for the taking.  Okay, at least a part of it is.  So go forth and disrupt!]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>Seth&#039;s Rant Against Textbooks</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/06/seths-rant-against-textbooks/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 14 Jun 2009 21:16:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=795</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2009/06/textbook-rant.html">Today's post</a> is remarkably relevant.

The problem seems plain to all who look, including students, professors and publishers. But the solution is evading everyone. Why has Seth's solution not come to pass? What would it take to create a book that teaches like gifted instructors do? Like O'Reilly books do? Like NPR does?

The challenge is clear. The opportunity enormous. We have a head start on the product, but we're not done developing and we're just beginning to figure out the sales and marketing that will enable the revolution. Here we go...]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[[Update: got more mail about this post than any other post ever. People pointed to Flatworld and to Quirk, and so far, more than 94% of the letters aggressively agree with me. Most of the people are either students, parents of students, former students or other disgruntled customers that are tired of being ripped off by a senseless, broken system. I also heard from a handful of people who said that I was jealous, that the union won't permit the system to change, that textbooks are really good, that professors are underpaid, that professors are too busy or (possibly and) that I'm delusional. I'll note that not one of these letters came from a textbook user.]

Hi David, not sure if you have seen the update Seth posted referencing Flatworld and Quirk....while we do not publish marketing e-materials...I still think it would be good for you to post something about Soomo and our mission for students in the Humanities?!]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>An Inside Look</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/06/an-inside-look/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 19 Jun 2009 12:31:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=798</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I like the tone of <a href="http://toc.oreilly.com/2009/06/inside-look-at-rands-995-ebook.html">this piece</a> -- giving you a behind the scenes look at our thinking. It's a nice way to market with an educational voice.

It begins:
<blockquote>Recently, the <a href="http://www.rand.org/">RAND Corporation</a> announced that it has revised the suggested retail pricing on all RAND ebooks to $9.95 each. RAND ebooks are available through a wide variety of wholesale and retail partners.

The <a href="http://www.rand.org/news/press/2009/06/01/">press release</a> provided some explanation for the decision, also discussed in <a href="http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA6662061.html?industryid=47152">Publishers Weekly</a>. I have been asked by Tools of Change to provide some additional insight into our ebook pricing strategy.

There were several things that went into our thinking on, as one of my colleagues appropriately called it, this "new math." Some of these factors will generally not apply to other publishers, though I do believe some factors should, and eventually will, affect other publishers' pricing strategies as well.</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Ubertrends Blog</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/07/ubertrends-blog/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jul 2009 14:32:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=810</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This is one of the richest blogs I have seen in a long time.  Really well written and researched posts.  Visually impressive too.  I like how the top two stories are full width but the next few older are in a two column format.

<img src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/07/ubertrends-tracking-the-future-of-the-consumer-lifestyle.jpg" alt="Ubertrends | Tracking the future of the consumer lifestyle" width="917" height="801" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-811" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Soomo on Rails</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/09/soomo-on-rails/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Sep 2009 02:30:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=822</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The sprint for APSA was remarkable and resulted in an unprecedented number of projects running successfully in parallel. At times I felt like our speed was taking a toll on our chassis -- that we just weren't built to go that fast -- and it was exhilarating.

But I need to admit that at times, I failed to get input from key people or failed to facilitate complete handoffs between team members. I created fires we didn't need and overlooked key work that had been done.

I despise unnecessary process as death to productivity and internal systems too often become obstacles to doing good work in the world outside our walls -- and as an organization, we do nothing of any consequence until it impacts a life outside of our organization.

But it may be time to put some very lightweight, simple process into the organization, to allow us to go even faster. Let's consider a light, fast model for project-based organization.

1) Projects shall have a name -- and a place in basecamp. Just listing all our current projects could be dizzying -- and that's a warning sign that we might be trying to do too much. This week we'll be listing them all, in basecamp, and getting a sense for what it is we are really undertaking in the days and weeks ahead.

2) Projects shall have an owner. We have no projects that can be completed solo -- at the very least everything needs a second set of eyes before shipping. And we have exceptional teamwork and inter-reliability. But I've been slack about who owns what and that leads to confusion and disappointment. So each project going into basecamp needs an owner.

3) Projects shall have stakeholders. People who are keenly aware of the needs a project meets, the work required to to complete the project, the validity of the project output or how we build this particular thing, are stakeholders. Other opinions are welcome and other people will be involved. But the stakeholders should be formally named and met with at least three times:
- in a kick off meeting to define the needs and goals of the project
- in a design review meeting to discuss the solution we propose to build
- in a project review meeting to look at what was built and raise any concerns before it goes live.
There may be other meetings as needed, but at the least, these three.

4) Projects need a calendar. At the least, this is the day it will be done. There may be interim milestones as well, but at the very least knowing the day it will be done will give us enough structure to know what we are committed to and for how long.

That's about the least I think we can do and call our workflow project oriented. There will be an increase in meetings but it should be more than offset by an increase in communication and a formal sharing of knowledge rather than ad hoc and ill timed. And there will be a reduction in flexibility, but this should be offset by the gift of focus -- of being able to know what we are working on in a given day and a reduction in an unpredictable meteor shower of sudden crises decimating less formal goals.

At worst, we're going corporate. But at best, we're putting some titanium struts on our rail buggy so we can double our speed on hard flat sand. Fill the keg with fuel and let's see how fast she'll go.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/09/railbuggy.jpg" alt="railbuggy.jpg" border="0" width="440" height="388" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Lots o&#039; Projects</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/09/lots-o-projects/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 16 Sep 2009 11:59:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=825</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[After one full day of project-based workflow, there are already some interesting things to see. One is, not surprisingly, we have a lot of projects going on. We already did, of course, but this makes it more explicit.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-826" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/09/projectlist.jpg" alt="projectlist" width="219" height="454" />

To sort through this list, DP suggested leading the names of the projects with his name -- which creates a kind of implied two column layout, makes it easier for him to see his own projects and will mean that in the Monday crunch all his updates will be groups together.

Kathi points the way to a similar strategy by building a set of projects which begin with "Troy." Again this categorizes, makes them easy to find, and groups reporting.

It will be interesting to see how our management of this list continues to mature. (And to see if anyone other than DP can figure out how to get cool stars into their project names...)]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Stakeholding</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/09/stakeholding/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 16 Sep 2009 12:07:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=828</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Another insight from yesterday was seeing the stakeholder meeting really work. It's a simple task to take a moment to reflect, "who all will be interested in the outcome of this project?" but it's something I, for one, am not in the habit of asking.

One example yesterday was a leeeeengthy four-person planning session on our fall email campaign. Then we added three people to the mix to talk about it with everyone at the table, and things shifted. Substantially. I would have sworn we had a good plan but by taking another 30-60 minutes to talk to all interested parties, the plan matured and strengthened. Had we skipped that conversation, we would have found these weaknesses later, on an ad hoc basis, after building some momentum toward off-target goals. I won't go so far as to say it was fun to have yet another lengthy conversation or to adjust our plan. But I will say I am deeply grateful that we took the time to align all the parties and will be building on a much stronger foundation as a result.

So far I'm seeing stakeholder meetings as getting more collective issues out on the table, building broader and deeper consensus to our plans for fall and increasing cross-functional understanding of our projects. (That sounds jargony -- I mean 'more people know what all is going on.')

Finally, we're seeing how blurry the edges of many efforts; how interconnected we are. The sales team is planning an effort to promote new content, which needs to first be developed by editorial, then reviewed by editorial, which needs sales to help find the reviewers and tech to help make reviewing easier. Lots of interconnections. And this shouldn't be surprising, but it's another benefit to gather all stakeholders at once.

I'm glad we have a really nice speakerphone!

Looking forward to day two.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Getting Things Done</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/09/getting-things-done/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 17 Sep 2009 12:25:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=830</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[After rejecting the idea of sending everyone a copy of <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Getting-Things-Done-Stress-Free-Productivity/dp/0142000280/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&amp;s=books&amp;qid=1252893176&amp;sr=8-1">David Allen's book</a>, or setting aside time each Monday to talk about Getting Things Done (GTD), I'm now thinking I should share these thoughts in the most passive (least obnoxious) way possible. So I'll make a few posts to shoebox.

This is not because we are in any way failing to get things done. Quite the opposite. We're doing so much that I felt I needed help keeping up with my promises and priorities. (see ProjectPath) I dug back in to GTD and found, yet again, some really useful stuff. Since it helped me, I'm inclined to share.

GTD is a set of specific strategies for dealing with your personal workflow. It assumes more things land on your desk or in your in-box than you can deal with and offers some techniques to manage that flow.

The goal of GTD is, unsurprisingly, to get things done. But the underlying strategy is surprising -- the techniques are focused on freeing your mind from the dull ache of constantly being aware of all the things you need to do <em>but are not currently doing</em>. [But "quit thinking about all you are not doing right now" is not as catchy as "getting things done."

The guiding principle, in a nutshell: assume you are holding in your head all of the commitments you've made to yourself and others along with every meeting you have this week, everything you need to pick up at the store next time you go, and buckets of other things you've been meaning to do. All this stuff is eating your brain. If you can just get it out of your head and into a "trusted system" then your mind can relax and get productive.

For example, if you have an overwhelming number of appointments this week (or, say, at APSA) you might start to freak. But if you write them all in your calendar, and you trust your calendar, and you trust yourself to regularly look at your calendar, then you can relax and just "be here now" without constantly running the list of things to not forget. At that point, your calendar has become a "trusted system."

<a href="http://www.davidco.com/what_is_gtd.php">As David Allen puts it</a>:
<blockquote>"Implementing GTD alleviates the feeling of overwhelm, instills confidence, and releases a flood of creative energy. It provides structure without constraint, managing details with maximum flexibility. The system rigorously adheres to the core principles of productivity, while allowing tremendous freedom in the "how." The only "right" way to do GTD is getting meaningful things done with truly the least amount of invested attention and energy."</blockquote>
He lists four key strategies:
<blockquote>* Capturing anything and everything that has your attention
* Defining actionable things discretely into outcomes and concrete next steps
* Organizing reminders and information in the most streamlined way, in appropriate categories, based on how and when you need to access them
* Keeping current and "on your game" with appropriately frequent reviews of the six horizons of your commitments (purpose, vision, goals, areas of focus, projects, and actions)</blockquote>
And the book is an explication and exploration of this workflow, which is simpler than it looks:
<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/09/gtd.gif" border="0" alt="gtd.gif" width="350" height="419" /></div>
If you're interested in knowing more, lets talk. Or check out the book or one of the many GTD resources:
Perhaps the premier GTD blog: <a href="http://www.43folders.com/">43Folders</a> (This is <a href="http://www.43folders.com/2004/09/08/getting-started-with-getting-things-done">a good first post</a>)

Lifehacker has a <a href="http://lifehacker.com/tag/gtd/">special section</a> for such posts.

GTD <a href="http://www.gtdtimes.com/2009/09/10/gtd-and-the-sales-pipeline/#more-2114">applied to sales</a>.

A <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qo7vUdKTlhk">45 minute video overview </a>by David Allen, at Google in 2007.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>830</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-09-17 07:25:09</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-09-17 12:25:09</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>getting-things-done</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	<item>
		<title>Yammer</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/yammer/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 02 Oct 2009 11:35:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=837</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Good times to yammer:

- when something just happened and you feel the urge to tell someone

- when you experience some small success (or frustration)

- when you hear something worth repeating<!--more-->

- when you come across a link that needs to be shared

- when you have a question to ask the team

basically, any thing you would raise your voice to say over a cube wall.

.

.

<strong>Yammer Face</strong>
One other thing to know about Yammer: for better or worse, Yammer is the primary day-to-day window each of us has on each of the others. If you never yammer, people will wonder what you do. That's not say they'll think you don't work, but rather, they will wonder what you do when you work. The people who work with you least form the greatest part of their understanding of you based on your yammer flow. In some ways it's a very constructed identity. And therein lies a subtle and never-resting pressure.

.

.

<strong>Yammer Freedom</strong>

Yammer is not meant to be a burden -- but rather an outlet when you have news you just need to share. If you get the urge, yammer. If you're curious about what's going on, look in yammer.

Personally, I yammer compulsively. I find it hard to not share a lot of this stuff. Tom, Rebecca and I have each posted over 900 messages. I'm not sure what that says about us and I'm not sure it's all good. But there it is.

Though sometimes, I don't feel like sharing what I spent the last 4 hours on. Yesterday I spent most of my time on various versions of proposals for the webinar and TLC workshop, but nothing conclusive happened so it never hit me that we've crossed a threshold worth sharing about.

MJ on the other hand does stuff every day but only yammered once each in June, July and August. Not at all in September. She's not a yammerer. And that's just fine.

How do you use yammer?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<wp:post_name>yammer</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
		<title>Core Soomo Web Tools</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/09/core-soomo-web-tools/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 28 Sep 2009 13:04:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=844</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We use a lot of web services on purpose. Because we create web tools it's worth the overhead for us to spend a lot of time using a diverse set of tools. And we change or try out new tools regularly. Much of our value in serving professors and students comes from knowing what's possible, what works well, and what is intensely annoying about web-based tools. And deep knowledge of these things comes from daily use. We don't need to master all, or any, of these. But using them teaches us about the world in which we we are working.

<!--more-->

<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<strong>Mite</strong>
Time tracker used throughout the day. Essential to use as it feeds accounting and helps us know where we are investing what is, far and away, our most precious resource -- our time. The vast majority of our expenses are our hours so knowing where they went helps us know what actions led to what results. And personally, closely tracking my time is almost always surprising, informative and leads to changes in how long I'll let myself work on relatively lower priority issues.

<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<strong>Yammer</strong>
Team conversation, used throughout the day. Yammers are usually 1-3 sentence posts about what's going on right now, or what just happened. And this is how most of our team stays in touch with most of our team most of the time. In other words, most days, most of Soomo hears from you only in Yammer -- and that's true for everyone.

<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<strong>ProjectPath</strong>
Tool for project planning and tracking. Often used daily, but at the very least updated weekly for the Monday crunch. This is a central location for project information, documents, calendar and todos. It's especially helpful for seeing handoffs from one person to another and seeing how many of us work together to get things done.

<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<strong>HighRise (and FileMaker)</strong>
HighRise tracks our organization's communication with people -- professors, publishers, some freelancers and so on. When we have multiple people communicating with someone, all they have to do is CC HighRise on all email and then we all have a single place to go to see the entire conversational thread. So Mary, Tom and Melissa might all be communicating with a professor. Before I would respond to an email from that prof, I'd go to HighRise to get the backstory. It's also a place we can record details about each contact. If I learn some things at MPSA 2008 and more at APSA 2009, I can record those notes in HighRise and now everyone has access to them. Just this morning Tressa Tabares asked me to call her tomorrow at 11. Using HighRise I was able to get her cell number, which she'd given to someone else on our team, and make life easier for Tressa and myself. (Filemaker is a database of 8,000 people we know teach political science but who are not yet in conversation with us. We reach out to them via email periodically and, if they start responding, move them into HighRise.)

<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<strong>BackPack</strong>
Backpack is a tool for posting notes we can all see. A backpack page allows multiple people to work on a document. A writeboard allows multiple people to work on a document and tracks versions so you can roll back if need be. You can also post documents in backpack within a page which allows you to describe the file before you post it. Where files need to be accessed by all of us, and need to be described with something more than a file name this is a perfect place. Or if we need to all know of the place to get the latest version of some file (e.g. a list of all collections or demo log-ins) then this can be a good place for that.

<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<strong>getdropbox</strong>
This tool allows us to have a shared folder which behaves much like a local folder. You can browse through folders, organized in nested files and open, alter and save. It can be incredibly convenient. But it's public space. And if I delete a file, it's deleted out of everyone's version, so it takes some coordination to work out how files will be organized, managed and updated with your teammates.

<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<strong>gMail</strong>
All of our email runs through gmail -- they have great backups, spam filters and a reliable web interface. Some of us use the web interface of gmail all the time. Some of us use a local client such as Mail, MailPlane or PostBox.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_author_IP>173.20.53.57</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2009-09-29 08:34:12</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-09-29 13:34:12</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[All snickering aside, this is really a helpful rundown of the bountiful tools in the Soomoian's toolbox. I would add one comment about Backpack: if there is an event coming up that more than two or three of us are attending (APSA, TLC, MPSA, etc), I've generally made it a practice to make a Backpack page outlining all the details of the event, any pertinent contact info, files, dates, maps, whatever. I usually title the page with the name and date of the event. This works well as a one-stop information center, answering all the basic questions about the event in an accessible way, making sure we're all on the same... wait for it... page.]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>ProjectPath</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/09/projectpath/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Sep 2009 11:55:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://shoebox.soomo.org/?p=848</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://soomo.projectpath.com/clients">ProjectPath</a> (aka <a href="http://basecamphq.com/">Basecamp</a>) is our project management headquarters. We've been using it for the past four years and we've tried a number of different approaches to make it truly useful without being taxing -- to make sure the juice is always worth the squeeze.
<!--more-->
<div style="text-align:center"><img style="border:0 none" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/09/projectpath.jpg" border="0" alt="projectpath.jpg" width="525" height="360" /></div>

<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2><strong>Crunch Agenda</strong></h2>
The most basic function of project path is to help us all to know about all the projects we are currently working on. In our weekly meeting -- the 1:00 Monday Crunch -- we go through the list of projects. If it's in the list, we talk about it. if it's not, we probably don't. For this reason it's important that all active projects (meaning, we are working on them this week) are listed and all inactive projects are either "on hold" or "archived."

"Projects on hold" is a great place to stage work. You can set up messages, todo lists, milestones, files etc. but we won't cover it on Mondays and it won't show up in dashboard updates. So if you're taking a week off from a project -- put it on hold. If you need a place to stick things as they come to you for a project you're not yet engaging, "on hold" is a great place to do it.

Right now we're prepending project names with the project owner so that it's easy to find your stuff and so we can report in bundles on Mondays.


<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2><strong>Projects</strong></h2>
What exactly counts as a "project?" We've worked with many different definitions of over the years, different ways of using this field in projectpath. Our current definition is heavily informed by Peter Drucker (an organization only matters when it delivers something of value outside itself) and David Allen (a project is a series of action items leading to a desired outcome.) So a project should be:

<strong>1) a thing we are doing that will result in something of value.</strong>

<strong>2) a thing that will end.</strong>

We have in the past had "umbrella" labels such as "marketing." The problem with this is it's a category of projects and not a project, which leads to 1) hiding many projects (thus not realizing all we have going on) and 2) never, ever coming off the list (which leads to a sense of hamster wheeling -- that is, work grinding on without end forever and no progress being made.)

<strong>3)  a substantial thing that will take some time (more than 20 hrs) and/or multiple people, but not a gargantuan thing (less than 2 months)</strong>

Sometimes a shorter one goes in because it requires multiple people and tricky handoffs. Most things smaller than 20 hours are best seen as part of a larger project. And we definitely have some well-defined editorial projects that will receive attention every week for more than 12 weeks. But in general, if the project is going to take more than two months, see if there' s not a smaller project within it that could be handled on its own.

If there is something that will consume a lot of your time this week, that is not on the project list, then you should see a flag -- why am I spending so much time on this non-project thing? Is it really a project? Who else should be involved?


<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2><strong>Stakeholders</strong></h2>
This is fairly new for us but getting ready for APSA highlighted the fact that we were going so fast we were often failing to get crucial input from teammates until the project was done. Now, every project has an unambiguous owner who is ultimately responsible for the project and stakeholders who are those people who need, at the least, to be part of the three key conversations:

<em><strong>kick off meeting</strong></em>
in which we define the problem we are trying to solve with this project -- why does this project exist?

<em><strong>design meeting</strong></em>
in which we review the proposed solution before it's actually built -- it's much easier to make changes now

<em><strong>review meeting</strong></em>
in which look at what is potentially ready for release, to catch any issues before it goes live

There may be additional meetings as needed, but these three are a bare minimum.

There are some surprising connections at times between team members. For example, a recent mass email to generate sales leads promoting new content required
- Melissa, who best knows the content and how to portray it accurately
- Mary &amp; Danielle, who best know the market and how to reach them effectively
- Jamie, who was responsible for building an html template and working with MyEmma to get it produced
- Tom, who would need to help people trying to take advantage of the offer
- Kathi, for her leadership role in sales and editorial
- David, as our interim marketer

It was not initially obvious we would need HTML coding and support present to kick off a marketing effort, but it was obvious once we asked, "Who all will need to be on the team to make sure this comes off well, start to finish?" Had we not asked this question, and not brought Jamie and Tom in to the meeting, we still would have needed their help -- but it would have come as a surprise to them that this big new thing was suddenly on their plate and urgent.

These meetings can feel onerous because they are bigger than we expect -- and big meetings are incredibly expensive. But in the end, they mean we build smarter with more input out of the gate, and we build faster with better hand-offs, by not blindsiding people.
<div style="text-align:center"><img style="border:0 none" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/09/stakes.jpg" border="0" alt="stakes.jpg" width="491" height="206" /></div>
Right now, I'm listing the stakeholders for each project in the Project Overview page. You can do this by clicking "project settings" in the upper right.
<div style="text-align:center"><img style="border:0 none" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/09/settings.jpg" border="0" alt="settings.jpg" width="390" height="222" /></div>
On the Project Settings page you can enter an "overview page announcement" and check the box to display it. Incidentally, this is also where you put a project on hold.
<div style="text-align:center"><img style="border:0 none" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/09/settings_page.jpg" border="0" alt="settings_page.jpg" width="347" height="305" /></div>


<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<h2><strong>The Tabs</strong></h2>
A few, very brief comments, on the tabs in a project:
<div style="text-align:center"><img style="border:0 none" src="http://soomoshoebox.files.wordpress.com/2009/09/tabs.jpg" border="0" alt="tabs.jpg" width="418" height="42" /></div>
<em>Overview</em>
Your project dashboard. Should list the stakeholders and automatically shows recent updates.

<em>Messages</em>
Text boxes. A great place for meeting notes.

<em>To-Do</em>
Usually the heart of the project. "to-do lists" are the mini-projects within the whole. These deserve a post of their own...

<em>Milestones</em>
A great place for your big deadlines. These not only provide an easy place for all to see the cal, but they also stream into the ProjectPath dashboard where everyone can see what's big on your plate. It's easy to over do it here -- just put the big ones in.

<em>Writeboards</em>
Like messages, but tracks versions, making it a great place for collaborative or evolving documents

<em>Chat</em>
I've never used this -- anyone?

<em>Time</em>
We use Mite.

<em>Files</em>
Perfect place for files related to the project (but a frustrating place for files you'll need beyond the scope of the project, so check with yourself when uploading and if the document will be needed beyond this one project, look to backpack or dropbox.)]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Professor-to-Professor</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/professor-to-professor/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Oct 2009 15:37:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=879</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[New post at: http://nobodywriteslikeme.wordpress.com/

...in which Chris details the meeting she had yesterday with the English faculty of Mars Hill. They were curious about her digital experiment this fall and also wanted to have a departmental discussion about whether or not one instructor should be allowed to teach out of a non-standard text. (That's a very loaded sentence.)

Her pitch and it's reception are remarkable on several levels, I'll mention just two:
<!--more-->

<strong>BEST IN THE WORLD</strong>
NWLM is already best in its class. While we are keenly aware of all the potential yet to be realized, we have in fact launched a market leading project right out of the gate (again). While Chris' latest post is focused on faculty reception, her students in multiple sections at two schools are equally enthusiastic and see this as a generation ahead of other web resources they've been assigned.

I can't say enough to thank Chris, Emily, Kathi, Camryn, David, Jamie, Paige and everyone else who contributed to this launch. NWLM is amazing, its reception is encouraging, and it all makes me want to accelerate...come on paper upload and grades!

<strong>ARMING THE REBELS</strong>
It's controversial for an instructor to use something new. And it's controversial to use an eBook. In each course, you only get one shot at this particular set of thirty kids and they're real people who deserve the absolute best -- profs don't take lightly to experimenting on students. We must give them great confidence that this is, in fact, the best possible resource.

A professor, instructor or (in very rare cases) adjunct who tries something new takes a professional risk. And persuading peers to move the whole department in a new direction is a really big deal. (I hesitate to say where we should eat tonight for fear some won't like it. Imagine telling everyone in the department, "trust me on this, this website will be way better than books....")

For Soomo to succeed on a large scale it is essential that we
1) Use every ounce of sales and marketing muscle we have to find those few professors eagerly seeking an alternative to the status quo, happy to try out something just because it looks promising, and willing to do the extra work it takes in hopes this will really matter for her students.

and 2) equip, assure and thrilling those professors so much that they begin to evangelize -- to wage the on-the-ground, interpersonal campaigns that we can't. Equipping them is our core sales and marketing mission. No matter how big we get, how cash rich we become or how many workshops we give at TLC we simply can't speak to a professor as a peer. We need professor-to-professor recommendation. Chris, as a Soomo alum and the original designer of NWLM is, admittedly, a plant. But still she's given us a remarkable peek behind the curtain at what those advocating our adoption are up against.

In the first semester American River used us, we were tipped off that Tressa was the gatekeeper -- a savvy user of technology who wouldn't tolerate tomfoolery. Thankfully, we had Americans Governing and Tom Meeks and the rest is history. But I'm amazed and humbled to know more about these departmental meetings in which professors advocate for us without us being there, at professional risk and amidst political complications. All of which leads me to double my resolve in making sure we are easy to explain, easy to defend and obviously compelling -- in six screens or less.

Thank you team. Thank you Chris. Let's make sure Chris and all our other advocates are thrilled!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Get PoliSilo delivered to your Yammer</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/get-polisilo-delivered-to-your-yammer/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 06 Oct 2009 11:56:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=874</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[If you want to make sure you never miss another PoliSilo post, and you watch yammer, you can subscribe to the RSS (that's "Really Simple Syndication", not Rebecca) of PoliSilo and it will, um, yam at you automatically.

To do this, go to yammer and
1) click on RSS in the right hand tool bar.

<img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-875" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/wp-content/uploads/1-RSS-300x178.jpg" alt="1 RSS" width="300" height="178" />

2) Click on "find RSS Feeds" in the yellow message.
3) You should see polisilo listed
4) click to "follow"

<img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-876" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/wp-content/uploads/2-select-feed-1-300x182.jpg" alt="2 select feed-1" width="300" height="182" />

Now PoliSilo message will show up in your yammer stream (but not in anyone else's unless they too subscribe.

Yay RSS.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Event Tracking on Google Analytics</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/event-tracking-on-google-analytics/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 02 Oct 2009 17:17:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=897</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This write up is meant to show how to view event tracking in Google Analytics. We use event tracking to see how many people are viewing the various videos on the AG, CG, and IR marketing sites. At first glance it appears as if GA is not properly reporting events, but once you dig a little deeper you can get pretty granular with event tracking data.

<!--more-->
<h1>Step 1:</h1>
Log into GA. On the dashboard click on the site that you want to view (in this example I use AG).

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-898" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/GAStep1.png" alt="Google Analytics Step 1" />
<h1>Step 2:</h1>
On the left nav click the <strong>Content</strong> link.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-899" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/GAStep2.png" alt="Google Analytics Step 2" />
<h1>Step 3:</h1>
On the left nav under the Content header, click Event Tracking.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-900" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/GAStep3.png" alt="Google Analytics Step 3" />
<h1>Step 4:</h1>
On the next screen towards the bottom you will see a list of event categories. For now, we only have 1 category which is labeled <strong>Videos</strong> (since that is all we are tracking at the moment). This is a top level category. Clicking on the <strong>'view all'</strong> link (which can be a bit hard to see) will allow you to view the sub-categories of Videos.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-901" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/GAStep4.png" alt="Google Analytics Step 4" />
<h1>Step 5:</h1>
This next view lists actions under the Videos category. Since we wanted to know how many users are viewing the videos, we are monitoring the 'Open' action. Click on the word 'Open'.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-902" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/GAStep5.png" alt="Google Analytics Step 5" />
<h1>Step 6:</h1>
Now we can see a list of all the videos that users are calling the 'open' action on.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-903" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/GAStep6.png" alt="Google Analytics Step 6" />

You can go even more granular if you want by clicking on one of the items and then using the drop down menu to view statistics about that specific item such as OS, browser, etc.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-904" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/GAStep7.png" alt="Google Analytics Step 7" />

This concept holds true for most items on Google Analytics. Everything starts with a wide view and clicking down will give you more detailed view of an item.

Hope this helps.<span style="background-color: #ffffff;"> </span>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Things</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/things/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 05 Oct 2009 11:14:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=915</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://culturedcode.com/things/">Things</a> is tool for tracking to-dos.
<p style="text-align: center;"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-917" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/Things-.jpg" alt="Things" /></p>
If you have a good handle on what's next for you, rarely wonder if you're doing the thing you really should be doing right now, don't forget stuff and don't feel burdened by what you're trying to remember, then the rest of this will seem absolutely absurd.

<!--more-->

Personally, I get so overwhelmed with it all that I actually take "<a href="http://www.davidco.com/what_is_gtd.php">Getting Things Done</a>" seriously and use Things as a tool to help me deal with it all.

GTD comes down to three uber-strategies in my mind:

- <strong>A trusted place to put everything</strong>.
that's the trick to freeing up your mind

- <strong>Regular reviews of everything in that place.
</strong>otherwise things go in but never come out

- <strong>Always know what's next</strong>
have a smaller list organized by priority, urgency and context

Things is starting to perform all three roles for me and it's getting easier every week.

<strong>A TRUSTED PLACE</strong>
I can enter tasks into Things with less friction than any other note making tool.

No matter what application I have open, pressing [<strong>ctrl + option + space</strong>] gives me the quick entry dialogue, which is fast enough to make a note to do during a conversation. No windows to navigate, no mouse to move. Type and return and it's gone.

Even better, with Mail or a browser open, pressing [<strong>ctrl + space</strong>] opens the quick entry dialogue seeded with a link to the selected email or web page. This was the missing piece for a long time. Until linking a todo to an email was that easy, I always had this other stash of unstructured todos in my in-box "action" folder and in my "to read" bookmarks.

And the iPhone app works well, though I have to remember to sync since it doesn't happen automatically as with SimpleNote, nor upon plugging in. But when I do remember to sync it works well.

I typically throw new items into the inbox while I'm doing other stuff - mid-thought, mid-conversation or while reading. Then later I "process" my in-box to organize the actions by completing the though, tagging it as needed and dropping it on an appropriate project. This doesn't have to be a two step process, but for me I'm typically recording tasks as they occur to me while I'm doing something else. Managing those tasks is it's own task, albeit a brief one, and Things makes this much easier than anything else I've tried.

ORGANIZING ACTIONS
-- <em><strong>Areas of Responsibility</strong></em> and <em><strong>Projects</strong></em>
These two categories serve to group actions, dictating a folder structure exactly two levels deep. Areas hold Projects which hold Actions. And using this strict hierarchy is most useful to me in exactly the way implied.

My Project "Fall Email Campaigns" conveniently holds all my Actions for that project.
My Area "Marketing" holds all my projects related to marketing and any marketing Actions that don't belong to a project.

As a result, I can see all areas, projects and actions sorted in this hierarchy.
The order of Areas dictates the order of both Active Projects and the list of Projects.

e.g. Marketing is my highest priority Area and within it Fall Email Campaigns is highest
<p style="text-align: center;"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-916" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/project-lists.jpg" alt="project lists" /></p>
-- Tagging
The area and project labels are hierarchical. Each task can have at most one area and one project.
Tags, however, are a far more flexible way of indicating types of tasks (such as "design") and contexts (such as "errand").

My context changes most significantly as people come and go physically or on the phone. For example, when I'm at David Perkowski's desk, I need to know everything I've been meaning to talk to David about, regardless of Area or Project.

I gave up on the "team mate" function of Things because each item had to belong to one and only one person and sometimes I need to talk to both Kathi and Melissa about something. And I couldn't browse teammates from the iPhone, which meant that I could summon Tom's list unless I had my computer with me. And to disassociate an item with a person I would have to drag it back to my inbox, then click on the inbox, figure out which one it was and drag it to someone else or one or my projects. Blech.

But since I started using tags for the person or people involved, it's gotten a lot stronger. I can now click anyone's name (while in Next) and see everything I need to talk to them about. Big sigh of relief.

The only other tags I use are for truly special contexts such as "@home" "@work" or "saturday" and these are things I typically want to make sure I do before I leave such as "pick up projector - @work"
<p style="text-align: center;"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-919" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/tags.jpg" alt="tags" /></p>
<strong>REGULAR REVIEWS</strong>
All that data entry and organizing is simply a means of providing useful views of my lists so I quit messing with Things and actually get things done.

<strong>Views</strong>
-- Inbox
I look here to find the latest unprocessed tasks and notes to myself. I complete the details needed, then tag and file appropriately.

-- Next
This is my master list. If I need to know what I have been meaning to talk to Tom about I go to "next" and click "Tom." Next includes all actions from all projects and all areas of responsibility. It also includes actions that have no project and no Area (e.g. get wood glue for that wobbly chair.)

Next includes everything except:
. . Inbox, so I clean it out first before looking at Next
. . Someday (which is a place to put things I don't want to see in regular reviews)

-- Today
Today turns out be much like a special tag.
Anything can be flagged as today or unflagged. I use it more or less as intended to flag the things of highest priority or urgency.

<em>My Weekly Review</em>
Once a week, I take a quick look at my Areas to see if they are still in an accurate order, then I do the same with projects.
Then I go into Next, which can be a bit daunting, but I read every item to see what simply must have attention this week.
Those items that really must have attention this week get bumped into "Today" or I schedule them.

This is the crucial review that enables me to trust this system. It takes less than 15 minutes and provides immense confidence that I have a concise list on which to focus this week. This is the easiest method I've seen for such a review.

<strong> </strong>

<strong>KNOW WHATS NEXT</strong>
Day to day, I frequently do three kinds of review.

<strong>What's next?</strong>
More than once a day I look at all my "today" items to figure out what I really need to make sure I do in the next couple hours.

<strong>What do I need to discuss with Tim?</strong>
Everyday I meet with somebody, maybe for the only time that week, and I need to make sure we cover everything. I go the "next" view and click their name to see everything tagged for them.

The power of this is hard to express. I can have any thought at any time about something I want to talk to Tim about. And as long as I get it into Things with a Tim tag, through my computer or phone, I know that the next time I'm talking with Tim I'll remember to bring this up. (Now if you're Tim, you may be wondering if this is such a good idea. But if you're me, you'll breathe a sigh of relief that I really don't have to hold it all in my head.)

<strong>What's up with this project?</strong>
And most days I look into my current plan for one or more projects. Probably because I'm working with someone on it or I'm finishing up some part and need to see the full list or, frequently, I'm being reminded of the urgency of this project yet again and want to make sure it's all on track.

Those three views are my main guides through the day. They allow me to confidently know whats urgent, whats most important right now, and what all I need to discuss while I have someone's ear.

Things makes GTD possible for me. One place to put stuff as it lands on my plate, one place to go and easily sort through it all once a week, and one place to see what I need to do or discuss next.]]></content:encoded>
