	<item>
		<title>We are working in a new medium</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/we-are-working-in-a-new-medium/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 Oct 2009 11:44:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=938</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A <a href="http://toc.oreilly.com/2009/09/mobile-as-new-medium.html">post from O'Reilly's Tools of Change</a> blog gets the mobile textbook question exactly right. The question is not how to put a traditional text on a mobile device, but on how to use a mobile device to do the work of a textbook. (And I would argue the same holds true for a browser.)

McGraw, for one, is <a href="http://chronicle.com/article/New-E-Textbooks-Do-More-Than/48324/?sid=wc=wc=en">experimenting</a> in this direction.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>938</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-10-08 07:44:24</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-10-08 11:44:24</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>we-are-working-in-a-new-medium</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>70</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[pimashburn]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>melissa_mashburn@hotmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>24.61.156.47</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2009-10-09 23:18:14</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-10-10 03:18:14</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA["how do we port 2-page book layouts to a small screen." I suspect that's the question McGraw is asking...because none of the new "connected" texts they are touting are new texts. In fact, they've mostly selected their tried-and-true bestsellers. Might be worth purchasing one-- perhaps Lucas, their topselling communication text-- to see what the bells and whistles are. A truism in media adaptations is that if it's a great novel it will be a mediocre film. If it's a great textbook, I suspect it will be a mediocre text 2.0. Building from the ground up is the only way to go.]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>Fun with RSS</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/fun-with-rss/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 09 Oct 2009 17:26:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=942</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[RSS (Real Simple Syndication) allows you to subscribe to blogs and websites and stay updated in one single location without having to visit a bunch of sites throughout the day to see what's going on.

There are many tools and services you can use to keep up with RSS feeds. Most email clients will allow you to subscribe to RSS feeds. I personally am a HUGE fan of Google Reader which allows you to access your feeds online so you access them from anywhere. There are a number of desktop and mobile apps that will synchronize with your Google Reader account.

<!--more-->
<h2>Getting started with Google Reader</h2>
You already have a Google Reader account. Head over to <a title="Google Reader" href="http://reader.google.com" target="_blank">http://reader.google.com</a> and sign in with your Soomo mail address and password you use to log into your Soomo mail account.

If you've never been to Google Reader before you should see a screen that looks like this:

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-943" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/Reader01.png" alt="Google Reader Start Screen" />

Your reader will be empty so let's look at how to find and add RSS feeds. The easiest way to use Google Reader and add new RSS feeds is to use GR's bookmarklet.

At the top of the Google Reader page, click on the <strong>Settings</strong> link next to your email address. When the settings page loads click on the <strong>Goodies</strong> tab. Scroll down the page a little bit until you see the header "Subscribe as You Surf". Follow the instructions there and drag the "Subscribe" link to your bookmarks toolbar.

Now you're set up to quickly add new feeds to your Reader account.
<h2>Finding RSS Feeds</h2>
As you surf the web you might notice on the address bar different icons depending on your browser.

In Safari you'll see an icon like this on the address bar:

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-944" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/SafariRSS.png" alt="SafariRSS" />

In Firefox you'll see an icon like this:

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-945" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/FirefoxRSS.png" alt="FirefoxRSS" />

When you see this icon it means there is an RSS feed available for the site. You can click on the icon to see the feed, but that's not really necessary.

You have two options. You can click on the Subscribe bookmark you added earlier to quickly add the feed to Reader. The other option is to copy the URL from the address bar, open Reader, click the Subscribe button at the top left of the page and paste the URL into the field that appears.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-947" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/Reader03.png" alt="Reader03" />
<h2>Managing Your Feeds</h2>
Once you've started to import feeds into Reader you can manage them by grouping them into folders. Click on a feed that you've added in the left hand feed list. When the feed loads, click on the Feed Settings button underneath the feed's name at the top right. You can then select New Folder to create a new folder for the feed (or assign it to an existing one if you have any already created).

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-948" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/Reader04.png" alt="Reader04" />

Social Features

One of my favorite aspects of Google Reader is to be able to quickly share stuff with others (which is something I am constantly doing via Twitter and my blogs). Reader has some nice ways to get your links out quickly to others.

When you are viewing an item in a feed you'll notice a row of links on the bottom of the item.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-949" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/Reader05.png" alt="Reader05" />

<strong>Add Star</strong> allows you to flag the item and saves it in your 'starred items' folder which you can find at the top left of the window. I use this a lot for items that I might want to read later on.

<strong>Like</strong> works similar to Facebook's like feature. It just posts out to other Google Reader users that you liked the article. I honestly don't use this feature much.

<strong>Share</strong> and <strong>Share with Note</strong> are probably the best features. When you click Share or Share with Note, the item is added to your Shared Items feed which others can subscribe to. You can follow other users and see what they are sharing (and liking) which I will explain more about in a separate post. Share with Note works the same as Share, but allows you to post a comment on the item as you share it.

<strong>Email</strong> will open up a little Gmail compose box and let you email the item to someone in place (fully integrated into your Soomo/Gmail account so all your contacts will be right there).

<strong>Send To</strong> will allow you to post the item to other places such as Twitter, Delicious, or Facebook.
<h2>Desktop Apps</h2>
I used to just view Google Reader directly in the browser all the time, but I recently discovered a pretty nice desktop app that syncs with my Reader account directly called NetNewsWire. The program has actually been around awhile, but they recently changed their business model and made the app sync directly with Google rather than their own RSS aggregation service.

You can get NetNewsWire <a title="NetNewsWire" href="http://www.newsgator.com/Individuals/NetNewsWire/?gcid=S18242x004-NNW_ad1&amp;keyword=netnewswire&amp;utm_source=google&amp;utm_medium=ppc&amp;utm_term=netnewswire&amp;_kk=netnewswire&amp;_kt=f3d1c417-8978-4802-b2ec-14253c7bece4&amp;gclid=CPfS_eS3sJ0CFVRM5QodZWybjQ" target="_blank">here</a> (if you're on windows you can use <a title="FeedDemon" href="http://www.newsgator.com/Individuals/FeedDemon/?gcid=S18242x004-FD_ad1&amp;keyword=feeddemon&amp;utm_source=google&amp;utm_medium=ppc&amp;utm_term=feeddemon&amp;_kk=feeddemon&amp;_kt=749b01da-f376-4438-b914-7cd4118a3c71&amp;gclid=CLaj9MO3sJ0CFado5Qod6gNMiw" target="_blank">FeedDemon</a> which is developed by the same company).

Setting up these apps is extremely easy. When you install and load it for the first time, the app will ask you for your Google account info (use your Soomo mail account) and will automatically sync up with what you have online. When you use the apps as you read things it will stay synced with the online version so if you go to Reader in your browser you'll see all the changes you made in the desktop app.
<h2>iPhone Apps</h2>
If you have an iPhone, there are a couple of choices for syncing with Reader on the phone. You can go to the Reader website in Safari on your phone to view a specially formatted version of the site.

There are 2 other apps (that I know of) that are pretty nice:
<ul>
	<li>Newstand ($4.99) - <a href="http://bit.ly/xpXB" target="_blank">http://bit.ly/xpXB</a> (my personal favorite)</li>
	<li>Byline ($3.99) - <a href="http://bit.ly/Lmg5f" target="_blank">http://bit.ly/Lmg5f</a></li>
</ul>
Hopefully that helps get you started. If you have any questions feel free to hit me up and I'll help out any way I can. If you feel it might be useful we could also schedule a meeting/screencast and I can go over how I use Google Reader in more depth.

Cheers.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Or ruin it if you're anything like me. :)]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Fun with Email Organization and Filtering</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/fun-with-email-organization-and-filtering/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 09 Oct 2009 18:34:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>admin</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=953</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In our conversation earlier about how we use web tools as a company I made a suggestion about keeping emails organized and their purpose clear. This post is going to expand a bit more on what I was talking about and also outline some tips and tricks that I use to keep my inbox more organized.

The methods I use below are meant to work primarily in the Gmail web interface but at the end I'll run through some ways to utilize them in Apple Mail as well for those of you that prefer to use that.

<!--more-->
<h2>The Magnificent World of Subject Lines</h2>
When I worked in advertising and had to deal with a multitude of projects, change orders, team members, and clients on a daily basis I quickly learned that if you don't keep your inbox organized, insanity is sure to follow.

We learned that one of the simplest ways to keep the communication channels from getting chaotic was to standardize the subject lines of our emails. This naturally takes some discipline on the part of everyone in the team but is truly (in my humble opinion) one of the best things you can do to help each other out.

Gmail fortunately helps out a lot by grouping conversation streams together but if you're anything like me, your inbox can still be a bit tricky to figure out what's going on by reading subject lines.

What we did at the ad agency was come up with abbreviations for clients and projects and prepend all subject lines pertaining to those clients/projects with that abbreviation.

So in our case, we could do something like:
<p style="padding-left: 30px;">[EMTEXT CONTENT]: Chapter 50 ready for posting
[NWLM BUG]: It's broken!!!
[SP REQUEST]: Can we update the homepage?</p>
The strategy I'm using here is to use a project abbreviation and a category of sorts. This serves 2 purposes: it allows me to scan my inbox and easily identify different tasks/issues that need my attention and it allows me to easily set up filters to organize my inbox.
<h2>Filters and Labels in Gmail</h2>
I use filters and labels in gmail constantly. It's truly the only way I can keep track of what's going on in my constantly growing inbox. Normally I will go through each day and apply labels to various emails by hand to sort them out, but using the method standardized subject lines above I could easily set up filters to automate that process.

I do this a lot with my personal email. I route all of my various email addresses into my Gmail account and then use filters to dump emails from certain places into specific folders or apply specific labels.

Setting up a filter is pretty simple. You can create a rule from scratch or select an email that's in your inbox and build a rule from that. Here's an example:

Let's say I received this email:

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-954" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/Gmail02.png" alt="Gmail02" />

To set up a filter, I would check the box next to it, click on 'More Actions', and then select 'Filter messages like these'.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-955" src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/10/Gmail03.png" alt="Gmail03" width="550" height="173" />

By default the filter will be created based on the email address of the sender. In this case I want to filter based on what's in the subject line. So I cleared out the 'From' field and typed [NWLM BUG] into the 'Subject' field. Clicking on 'Test Search' allows me to see how my filter is working.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-956" src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/10/Gmail04.png" alt="Gmail04" width="799" height="256" />

Once I'm satisfied that my filter is doing what I want it to I click 'Next Step'. Now I get to decide what I want to do with these messages. In this case all I want to do is add the 'Bugs' label to the message. I make sure I check off 'Also apply filter to 1 conversation below' so that the new message is filtered when I'm done. Once I'm done, clicking 'Create Filter' will run the filter and turn it on.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-957" src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/10/Gmail05.png" alt="Gmail05" width="735" height="207" />

Now when I return to my inbox, I'll see the new label attached to the message.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-958" src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/10/Gmail06.png" alt="Gmail06" width="640" height="347" />

Labels in Gmail work on the same concept as tags (which is all they really are). Personally I would want to further filter messages like this since the email pertains to both NWLM and bugs that I need to fix. So I would create another rule for this email and have that rule apply the NWLM label.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-959" src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/10/Gmail07.png" alt="Gmail07" width="555" height="276" />

The downside to this is that it takes some time to "train" your inbox and set up filters. But you can easily do this as messages come in and before you know you'll have your inbox all sorts of organized.
<h2>Filters in Apple Mail</h2>
Filtering in Apple Mail works much the same way. Gmail's label system is reason enough for me to use it over Apple Mail, but that's a matter of personal preference.

To create rules in Apple Mail, go into preferences and click on the 'Rules' tab at the far right.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-960" src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/10/MailRules01.png" alt="MailRules01" width="590" height="349" />

Click the Add Rule button and then use the dialog to build your rule. The nice thing about Apple Mail's rules is that you can set multiple conditions and results in a single rule vs. having to create multiple rules as you do with Gmail. You can do this by using the + buttons next to the rules and actions.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-961" src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/10/MailRules02.png" alt="MailRules02" width="570" height="260" />

Click okay once you're finished. Mail will ask you if you want to run the rule on messages in your inbox so click 'Apply' to do so.

That's it.
<h2>Conclusion</h2>
As I said before, this is a pretty drastic change in workflow and may not appeal to everyone. I merely post it up here as a suggestion, but if you find it to be a useful way of keeping our communications organized than I think it would be worth giving a shot. It'll take some time to implement and adjust to, but I think in the long run it could help us all out a great deal.

And as always, if you have any questions, let me know.

Cheers.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Wireframing</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/wireframing/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 12 Oct 2009 11:15:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=966</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Wireframes are one of my favorite things in the world. Light, easy to create, easy to change, concrete-ish ways of brainstorming and communicating.

Wireframes often start with just a few pencil strokes. Whiteboards, pages and napkins of this:
<p style="text-align: center;"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-967" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/1.jpg" alt="1" /></p>
Then they often move into Keynote so we can start playing with more precise space, hypothetical images, text, navigation.

Rarely do they get more refined that this one for our next revision of ag.com. At this point, I am perhaps over the line into design being a little too fussy about the spacing, font weights, ornaments and so on.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-968" src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/10/ag-story-1002.key_.jpg" alt="ag story 1002.key" width="469" height="412" />

The final design won't look like this, but this gives me some shapes to kick around with folks before we pull Clint in and say "kind of like this." The shape heavily influences the words and vice versa. It's a classic catch 22. The designer doesn't know if we need a prominent headline, or a place for a screen cast or place holders for articles unless we know that's what we're creating. Yet the writer doesn't know that this stuff needs to exist until the placeholders are in the design.

This is usually resolved with drafts. Drafts of copy, sketches of interface, until one day something clicks and we have our basic form, our basic elements (you get one headline, four menu items, an 8 line blurb give or take, two photos, etc.) and we start polishing. Now it's typically too late to introduce new elements, but we can always replace a given element.

Then Clint gets into Photoshop and creates a flat design.
- When we all sign off on the design, he carves it up into pieces...
- and Jamie assembles those pieces in HTML with live text instead of flat images of text.
- Then David hooks it up to the database so it's part of our system.

And that's the semi-standard way most of our interfaces are created. For example, consider the content zones at <a href="http://www.soomopublishing.com/">http://www.soomopublishing.com/</a>

The zones outlined in yellow are wireframe -- understood as the skeleton or map of the site. All the fabulous text treatments, shading, spacing and so on are "design." The fact that the top photo cycles through four images is "browser-side functionality" which Jamie codes.

You can see that the design and the copy are tailored for each other. Clint needed to know how big our quotes would be to create this design, and we needed to see this design to figure out how big our quotes should be. That's a recurring catch-22, but working collaboratively (and trying things out quickly in sketches) it all works out.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-969" src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/10/soomo_home.jpg" alt="soomo_home" width="459" height="650" />

We're not using all the content areas we created. We plan for a news feed to run in area 4. And area 6 will eventually pick up streams from blogs. We could easily alter the text in area 2, but it really shouldn't change in length. We could add another slide to area 5, but not two more. And if we decided we wanted a "checklist to starting this fall" somewhere on this page, we'd either have to swap something out or redesign the page.

This probably has more in common with magazines and newspapers than book layouts. And most of our pages are far less complex than the Soomo home. But hopefully this description points out the role of wireframes in the give and take of content and design as they break out of the "you first" catch-22 to achieve an integrated presentation.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Busy Being Born</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/busy-being-born/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 15 Oct 2009 11:03:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=973</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Tim O'Reilly is one of the very <a href="http://oreilly.com/">best book publishers</a> and, simultaneously, the leading seller of <a href="http://my.safaribooksonline.com/">digital content</a>. His company is also the force behind the <a href="http://www.toccon.com/toc2010">leading conference</a> on how the industry is changing.

So perhaps it's not surprising to find <a href="http://radar.oreilly.com/2009/10/he-not-busy-being-born-is-busy.html">his thoughts</a> on this change to be so literary.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Features are plot, UI is prose</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/features-are-plot-ui-is-prose/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 22 Oct 2009 11:14:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=977</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In his <a href="http://shawnblanc.net/2009/10/tweetie-20/">brief praise</a> of an iphone app Shawn makes some insightful comments about some ways software design is like writing, and many other writerly tasks. It's an art. And it succeeds or fails based on what happens in the mind of your reader.
<blockquote>
<div>

What Loren has done in his design of Tweetie 2 is similar to what many of the best authors do in their writing. Some authors lay out plainly points 1, 2, 3, and 4, so we, the readers, are sure to be with them when they reach the height of point 5.

But, in my estimation, only the best writers have the skill to skip 2 and 4 while still bringing us to 5  their prose alludes to the missing pockets of plot just right so that we figure it out on our own. And this they do without us realizing, because though we were actually led by the writer, we feel like smarter readers.

It is in this regard that software developers are not unlike writers. But instead of a plot they have a feature set, and instead of prose, a UI. The developer can lay out the whole of their feature set before the user with menus, sub-menus, and more. Or they can hide pieces of it hoping that each feature will be discovered, but knowing that perhaps they wont.

But ignorance can still be bliss, because in my book a simple, well-written application that delights is far better than a feature-rich one which overwhelms. And this is why Tweetie 2 is not just my favorite Twitter application on any platform, period, it may also just be my favorite iPhone app.</div></blockquote>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>977</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-10-22 11:14:51</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>features-are-plot-ui-is-prose</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

	<item>
		<title>Epipheo</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/epipheo/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 24 Oct 2009 11:40:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=981</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The animation on the home page of AG is truly excellent. I've seen very few animations in the same class.

But <a href="http://lifehacker.com/5372987/two%20minute-video-makes-a-lot-of-sense-of-google-wave">this one</a> is definitely worth a look.
<p style="text-align: center;"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-982" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2009/10/epipheo.jpg" alt="epipheo" /></p>
Rebecca posted it to Yammer a while back and it's from <a href="http://epipheostudios.com/">Epipheo Studios</a>, a company focused on creating explanatory videos. They boil the bulk of a <a href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v_UyVmITiYQ&amp;feature=player_embedded">90 minute presentation</a> down to two minutes, without rushing. Their statement of the problem is especially good. I think they really understand that problem, and I wonder how well they do as a business explaining problems they don't actually have.

I can't help but want to see them take on something like...legislative process.

Thanks Rebecca!]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>74</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Melissa Mashburn]]></wp:comment_author>

	<item>
		<title>We are a start-up.</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/we-are-a-start-up/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 27 Oct 2009 11:25:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=988</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.paulgraham.com/really.html">Unusually well-informed and plain spoken article on start-ups</a>. This article rings true in ways that only lots of personal experience can. Amazingly well distilled. One quick excerpt to whet your appetite:
<blockquote><span style="font-family: verdana;font-size: x-small">Unconsciously, everyone expects a startup to be like a job, and that explains most of the surprises.  It explains why people are surprised how carefully you have to choose cofounders and how hard you have to work to maintain your relationship.  You don't have to do that with coworkers.  It explains why the ups and downs are surprisingly extreme.  In a job there is much more damping.  But it also explains why the good times are surprisingly good: most people can't imagine such freedom.  As you go down the list, almost all the surprises are surprising in how much a startup differs from a job.</span>

<span style="font-family: verdana;font-size: x-small">You probably can't overcome anything so pervasive as the model of work you grew up with. So the best solution is to be consciously aware of that. </span></blockquote>
Really, really good stuff. All the items seem imminently relevant to everything we're doing. But a few of these truths drive decisions every day -- in particular:

<strong>#4 "It can be fun" </strong>
Relates directly to the "move the needle" conversation. Once you see how you're fitting into the whole and are convinced you're doing the coolest possible thing, life gets more fun.

<strong>#8 "Start with Something Minimal"</strong>
Get a simple version up, then revise and revise and revise.

<strong>#9 "Engage Users" </strong>
Which is why we are all so desperate to get, remember and act upon feedback from any and all conversations with profs.

And finally <strong>#10 "Change Your Idea"</strong>
I'm so firmly convinced we haven't solved our problems yet that I get nervous when we're not constantly revising. We have to try many alternatives, and we have to figure out as quickly as possible what's working and what's not. A good item to add to every kick-off meeting might be "how will we know if this works or not?"

The stuff on investors is not so relevant yet -- Dan is truly unlike anything I've ever read about investors and a daily blessing to us all.  Granted, to make Soomo all it can be, we may one day need additional investment, but for today let's just be thankful for Dan and make all the hay we can in this extraordinary season.

Quite a few of the other items are timely reminders that what we're experiencing is part of life in most start-ups and the way through it requires a lot of hard work with a strong sense of urgency. Revolutionizing a market is hard. Success is not guaranteed, but we have a truly amazing opportunity here.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Buttonology</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/10/buttonology/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 28 Oct 2009 11:32:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=995</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Last week Christian Pruett, the tech lead for all 15 CC campuses in MS, made a really nice distinction between buttonology and pedagogy. His point was that telling a prof what all the buttons in Bb do is not really a service. Telling them how they might use Bb to teach, now that's helpful.

It's really the difference between:
- talking about technology and
- talking about teaching, while being informed about technology.

This was a great reminder (especially while writing ag.com) that the more we focus on "how you use this to teach" the more helpful, useful and understandable we are.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Decisions on the Fly</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/11/decisions-on-the-fly/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Nov 2009 15:32:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>rebeccasmithshelley</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=999</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.inc.com/magazine/20091101/the-way-i-work-jason-fried-of-37signals.html">This article</a> (found through my friend <a href="http://work.ableparris.com/">Able</a>, who designed some NWLM screens for us) profiles 37Signals founder Jason Fried, and highlights an interesting corporate culture and working style. Here's a piece that sounded familiar:
<blockquote>We don't have big, long-term plans, because they're scary -- and they're usually wrong. Making massive decisions keeps people up at night -- I don't like to make those. The closer you can get to understanding what that next moment might be, the less worried you are. Most of the decisions we make are in the moment, on the fly, as we go.</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Changes</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/11/changes/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 04 Nov 2009 15:36:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>matt bennink</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1005</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Here's a rundown on some changes that will be rolling out soon.
<ol>
	<li>Numbers in the URLs
<ul>
	<li>These are used to identify the course, chapter, and assignment and will help reduce errors when multiple windows/tabs are open.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>Redirects
<ul>
	<li>If there is only one chapter in a course, you will be redirected to that chapter and unable to view the Table of Contents page.</li>
	<li>If there is only one assignment in a course, you will be redirected to that assignment and unable to view the Table of Contents or Chapter pages.</li>
	<li>If the requested chapter/assignment is not found, you will be redirected to something that is found. For example, if an assignment is not found, you will be redirected to the chapter. This should only happen if you open a saved bookmark and the content has been removed.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>Custom Assignment Editor
<ul>
	<li>The editor has been changed from dojo to tinyMCE.  This shouldn't affect editing, but it will look different from the old editor.</li>
	<li>A preview button has been added to allow you to view your changes before saving them.  This way you won't need to Save/Student View/(Look at changes)/Edit.  [Note: Does not work in Safari.. yet!]</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
Hopefully these changes will be a good thing.  They are currently on Staging, so feel free to take a look.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Fabulous</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/11/fabulous/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 08 Nov 2009 23:21:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1110</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2009/11/fabulous.html">Seth's post today</a>:

<strong>Fabulous</strong>

This is so cool: because we only look at things we want to look at, only talk about things worth talking about, the amount of fabulous in the world continues to rise exponentially.

Even though we're at the tail end of the great recession, think about all the cool stuff in your life. Not just stuff you can buy, but experiences, works of art, innovations of all kinds... the bar has been raised for what you need to do to be noticed, and the market is responding.

Not only do I notice more fabulous, but it sure seems as though the creators of it are more engaged, dedicated and yes, joyful, than I can remember. If there was ever a moment to follow your passion and do work that matters, this is it. You can't say, "but I need to make a fortune instead," because that's not happening right now. So you might as well join the people who can say, "I love doing this."]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Sketching Experience</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/11/sketching-experience/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 12 Nov 2009 12:03:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1018</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Buxton:
<blockquote>The underlying premise of this book is that there are techniques and processes whereby we can put experience front and center in design. My belief is that the basis for doing so lies in extending the traditional practice of sketching. (p9)</blockquote>
To speak from a Buxtonian perspective, we (Soomo) do not design frameworks or content. We design experiences, which we call learning interactions. In Buxtons words, we design to create
<blockquote>the behavioral, experiential, and emotional responses that come about as a result of [our learning interactions] existence and its use in the real world. (p10)</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Sketch to Think</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/11/sketching-user-experience/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Nov 2009 12:40:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1023</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><em>Sketching User Experience: Getting the Design Right, and the Right Design</em>
Bill Buxton</strong>

Buxtons occupation comes through in his writing. He authors from the perspective of someone who spends half his time justifying the practice of formal design to a skeptical, if not hostile, organization and the other half of his time finding cites and precedent to make his point.

The book's title is an excellent representation of the text:

- we design experiences, not products or interfaces

- sketching helps you think, which produces better designs

- getting the design right is only half the battle, the other half is making sure you are designing the right thing.

His central arguments are:


<blockquote><br /><strong>Think before you build.</strong>
<br /><strong>Sketching helps you think.</strong></blockquote>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

	<item>
		<title>Sketch v. Prototype</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/12/sketch-v-prototype/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 Dec 2009 12:41:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1025</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Loving this distinction.

<h3>- Sketch: a tool for thinking.

- Prototype: a tool for explaining.</h3>

And so on. Much to plumb here. I enjoy the way this helps us to see sketching not as something done exclusively with pencil and paper, but as a category of activities which are light, tentative and exploratory.
<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/11/sketchvprototype.jpg" border="0" alt="sketchvprototype.jpg" width="400" height="382" /></div>
btw: this page of the book is yet another example of a style I think we will emulate in our study notes  there is something warm and compelling about great handwritting.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1025</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-12-01 07:41:19</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-12-01 12:41:19</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>sketch-v-prototype</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="design"><![CDATA[design]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>91</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[rebeccasmithshelley]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>rebecca@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-12-14 17:11:42</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[So using this model, when we say we're going to "spec" something under development, are we sketching or prototyping? Seems that the initial meeting is a sketch, but the final spec that goes out to everyone is a prototype? Also revealing to think about how these two concepts fit into our "three essential meetings" scheme.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>92</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Lindrum]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>david@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>65.14.229.26</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2009-12-15 17:49:39</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2009-12-15 22:49:39</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Great questions.

The first meeting, the kick off, is "problem setting" -- that is, defining the problem we are seeking to solve.

Early design work is sketching, later is prototyping.

A prototype, if needed, is what is brought to the second meeting for design review.

A spec is just a written description of the solution we're about to build.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Expanding v. Contracting Our Options</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/11/expanding-v-contracting-our-options/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 17 Nov 2009 12:42:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1027</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When we start thinking about a problem, we generate lots of ideas  we expand our list of options. This is classic brainstorming: dont shut anything down, let the creative juices flow, talk in a group and say the silly stuff which at the least might trigger others. The goal is to generate options, make connections, blow the walls off the box and come up with an abundance of options.

Then we stop and contract. With the table or whiteboard or sketch book covered with ideas we return to our central problem. Which of these is most likely to work well? Which seems most useful? And we narrow our choices. We throw some out and pick a couple candidates that seem likely to work.

Then we look at those candidates and start expanding on them, moving out of a winnowing posture and into a new, more focused, brainstorm thinking through options of how to make the most of these. This thinking might take us to entirely new options or it might just push us to think further about what is in front of us, deeper and more fully seeing the potential of the rough idea, polishing, evolving, refining.

Then we contract again.

Once Bill described this process, life got less confusing. As we worked on Comp I could see that some days we were in expansion and others we were in contraction. And if one person is trying to expand while another is trying to contract, things dont go so well.

Bills graph also helps me understand I am not going in circles as I keep coming back to idea generation. And I suppose it also helps me see when I am going in circles because the focus never comes.

In support of sketching, it also helps me see that in the early phases I dont have to think too deeply about any one option. I can rest in confidence that well hit that later. And it helps me head off the impulse to rethink everything when we are on the fifth contraction and moving into a time of polish. (When I start rethinking everything at that point, its usually a form of procrastination growing out of fear that Im not up to providing the polish now needed.)

A working understanding of expanding and contracting in cycles will help us, I think, to think about inventive work, to talk about it and to be at peace with it.


<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/11/winnowing.jpg" alt="winnowing.jpg" border="0" width="400" height="589" /></div>
(p 148)]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Design is Choice</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/11/design-is-choice/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 Nov 2009 12:42:33 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1029</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Buxton dances in some unnecessary and ambiguous ways trying to avoid a definition of design." He redeems himself, however, when he says simply that design is choice (p145) a definition that has long worked well for me.

When we are designing, we are choosing this over that for some reason. Which is why we cant make any choices until we know the goal.

Design is sometimes described as art with a purpose. And so it is. It is the specified purpose that enables the act we call design. Design is always strategic, that is, it is always a choosing of this over that for some specific purpose.

New to me is Bills identification of two different types of brainstorming or idea generation inherent in this view of design. To paraphrase:

<blockquote>There are two places where there is room for creativity:

1. generating meaningfully distinct options from which to choose

2. generating meaningful criteria to use when making your choices
</blockquote>

This makes a lot of sense to me. Im always nervous going with one option without having considered others because I know we can almost always do better than our first option. And having the right criteria in mind as we choose from among the options is, obviously, essential.

Just calling something a "first draft" implies another effort will improve it. But until Bill articulated this second creative font I completely missed that the first criteria which jump to mind are rather unlikely to be the best criteria to use, and further thinking or brainstorming here will result in a better frame for evaluation.

<strong>Example:</strong><br />In Comp we generated multiple wireframes for the home page trying to find the right mix. But we did not generate multiple sets of criteria to use when evaluating that page. When we went out to talk to professors, those multiple sets of criteria showed up and guided us to see both what was working and what wasn't in light of very specific use cases.

<strong>Strategy:</strong><br />Create multiple user stories, personas and use cases to think through as we evaluate a particular interface or content option.


This idea is closely related to  Expand and Contract. Bill quotes Paul Valery to make a point Tim Jones has been making for years:

<blockquote>Invention depends on two processes. The first generates a collection of alternatives, the other chooses, recognizing what is desirable and appears to be important among that produced by the first. What one calls genius is much less the contribution of the first, the one that collects alternatives, then the facility of the second in recognizing the value in what has been presented, and seizing upon it. (Translation: Bill Buxton) p.145
</blockquote>

Which is why Tims highest praise is, They made some nice choices.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Customer Needs</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/11/customer-needs/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 Nov 2009 12:42:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1031</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Buxton sets the scene in Cupertino, 1996. Jobs has been hired to turn Apple around. His second day on the job he calls in key members of the press, one of whom describes it this way:

<blockquote>[Jobs] specifically emphasized getting back to meeting the needs of their core customers and said that Apple had lost ground in the market because they were trying to be everything to everybody instead of focusing on the real needs of their customers.
</blockquote>


We are increasingly pulled to consider audiences beyond our original use case of students and professors in traditional classrooms, small enough to engage in vigorous discussion. We are increasingly called to also think about large classes of 100 or more students with no room for discussion. Distance education, with no physical meeting, provides yet another distinct use case. History and Stats are among our current efforts to consider first the needs of those interested in placing their own content in our system with no instructional design or new media development by us.

These additional scenarios are not necessarily bad things. Ideally one or more will become a crucial part of our success. However each new use case threatens to dilute our focus and makes consideration of a concrete use case more challenging. Adding disciplines will stretch us. But adding new types of customers will stretch us more, require new rigor in our thinking and frequent checks of our next actions against our touchstone values.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Problem Solving v. Problem Setting</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/12/problem-solving-v-problem-setting/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 08 Dec 2009 12:42:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1033</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Bill Buxton makes a great distinction on page 78, with credit to Donald Schon, on the difference between problem solving and problem setting.

<blockquote>    Problem solving: How should we build this?
    Problem setting: What should we build?</blockquote>

He notes the common experience of not really knowing what youre building until youve finished building it. Which weve experienced. Kick off meetings are all about problem-setting. Awareness of this will perhaps lead us to build lightly at first, knowing we are feeling our way in the dark, and then to be less hesitant in starting over when needed.

Buxton warns against letting problem-setting fall off the agenda  and this I am all too familiar with.

Failure here can flow as follows:

<blockquote>Articulate the problem, go to work on a design and let the design take on a life of its own, evolving with ever more distance from the original problem, ultimately creating an attractive or efficient design that is of little or no use.
</blockquote>

Success here looks like:

<blockquote>Test each new design against the perspective of real users and allow design iterations to reshape our thinking, change our metaphors, and lead us to better understand the problem.
</blockquote>

<strong>Example:</strong><br />In comp we saw up to four channels of independent content being used at various rates and built a TOC to match. As we revisited the real needs of students, we saw the need to harmonize these flows and realized the TOC was perhaps not a view of four channels as options so much as a highly directed list of todos. Switching our understanding from dashboard of options to todo list was quite helpful and wouldnt have happened without ongoing problem setting.

<div style="text-align:center"><img src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/11/nwlm.png" alt="nwlm.png" border="0" width="400" height="267" /></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1033</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>problem-solving-v-problem-setting</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="design"><![CDATA[design]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>From Idea to Product</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/12/from-idea-to-product/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 15 Dec 2009 12:43:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1035</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>It takes even more creativity to productize a good idea than it does to have the idea in the first place. <br />Buxton, p 223</blockquote>

He says it like its a surprise. And I guess it is foreign to mainstream culture in which the Inventor version of the Great American Dream is to come up with a great idea, sell it and make millions. For example, I have a friend who knows the guy who patented the idea to put a plastic lid on spice jar so you could shake out the spice and, as a result of this idea, made millions.

Of course, thousands of people may well have had that idea. For an idea to become truly useful it needs to be combined with thousands of other creative ideas, actions, relationships and solved problems. What is amazing to me is that this guy worked out the practical side from compelling prototype through all the problems involved in manufacturing and use (choking hazard, toxic plastics, arthritic hands, etc.) managed to get the meeting with McCormick or whoever cut the first check and put together a deal that traded a big check up front for micro-payments per jar far into the future.

The myth is that one person with one idea can create value. The fact is that generating substantial value requires thousands of ideas from many people all heading in the same general direction, collectively solving problems at every point along the way: prototype, design, construction, partnering, project management, pricing, marketing, finance, sourcing, support - thousands of solutions without overlooking any of the dozens of potential blind spots.

Soomo is in fact about great assignments which invite transformative learning. But for this to really happen in the life of a student requires additional expertise in all the processes, tools and efforts required to find, develop, host, support and market great assignments beautifully. And the system that hosts them. And explain it all to professors so they can choose it, assign it and use it effectively. All on a limited budget in a non-obvious sequence.

Productize is a hideous word. But Bills point is well-taken that while a great idea is a beautiful creative stroke, there is far more creativity required before real value is delivered to real people in a financially sustainable manner.  For us these additional challenges include everything from pedagogy to button names, recruiting the right reviewers, creating maintainable code, pricing, telling our story well, solid release notes, moving film making, memorable illustration, faultless bookkeeping right on down the line to, after weve done everything else right, dealing well with a cranky professor in Ohio.

Heres to all the things we have been given the ability to do well in support of a great learning experience.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>The World is Broken</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/12/the-world-is-broken/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 10 Dec 2009 12:43:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1037</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[On page 45 Buxton reminds us

<blockquote>Things will not always go right, and you have to factor that into your plannot as an error, but as a valuable (and expensive) learning experience. </blockquote>

One of the nice things about assuming there will be iteration is that you can include time for things to "not go right" as you move into the next revision. Estimating total time to build once perfectly and then adding a 30% contingency is not nearly as accommodating (or wise) as estimating the total time to build a first, then a second and then a third version. And, if were taking each version seriously and evaluating it wisely, that third version should be pretty good.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Better Ideas</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/12/better-ideas/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 03 Dec 2009 12:43:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1039</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote><h4>one of the most positive forms of criticism is a better idea, and frequently, that better idea would never have come about were it not for the idea that it replaces.</h4>

Bill Buxton (p 51)</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1039</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-12-03 07:43:31</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-12-03 12:43:31</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>better-ideas</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="design"><![CDATA[design]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
		<title>The Thesis</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/12/the-thesis/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 17 Dec 2009 12:43:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1041</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As he nears the end of Part I, p 201 to be precise, Buxton offers a succinct summary of the first half of the book. (Upon which I have elaborated, ever so slightly, below.)

- The nature of design (is making choices)

- The importance of sketching (its how we think)

- The plurality and variation of approaches that sketching affords (lots of ways to sketch a cat)

- The capacity forannotation. (Bill likes annotation on his sketches as a visible representation of reactions)

- The social nature of design (if we can share sketches, we can design together)

- The importance of having persistent displays (tape designs to your wall and live with them)

- the fundamental role of critique in design education (He's a little ahead of himself here, he hasnt been talking about it yet, but he dives in next and does a nice job with it.)

He goes on to say,

<blockquote>Due to its speed and low cost, sketching affords us the luxury of exploring a range of different solutions to any problem that we are confronting. In this process, the sketches do far more than just capture ideas. Through the process of their creation, and the conversations they facilitate, they are also a key vehicle for their generation and communication.
</blockquote>

And a little later on,

<blockquote>Taken together, all this serves the purpose of affording, encouraging, and enriching the conversations we have with ourselves, our sketches, our colleagues and our clients. From my perspective, such conversations are the essence of design thinking and the design process.
</blockquote>

He means it. That should be on the back of the book  it is the heart and soul of his project.

To condense even further: <strong><br />sketch as a means to think, <br />as a means to share your thoughts and <br />as a way to invite others to work with you on a particular design problem. </strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1041</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>the-thesis</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
		<title>Applied Knowledge Scenarios</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/11/applied-knowledge-scenarios/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 11 Nov 2009 12:49:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1113</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>We are emphasizing example sentences because we know thats how people learn words  by seeing them in context. How many of the last 20 words you learned were learned by reading a dictionary definition? More context equals more learning.
-- <a href="http://bit.ly/3GvQZR">Erin McKean in this remarkable interview</a></blockquote>

Last week, discussing cell structure and function with Kathi, we began talking about the importance of "applied knowledge scenarios." Not a very pretty name, but perhaps a rather important idea. Erin McKean's point about dictionaries is that they're useful reference, but not geared for learning. We're more likely to learn by seeing knowledge used than by seeing it coldly presented.

This ties to what Christian Pruett said in Mississippi about the difference between "buttonology" introductions to Blackboard and real instruction on how to put it to use for teaching. It's the difference between "how one uses this" which is often a list of features and "how I use this" which is often a personal case study.

We've been bumping around this idea for years in AG, but perhaps naming it and working with it explicitly would enable us to offer some nice innovations. For example, in the rhetoric for NWLM, we do provide examples. But maybe we need to provide a lot more -- maybe the examples are doing all the teaching and the rule or presentation of the facts is just there as a convenient abstract handle. Maybe interviews in AG work because all the information is applied, and if we accompanied them with the facts and definitions, to be reviewed afterwards, those facts and definitions would have more value? We've long said "we're putting pictures in the student's mental dictionary" - maybe the move to etext means we add the definition too.

I suspect I'm barely scratching the surface here, but already trying your patience, dear reader. And while much of this is likely common sense and widely practiced, there's something about it that I suspect is new as well. Eager to get back to a specific scenario in which we can seek to apply this knowledge.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Friday with Seth</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/11/friday-with-seth/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Nov 2009 10:43:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1179</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[He's shorter than I thought he'd be. But exceptionally nice. It was a bit surreal and I repeatedly realized "oh, that's a real person in the room with us" as opposed to a voice for an audio book or in a TED lecture or something.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-1182" src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2009/11/seth-group.jpg" alt="seth group" width="564" height="423" />

The common thread through all Seth's book is a worldview -- he has some beliefs/insights about how things work now and they are at odds with how they used to work. His beliefs, such as the new found importance of word of mouth as we become numb to ads, fits with my experience better than any thing else I've heard.

The most notable thing about the day's conversation is that his worldview is stronger, more present and/or easier to share in person than it is in books and web lectures. In retrospect this seems obvious. And the bottom line is, he was just like Seth only more so.

<strong>What did Seth say we should do?</strong>
Nothing specific. Seth is mostly about helping people see the way things are now, not giving step-by-step direction. And there wasn't time to really describe any of our situations adequately for any specific consulting.

<strong>Was it just what's in his books?</strong>
Thankfully, no. Because of the concrete case study each of us represented this was a very pragmatic conversation, and pragmatism is the enemy of dogmatism. So instead of speaking to a hypothetical audience of marketers banking on ads (i.e. who Seth used to be), we were having a conversation among earnest business people who've already sign off on this approach. As a result it was far more appropriate to acknowledge the legitimate roles of ads, lead generation, sales and so on.

<strong>New insights?</strong>
His attention to measuring effectiveness was compelling, and if it's in the books I missed it. Perhaps he takes it for granted that we would, of course, be doing that. Counting what works and comparing the outcomes of various methods seems useful, possible and important.

<strong>What now?</strong>
Perhaps the creme of the day was in the questions he posed. These are really strong questions that would benefit us, but there's little point in me answering them by myself. We're too much of a team for that now. A sales meeting in December would probably be the best venue: probably right before Christmas.

<strong>Bottom Line</strong>
The single biggest takeaway for me was a sense that I haven't really committed to any one, two or even three marketing/sales strategies. I feel like a big fat dabbler on a dozen fronts. And Seth, speaking to a bunch of people already in basic agreement with him, is all about putting it to work. Make a few, intentional, bold commitments and give it all you've got. You must get feedback and stop what isn't working. But you must try boldly. Now.

[<em>Thank you Dan for this opportunity. It was extraordinarily helpful, did much to temper Seth's sometimes polemic voice, and much to reveal what he was taking for granted that we already knew (but I didn't.) It was especially helpful to meet other people who have already built successful businesses informed by some of these assumptions about how the world works. It really does seem possible to do things well and still be profitable.</em>] ]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Three Essential Meetings</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2009/11/three-essential-meetings/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Nov 2009 11:00:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1187</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[A few weeks ago we launched a new routine for projects designed to increase communication across the team, get the best input from each other as early as possible, and give us a chance to think through some key questions for each project. Personally, in the urgency of daily action, I tend to forget why we have these meetings. Which is why the structure is so important. What follows are a few notes I made to myself to remind me of why I need these meetings and what each is intended to accomplish. Perhaps these notes will be helpful to others as well.

<strong>Kick Off</strong>
- why are we doing this?
- how will we measure success?
- when will the design be done?

Brings together all stakeholders (everyone who cares about the outcome of a project) and key participants (people who will lead some phase) to discuss the purpose of the product, key timing and what success looks like. An opportunity to present and discuss the project goals. If the goals are off, in the mind of any stakeholder or key participant, catch it now.

<strong>Design Review</strong>
- will this design meet the project's goals?
- is this the best possible design, given our constraints?
- do we have the resources to complete this project as designed?
- when will the project be complete?

Brings the same folks back together to look at a plan to meet the goals already established. A chance to remember those goals, which are now better understood and driving a plan. This is an opportunity to share the plan, improve it, establish a schedule and all agree that if this design is executed, the needs will be met.

<strong>Pre-Release Meeting</strong>
- did we meet our project goals?
- any reason this shouldn't be released?
- how can we make the most of it when it is released?
- when will we have some results?

When the project is essentially completed, but before it's due to be released, is the time for another review by all stakeholders. Now that we can see it, what could we do briefly that would make it dramatically better? This meeting needs to allow time for some minor revision before public release.

Every project should have these three meetings. They often seem unnecessary and I am almost always tempted to skip them. And then I see that I am, once again, building the wrong thing, building it inefficiently or in a crisis-creating schedule or releasing without having sought wise input from people already on our team.

Two rules of thumb:
- A "project" is anything requiring several hours and/or help from others to complete.
- If it's a project, it goes in projectpath and gets all three meetings, though they can be very informal.

Today is a good day to figure out which meeting is next for each of your projects, and get at least that one next meeting onto the calendar.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1187</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2009-11-30 06:00:28</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2009-11-30 11:00:28</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>three-essential-meetings</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Page One</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/01/page-one/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 01 Jan 2010 10:59:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1207</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[What is the value in reading a post? Often it's not in what the post says as much as what the post triggers; what you think about as a result of reading. A value deep within the design of Soomo is that questions are, if not more valuable than answers, at least essential precursors to really getting a hold of the answers in a meaningful way.

<em>Tribes</em> is quite intentionally not a book of answers. Seth's goal is to reorient us from mass marketers to leaders of a tribe. The big questions of "is he worth listening to" or "is this relevant in our market" are valid, but are ultimately answered in thousands of smaller questions. Are the questions he asks us worth our consideration?

Let's float a few and see. Feel free to react in the comments section, in email, on the phone, in the hall or not at all.

From Tribes:
<blockquote>While Joel runs a small software company in New York City, his real passion is in talking about <em>how</em> to run a small software company. (p1)</blockquote>
Soomo is a small publishing company, but much of our passion is on two related fronts.

For those of you from publishing, "What's the right way to run a small publishing company? How should publishing be done? What practices, common in the big houses, should be revised, reformed or destroyed? In sales and editorial, from product development to organizational design, what would you change if you could?"

For everyone, "What constitutes the ideal out-of-class resource?" (Asking, "how can you put a textbook online" tends to lead to PDFs. Go deeper.) What do you most need between classes? Which course was your toughest and what would have helped? Which courses changed your life and why did they do so? What might have made that change even greater? How do you learn things outside of school and does that inform how you would like to learn in school?

What if our business was being a publisher but our real passion was talking about revolutionizing textbooks? What would you talk about?

We're seeing more than a new year dawn this morning -- it feels like a new age in which Kindles are the equivalent of an AM radio, a silent movie or fuzzy black and white TV. What should homework look like now? And what should characterize the organization optimized to create it?]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>95</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Matt Bennink]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>matt@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>97.89.176.98</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-01-04 14:53:16</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-01-04 19:53:16</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I learn by doing.  "Doing" enhances my understanding of a particular domain of knowledge because I can explore that domain myself; I choose where I will go next.

My ideal out-of-class resource is something that makes me think.  It asks questions.  It leads me to find underlying themes.  It is also completely dependent on the subject.  Economics is different from Comp Sci, which is further different from Literature, Biology, and History.

So, what do I need in a resource?

I need repetition.  I need to see and do the same thing over and over throughout the semester.

I need discussion among my peers and teachers.  As an introvert, I tend to think in my head and even days after the fact.  I need to be able to process these thoughts 3 days after the lecture has been given.

I need a playground.  I need a place to practice programming.  I need to perform experiments without access to a lab.  I need a driving simulator when a car isn't available.

I need involvement.

Now, only to figure out what this resource (or resources??) might look like...]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>For Rent</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/01/for-rent/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Jan 2010 12:21:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1222</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When people complain about the costs of textbooks, they tend to cite the price of a new text - something over $100.

The majority of books purchased are used (by many accounts including MIR data) and prices for used texts in American Government, for example, are typically closer to $80 than to the $130 price on a new leading text.

When digital texts are offered at half retail, say $65, the math often cited gets wonkier and people tend to throw up hypotheticals such as a $100 text can be sold back for $50 (which is rarely true) so the real cost is $50. So a digital text for $65 is actually more expensive.

Fuzzy numbers aside, the implicit calculations on purchase price minus sell price is that books are rented more than they are bought. What if the student only paid the marginal price and at the end of the semester turned the book back in? Would that work? What kind of behavior would this encourage for faculty, publishers and students? Would it be a better deal? A cheaper book long term?

Quite a few people are aggressively entering this space. Dan discovered this <a href="http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2010/01/12/rent">Inside Higher Ed</a> article offering an unusually complete survey of this emerging rental landscape.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Giving Experience</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/01/giving-experience/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 14 Jan 2010 12:51:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Discussing photography, Susan Sontag reminds us of what we do when we create an assignment:
<blockquote><span>By giving us an immense amount of experience that normally is not our experience. And by making a selection of experience which is very tendentious, ideological. While there appears to be nothing that photography cant devour, whatever cant be photographed becomes less important.</span></blockquote>
from <a href="http://bostonreview.net/BR01.1/sontag.php">this interview</a> (via <a href="http://bobulate.com/post/325177207/the-parts-and-wholes-of-photography">bobulate</a>)]]></content:encoded>
