	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Soomo Notifications</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/01/soomo-notifications/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 18 Jan 2010 16:23:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>matt bennink</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1233</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[If you've spent any time on Yammer in the last week, you've met App Robot. App Robot is one part of a bigger whole - Soomo Notifications.

Soomo Notifications is a system within our app which sends notifications based on events. Here, a notification is an e-mail, Yammer post, or possibly even a Splash page shown to the user upon login. An event is an <strong>action</strong> occurring at an <strong>instance in time</strong>. A student registering at 10:40pm or a new assignment made available in the catalog at 8:00am are possible events.

This is perhaps best understood with an example. Suppose we want to be notified by Yammer each time a student registers - soon to premiere until everyone is sick of how many students are registering. What must be done?
<ol>
	<li>A <em>StudentRegistered </em>class must be created which provides access to the event's context. The context here is the <strong>time of the registration</strong> and the <strong>title</strong> (Americans Governing, Nobody Writes Like Me, etc).</li>
	<li>A notification template must be created which provides the subject/body and delivery type of any notifications. An example template for the body a Yammer post is given below. Notice how the context is used?</li>
<blockquote>"Another student registered for {{event.title.name}}!"</blockquote>
	<li>Code must be inserted to record the event in the application. This looks like <em>StudentRegistered</em>.fire!(<em>title</em>) -- a single line of code inserted just after a student registers.</li>
</ol>
And that's it! Now, whenever a student registers, a Yammer post will be generated from the notification template.

Only thing unmentioned is the event subscription process. This didn't apply above because, at the moment, we assume all Yammer users care about Yammer notifications. However, for notifications via e-mail or Splash pages at login, we must have a method for determining who should be notified. For this, we have event subscriptions where a user can subscribe to specific event types.

For example, assume we create an event called <em>MaintenanceTaskComplete</em> which is fired each time a maintenance task of some sort completes. Let's also assume a template is created which sends an e-mail with the subject "Maintenance Task Complete" and the body "Maintenace Task {{event.task.name}} completed at {{event.task.time_completed}}.". I can then subscribe to the <em>MaintenanceTaskComplete</em> event and I will be notified via e-mail whenever a maintenance task is complete.

It's a bit difficult to explain entirely, but I hope the above makes sense to you. The next step is to create a list of events that we are interested in, and then start inserting them into the application. Student registrations is one idea, notifying of updates to the catalog is another. What else?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1233</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-01-18 11:23:15</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-01-18 16:23:15</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>soomo-notifications</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="site-enhancements"><![CDATA[Site Enhancements]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>

			<wp:comment_author_email>david@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>97.95.232.164</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-01-19 09:12:47</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-01-19 14:12:47</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Fabulous Matt! Thanks.

Here's a stat I've long been craving. What if early each morning the App Robot rolled up the previous day? E.g. Yesterday:
- 55 students subscribed to Americans Governing
- 10 subscribed to NWLM
- 5 new courses were created for AG
- 473 quizzes were completed
maybe even
- 59M of data were served or 3062 pages were viewed..
All of these stats have the same goal -- give us a window on the real people out there using our stuff everyday. We really only glimpse them at conferences, but the fact is that every day there are literally thousands of students doing (or putting off) a soomo assignment. And that's something we should stay in touch with.

Thanks Matt (and David) for great functionality and documentation even I can follow.]]></wp:comment_content>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Your Tribes</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/01/your-tribes/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 21 Jan 2010 14:54:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1237</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Forget Soomo for a minute.

Sometime in the next few days, perhaps over the weekend, ask yourself, "To which tribes do I belong?"

Personally, I'm not sure I want to admit to any -- I'm no lemming. But I'd probably get called out as a member of the Apple tribe. I read their spam to me. I read news about them. I actually do respect much of what they do as a business. So...I think I'm probably in that tribe. Likewise for Patagonia. Maybe Ikea.

Beyond businesses, the leaders I am quickest to seek out include Drucker and Godin. I suppose I'm in tribes there as well - though I'm not communicating with other members and I'm not in the market for a tattoo of either. I bristle at the thought of being a "Drucker follower" but when I have questions I do find him to be one of the sanest voices out there.

"Tribe" might be too strong a word for a businesses that is simply my default (Nordstom) or where I frequent (Over Easy) or am eager to share with others (12 Bones). But I am a fan of each of these. They have established a vibe, outlook, product and experience that fits with (and inevitably shapes) my sense of what I want.

What about you? Who are your defaults? Who do you trust? Who's spam (email) and catalogs (junk mail) do you read? What tribes are you in? How can you tell? And how did you get there?]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Released:  Fix to prof registration email goofication</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/03/released-fix-to-prof-registration-email-goofication/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 02 Mar 2010 23:00:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1277</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Here's a strange one: When a prof would register using an email address that we already had registered as a student - havoc would ensue. Now they get this tidy message:

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1278" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/03/Registration.jpg" alt="Registration" />]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1277</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-03-02 18:00:49</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-03-02 23:00:49</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>released-fix-to-prof-registration-email-goofication</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="released"><![CDATA[Released!]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

		<title>Notebook adjustments by Matt</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/03/notebook-adjustments-by-matt/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 05 Mar 2010 22:15:04 +0000</pubDate>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Matt made some simple adjustments to the behavior of the notebook that really matter to real professors.

When a professor views the notebook, the time stamp reflects the last time a student edited their answer. Also, the reference answers are hidden by default. Professors ask, Soomo answers!

	<item>
		<title>Lifecycle of a bug fix</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/03/lifecycle-of-a-bug-fix/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 09 Mar 2010 20:58:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1315</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Reported by Michael at <strong>2:25 pm</strong> - I found a dead link and it's stinking up the place.

Verified by Tom at <strong>2:27 pm</strong> - It's dead and that stinks.

Reported to Melissa at<strong> 2:28 pm</strong> - "Melissa, a zombie assignment is on the loose and frightening educators in South Carolina."

Verified and handed to Rebecca at<strong> 2:30 pm </strong>"Rebecca, zombie assignment, do your magic!"

Fixed and passed back to Tom at <strong>2:32 pm</strong> - "Tom, I fixed it and it's ready for publication."

Verified and published to all active and catalog courses at <strong>2:35 pm</strong>.

Nice one team!]]></content:encoded>

Good writing and lots of interesting parallels to the communicative complexity of building a webtext publishing house.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Linchpin</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/03/linchpin/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 12 Mar 2010 17:11:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1323</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Another candidate for what we might read together next. Any interest in <a href="http://bit.ly/d0B6gJ">Seth's latest book</a>?

This one is not about marketing, but instead is about understanding the nature of work and the questions we should ask ourselves to ascertain how our work might become more meaningful and, through that, make our work more valuable to ourselves and to our organization.

The beginning of the reviews from Amazon:
<blockquote>This is by far Seths most passionate book. Hes pulling fewer punches. Hes out for blood. Hes out to make a difference. And that glorious, heartfelt passion is obvious on every page, even if it is in Seths usual quiet, lucid, understated manner.

A linchpin, as Seth describes it, is somebody in an organization who is indispensable, who cannot be replacedher role is just far too unique and valuable. And then he goes on to say, well, seriously folks, you need to be one of these people, you really do. To not be one is economic and career suicide.

No surprises therethats exactly what one would expect Seth to say. But heres where it gets interesting.

In his best-known book,  <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Purple-Cow-New-Transform-Remarkable/dp/1591843170"> <em>Purple Cow</em></a>,  Seths message was, Everyones a marketer now. In  <a href="http://www.amazon.com/All-Marketers-Liars-Preface-Works/dp/1591843030"> <em>All Marketers Are Liars</em></a>,  his message was, Everyones a storyteller now. In  <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Tribes-We-Need-You-Lead/dp/1591842336"> <em>Tribes</em></a>,  his message was, Everyones a leader now.

And from <em>Linchpin</em>?

"Everyones an artist now."

By Seths definition, an artist is not just some person who messes around with paint and brushes, an artist is somebody who does (and I LOVE this term) emotional work.

Work that you put your heart and soul into. Work that matters. Work that you gladly sacrifice all other alternatives for. As a working artist and cartoonist myself, I know exactly what he means. Its not what you do, its the way that you do it.

The only people who have a hope of becoming linchpins in any organization, who have any hope of changing anything for the better in real terms, are those who have the capacity to do emotional work at a high levelto be true artists at whatever they set their minds on doing. The guys who just plod around the office corridors, just turning up for their paycheck.... Well, those guys dont have a prayer, poor things. The world is just too interesting and competitive now.

And Seth then challenges us, the readers, to become linchpins ourselves. To make the leap. To become artists. To do emotional work, whatever the sacrifice may be. Its our choice, and its our burden. Seth wont be there to catch us if we fall, but to become the people we need to be eventually, well, we probably wouldnt want him to, anyway.

Congratulations, Seth. You have penned a real gem of a book here. Rock on.

<em>--Hugh MacLeod</em>
<h3>Review</h3>
"It's easy to see why people pay to hear what he has to say."
-<em>Time</em></blockquote>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:post_name>linchpin</wp:post_name>

		<title>Hey Apple Mail users...</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/03/hey-apple-mail-users/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 19 Mar 2010 14:15:18 +0000</pubDate>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Apple Mail remembers who you send mail to and conveniently fills in the address as you type. It goofed me yesterday because I didn't cross check the name and address - who has time for that - my email mail went nowhere.

Turns out, there is a place where you can remove addresses from Mail's memory -Under the Window menu, choose Previous Recipients.

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1336" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/03/Previous-Recipients.jpg" alt="Previous Recipients" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Features and Simplicity</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/04/features-and-simplicity/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 05 Apr 2010 16:10:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>matt bennink</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1406</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[From Douglas Crawford's <span style="text-decoration: underline">Javascript: The Good Parts</span>
<blockquote>"We see a lot of feature-driven product design in which the cost of features is not properly accounted. Features can have a negative value to consumers because they make the products more difficult to understand and use. We are finding that people like products that just work. It turns out that designs that just work are much harder to produce than designs that assemble long lists of features.

Features have a specification cost, a design cost, and a development cost. There is a testing cost and a reliability cost. The more features there are, the more likely one will develop problems or will interact badly with another. ..."

"... in designing products, we want to get the core features - the good parts - right because that is where we create most of the value.

We all find the good parts in the products that we use. We value simplicity, and when simplicity isn't offered to us, we make it ourselves. My microwave oven has tons of features, but the only ones I use are cook and the clock. And setting the clock is a struggle. We cope with the complexity of feature-driven design by finding and sticking with the good parts."</blockquote>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

They aren't simple to navigate, there are too many features (to appease the committee), and their pedagogical structure is lost in the complexity. 	<item>
		<title>The Checklist Manifesto</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/04/the-checklist-manifesto/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 11 Apr 2010 16:15:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1411</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.amazon.com/Checklist-Manifesto-How-Things-Right/dp/0805091742/"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-1414" style="margin-left: 30px; margin-right: 30px;" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/04/checklist.jpg" alt="" /></a>This thought provoking book has the potential to make Soomo stronger, faster, smarter and funner. In this review, I summarize the text, apply it to Soomo and give some back story on a forthcoming emphasis on creating and using checklists. The post is long, but the alternative was to do this during crunch, and I love y'all too much for that. On the other hand, if you'd like to know even more, <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Checklist-Manifesto-How-Things-Right/dp/0805091742/">Amazon</a> has copies in stock..

This book is ostensibly written for doctors, but consciously raises questions for any person or organization attempting to do complex tasks requiring practitioners to remember more than any one person can really be expected to remember. The author, Atul Gawande, is a surgeon and he starts and ends in the operating room. His research shows that commitment to a simple checklist of best practices saves lives.

In aviation, he finds checklists coming into use when planes became too complicated to be flown by one person. They remain in use due to the very high cost of making a mistake and the simple truth that we all make mistakes. Aviators also find them useful in rare and high stress situations. He cites a checklist for dealing with complete engine failure on which item number one is "fly the plane."

In construction of large office buildings he finds much more complex checklists. These lists enable teams to work with complex and extensive building codes which no one person fully knows. In extensive contingency flowcharts they coordinate communication and sequencing of work among many diverse teams such as steel workers, plumbers and electricians. The tasks are so complex, no one person can do or manage it all. It is these sophisticated checklists which enable super-human coordination and communication.

The heart and soul of this text is in improving patient outcomes in surgery. Consider this list of seven items to discuss before starting surgery:
- confirm patient identity
- confirm patient consent
- ensure the surgical site is marked
- ensure pulse oximeter is working
- note any medication allergies
- review the risk of airway problems, equipment and procedure for addressing emergencies
- check for availability of at least a half liter of blood and lines for infusion

This is the first of three lists, 19 items in all, developed by his team and deployed at nine surgery centers around the world. The improvement in results was staggering: major complications fell 36%, deaths due to surgical complications fell 47%. This was true at high-end hospitals and rural clinics alike regardless of funding, training or previous success rate.

Perhaps the most striking thing about this list is how pedestrian it is. These are so mundane, so routine, they seem at odds with his notion of checklists being required where complexity exceeds our ability to remember. How could they have led to such dramatic results with so many different surgical units from London to rural Africa?

He highlights several complimentary dynamics enabled by the checklists:

ARTICULATE ESSENTIALS
They take what everyone agrees is important and codify it. No one doubts the importance of these things. Yet when the checklists were rolled out, they found that these things were done more consistently and thus radically improved outcomes.

SUPPORT THE WORKERS
They build broad support for ensuring these particular things happen. In some cases the problem was that doctors and nurses did not have the supplies they needed to do these things. With administration buy-in to the list, they became better equipped, radically improving outcomes.

SPREAD AUTHORITY
They empower all present to enforce the agreed upon best procedures. In some cases, the checklist gave nurses the authority and opportunity to stop the doctor and ensure best practices were observed.

REQUIRE COMMUNICATION
They force critical communication. Things don't always go smoothly in surgical prep (or life) and by having these three times where the surgical team walks through these short checklists the ensured much better communication. For example, an anesthesiologist who missed the patient interview was told during the pre-anesthesia checklist about a key deviance from normal procedure for this particular patient. Note how open the items in the list are to discussion and how abstract they are from the procedure. It's not nearly as much a "to do" list as it is a "to consider" list.

How does all this relate to Soomo? We are inventing much of what we do so we are learning a lot, all the time. We spend a lot of time thinking about how to do this stuff, and then how to do it better. We iterate, and learn with each revision. Lessons derived from our past efforts and mistakes are a big part of our value.

Our products are truly helping people today -- just ask App Robot how many students turned in quizzes in the past 24 hours. But long term, our value lies in our processes. What we have figured out how to do, what works, what doesn't and how to work efficiently are our greatest assets. Checklists give us a way to codify what we know, to preserve and build upon it and to pass it along to our next new additions. If we doubled in size tomorrow, and passed none of this information along to our new counterparts, they would be where we were when we started.

And everything we do is done as a team -- nothing goes from idea to live  on one desktop. Each and every project requires hand-offs and lessons learned from past experience from setting up a new email account to replacing an image in an assignment to adding a multiple choice question. They all require multiple people working from different perspectives and bodies of experience.

Take something as simple as sending out an email with MyEmma. A short checklist of "things to think about" could bring together what we've learned from pouring over the subject lines and open rates, decisions we've made recently about branding, Dawn's take on our core messaging, the research we did two years ago on complying with spam regulations, the painstaking lessons of ensuring our email looks good across email clients and that we are pulling together our mailing lists in full-knowledge of those who've opted out and should not hear from us again. Art from Jamie, copy with multiple reviewers, QA from Tom, audience building with Mary, scheduling coordinated with Maureen on conference emails and David for other scheduled marketing. Just generating that list implies a simple list of things to consider. An easy to find and use checklist, and template, can turn this into a fast, simple, easy task without us repeating our first year mistakes again in our second year, and again in our third, and again...

Just a few other potential (and actual) lists:
- things to think about before planning a conference, conducting a peer review, printing new business cards
- how to get a new person into all of our various systems and services, equipped, given our glossary
- what we need to know about each adopting prof, what they need to know about us, what the bookstore needs to know, students, Bb
- what to ask a student who says "video won't play," "page won't print," "I can't log in."
- what we always need on our home page, ensuring accessibility, pages that will work across browsers and devices
- things to consider for every video we post, keys to posting to YouTube, transcript production flow
- standard expense report template, how to get ready for the crunch, how to pass along what was learned in a prof conversation
- creating an assignment, writing a good multiple choice question, getting an author up to speed
and on and on.

We are not, of course, going to stop working and start creating checklists. But creating these lists needs to become a normal part of what we do. And, like everything else we're doing, this will require some invention, trial and error, iteration, communication and codification. It certainly did for Gawande's team, the pilots, the construction workers, the investors and everyone else referenced in the book. But they all do it because it makes life easier. Granted, it's hard to make a good list. No doubt there are many ways to do it wrong and make the stupid list tedious, irrelevant, unworkable or counter-productive. But a good list saves lives. And that's the point of the text.

Checklists can help us. They will help us know what we know. They will help us store what we've learned so we can effectively remember it and share it. They will increase our ability to do everything we need to, every time, despite growing complexity in our jobs and organization. They will ensure we get the support we need from others on every project. They will enable all of us to have more authority and to better help each other avoid repeating common mistakes. They will encourage quick, effective hand-offs and check-ins with less "meeting sprawl" racking our brains to once again think through everything we ought. They will give us a trusted system into which we can place hard-won knowledge. (After leaving the pole hooks at CCCC, I may never again forget to check for them. But in a list, I could spread that knowledge and prevent that pain.) I feel certain that checklists will enable us to work faster as individuals and work together better as a team. My hope is they will allow us think through issues once and then move on, confident that those conclusions are settled and we can move on to the next challenge. As Tom told me recently "I don't pack faster because I have a checklist. I pack faster because I don't have to think."

Checklists, I believe, will make us faster, better and more valuable. They will make work easier and more fun. And, as an end result, students will have fewer problems, better resources and will learn more.]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_author_email>rebecca@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>70.144.65.253</wp:comment_author_IP>

			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-04-11 19:07:11</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[This is exciting. Maybe it's a personality thing, but checklists are indispensable for me. Without a detailed one for each of my projects, I'm never quite sure when I'm done, or if I have done well. So this broader idea of "meta" checklists, created for posterity and crafted through mutual experience, makes great sense. It's always comforting to know when you've hit the mark, especially in Soomo's fast-growing environment. And imagine what we could do with the brainspace freed up by "not having to think"?]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>109</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Kevin]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>kevin@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>74.250.179.191</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-04-11 19:57:21</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-04-11 23:57:21</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[NPR covered this text in january: http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=122226184 nice story]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>110</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Dan]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>dhb@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>68.113.116.5</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-04-12 08:29:35</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-04-12 12:29:35</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I like it!  It's like making certain you have the same setup and checklist every time before making a golf swing:  You eliminate many variables which can cause the result to be a shank or a duck hook.  You  immeasurably increase your chances of a good shot.

The first thing that pops in my mind is that there are always a few specific steps in every process which are essential for overall success of the project.  Frequently, their effectiveness is a function of timing; i.e., when they're done in the process.  Once any one of these is overlooked, the opportunity to positively impact the result is diminished or even lost.

Your checklists will really strengthen our processes...  and set Soomo even further apart from the herd.  Count me in.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>111</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[kprancan]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>kathi@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>75.237.175.230</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-04-12 12:20:37</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-04-12 16:20:37</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Like Rebecca, I am a slave to checklists.  They help me know what I need to do, how to prioritize and give me a sense of accomplishment once completed.  Applying this tactic to our general processes at large can provide the same benefits to our products and our people.  I love it!]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Linchpin Musings</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/04/linchpin-musings/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 15 Apr 2010 17:51:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1421</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Notes from our discussion today on reading Linchpin.

Things we need more of. (Or at least what made it to the whiteboard.)

<strong>Deadlines </strong>
Define the time budget, and then ask "What's the best we can do in the defined time?"

<strong>Thrash early</strong>
(Not late.) When the project is in pencil or dry erase ink, get all the opinions, ideas and concerns into play. Lots of ideas.

<strong>One Leader per Project</strong>
Take the opinions of every wise person you can, and then make the best stuff possible in the allotted time.

<strong>Second Set of Eyes</strong>
Let others help make the decision about whether this should ship on time, or slip.

<strong>Iteration</strong>
Nothing needs to be perfect. It needs to be better than what we have now. It needs to ship on time. And if it works it will be replaced.

<strong>Distribute Information</strong>
Making sure no one person is the only person with key information -- as this puts undue urgency on that person.



Additionally, rhere was some impassioned discussion of the <strong>three stock checkpoints</strong>, about which I remind us:
- At three points (kickoff, pre-build and pre-release) ask yourself "who should I get input from on this?" Then meet with them.
- Catch problems as early as possible. Get all the wise in put you can as early as you can. Coordinate with others.
- The owner of the project has the authority and responsibility to make it succeed.

And while it didn't make the whiteboard, <strong>project path</strong> came up along with agreement (I think) that:
- This is a place for any project requiring most of your time in a given week. Anything you plan to work on this week should be there.
- If it is not one of your 2-3 big things this week, it shouldn't be in ProjectPath. Put it on hold, archive or delete as needed.
- A project needs only a placeholder project name for Monday discussion. Use other features only if they help you.

Next discussion is May 5, focused on the gifts chapter.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>The thrill has arrived - live notebook demo!</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/04/the-thrill-has-arrived-live-notebook-demo/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 22 Apr 2010 18:07:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1436</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[One of the hardest features to demo is the notebook. Any time a sales person has to create an imaginary world for a prof, the chain is getting a little slack. Today, demoing the notebook is dead simple and student privacy is protected.

Any course created at Soomo College in Alabama will have this link at the top of the notebook:
<a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/04/Notebook1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1439" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/04/Notebook1.jpg" alt="" /></a>

Go ahead and click it. Matt's robot will quick add some latin text to protect the innocent.

<a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/04/Notebook-11.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1438" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/04/Notebook-11.jpg" alt="" /></a>

Click on a check mark to read the students answers, just like in the real world.

<a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/04/Notebook-21.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1440" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/04/Notebook-21.jpg" alt="" /></a>

For multiple choice quizzes, the notebook looks great too.

<a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/04/Notebook2.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1473" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/04/Notebook2.jpg" alt="" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Deployment Speed up</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/04/deployment-speed-up/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 22 Apr 2010 19:04:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1444</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Matt made a key change to the system today that increases efficiency all around. The <strong>Business Stats</strong> content is huge in number of files, not so much in actual disk usage. He moved those gazillion small files to S3 and off of our servers. The result is <strong>speed</strong>, baby, <strong>speed</strong>! We had a process that usually takes 5 minutes that is now down to one or so.

The change was pretty significant, all of the Business Stats content that draws a formula or other mathy thing was affected. Lot's to test and verify before release.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>What&#039;s a Soomo?</title>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Defining Soomo's brand is step one to getting getting a clear, concise, compelling message. Then comes getting the message out there in the right way, to the right folks. I'll be posting ideas, questions and findings here and am looking forward to getting your thoughts.

The information you all provided in the interview/survey about Soomo has been amazingly helpful. Thank you! Who better to define Soomo than...Soomoans.You may recall that the first question was a request to list a couple of the coolest companies you could think of off the top of your head.To get the brand juices flowing, here is a video of a bunch of folks asked a similar question:

<a href="http://tinyurl.com/2fopx5p">Who Cares?</a>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[What is a Soomo? I am a Soomo!  Let's get Grant started on a "I'm a textbook" "I'm a Soomo" campaign.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>

	<item>
		<title>What is a brand?</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/04/what-is-a-brand/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 30 Apr 2010 05:55:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dawnhagen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1482</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[When I asked Soomo to name some cool companies, not surprisingly, Apple was named most often. When asked why, everyone was able to articulate their reasons without hesitation. And they were pretty powerful. Here are a few:
"Apple changed my whole thinking about computers."
"Lives up to the hype."
"I'm a fan of ideas. It's about ideas."
"When I sit down at the airport next to a guy with his Blackberry and PC, and I pull out my iPhone and Macbook, I feel cooler."

These responses go way beyond whether or not the laptop turns on and does what you need it to. Other companies that got multiple mentions were:
Anthopologie - "Their products, marketing and style- it's a feeling...Their customer interactions- always friendly and helpful."
Amazon -  "Just amazing customer service and reliability."
IKEA - "They appear to do the impossible: great design for cheap."
Patagonia - "A great company story. Strong tribe."
Zappos - "More than their products, it's an attitude. They really care about the customer."

Again, most of these statements step beyond the functionality of a product or fulfillment of a service. Equally interesting were Soomo's less popular answers:
Starbucks Coffee- "I love coffee and always get a great cup there. Consistency- I can go anywhere and it will be the same."
Southwest Airlines - "You have the sense that improving the customer's experience and innovating significantly in order to DO that is always on their mind."
Walt Disney World - "When you go there, it's amazing..."

Brands make us feel stuff. They illicit admiration, good will, respect and because of that, our loyalty. So, what IS a brand exactly? Here's what Scott Bedbury says in A Brand New World:

A brand is the sum of the good, the bad, the ugly, and the off-strategy. It is the sum total of your best and worst product, your best and worst day. For every finely worded public statement, the brand is also defined by derisory consumer comments overheard in the hallway or in a chat room... Brands are sponges for content, for images, for fleeting feelings. They become psychological concepts held in the minds of the public, where they may stay forever... Scott Bedbury, A Brand New World

...bla bla bla...marketing mumbo jumbo. What is a brand? A BRAND IS A PROMISE.]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Passkey lookup admin tool</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/04/passkey-lookup-admin-tool/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 30 Apr 2010 19:41:49 +0000</pubDate>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Sometimes a bookstore or student will call to see if the passkey they are holding is valid. Matt built us a tidy looker upper that lets us know right quick. We do our best to make each passkey easy to read and type in, but sometimes people get silly with them.

	<item>
		<title>Customer Foo</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/04/customer-foo/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 30 Apr 2010 19:55:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1493</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This week, Ms. Webb, a student at OU, wrote to report that a question on a multiple choice quiz was graded incorrectly. She included research to prove her point and asked kindly that her grade be changed. I passed the question along to Melissa in the editorial group who validated her position and fixed the assignment.

I forwarded Ms. Webb's note to her professor asking how she wanted the problem solved for the rest of the class. Prof Burdett was kind and quick with her reply. With her input Matt was able to adjust everybody's grade. In fact, Prof Burdett told us that she had complaints from a number of students but only one wrote to us.

For their desire for justice and unspoken thirst to make AmericansGoverning.com a better place to teach and learn, we sent them a nice note with a $25 Amazon gift card attached.

All of you reading this are a part of a caring and generous tribe wildly proficient in the ancient art of customer foo!  (I know it is spelled fu, but didn't like the way it looked in print.)

<a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/04/Amazon.com_-Gift-Cards-Buy-Gift-Cards-Online-1.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1494" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/04/Amazon.com_-Gift-Cards-Buy-Gift-Cards-Online-1.jpg" alt="" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Registration Jump Start</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/05/registration-jump-start/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 03 May 2010 15:50:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1504</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Neat new feature that simplifies the registration process for students.

When a professor creates their course, we create a url for them to pass to their students.

<a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/05/test-ngbd-hgfd.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1505" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/05/test-ngbd-hgfd.jpg" alt="" /></a>

When the student clicks the link, they are directed to registration like normal and their course info is filled in for them.

<a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/05/Registration-39.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1506" src="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/05/Registration-39.jpg" alt="" width="712" height="443" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Brand Building</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/05/brand-building/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 03 May 2010 16:56:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dawnhagen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1509</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Where were we? Oh yeah, a brand is a promise. Its everything we do, dont do, believe and create. Additionally, its what a customer thinks about what were doing, not doing, believing and creating. This might make brand start to feel a little too conceptual, intangible...squishy. But case study after case study shows that organizations who are clear about their identity (what they stand for and where theyre going), do well. Companies that are not clear...well, not so much.

How does one build a brand? Marketing gurus make a lot of money teaching the mysteries of brand building, but all share the same three critical components:

1. Vision - What do we want to be (in 5-10 year)?
2. Mission - How will we get there?
3. Values - What do we believe in?

Each of these build on the other - what we believe (values) supports our daily activities (mission) that move us toward our goal (vision).

What is the best way to build a truly great brand (think about those Apple comments)? Authenticity. When a brand is authentic, it comes from within the company. It is not some distant ideal that sounds nice, but doesnt resonate with reality. Case in point, after asking each of you to name the Soomos values, I asked how you had assessed those values. Here are some your answers:
<ul>
	<li>Through day-to-day observations. People at Soomo exhibit these values.</li>
	<li>From experience and observation. By seeing the example set by leaders.</li>
	<li>Conversations with various people in the company. David. By seeing what they are trying to do.</li>
	<li>The product produced and how they seem to focus on things - it has to be really good.</li>
	<li>By the work we produce- across all departments. How we are treated.</li>
	<li>Ive seen people in this office surprise by how they are treated. They are aggressively cared for.</li>
</ul>
When a brand is authentic- when a company is walking the talk across the board - there is brand alignment. As a result, product development, customer interactions, strategic partnerships, employee interactions - all work in synergy and support the vision.

Next stop: defining Soomos vision.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1509</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>brand-building</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="brand"><![CDATA[brand]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="ideas"><![CDATA[Ideas]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="marketing"><![CDATA[Marketing]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="marketing"><![CDATA[Marketing]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="mission"><![CDATA[mission]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="values"><![CDATA[values]]></category>
		<category domain="post_tag" nicename="vision"><![CDATA[vision]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[25]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[25]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[25]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[25]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Envisioning Soomo</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/05/envisioning-soomo/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 05 May 2010 06:10:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dawnhagen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1518</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Soomo is nothing if not visionary. So defining Soomo's vision seems an appropriate starting point for the brand building process. Well, that and it really makes the most sense to start there, given that everything that comes after it should ladder up to, and support our vision - what we want to become.

The statement below came out of looking closely at what Soomo is saying about itself (external marketing and communications), observation and conversations with the Soomo team and head visionary, Mr. Lindrum.

Below, you will find a diagram explaining a bit about some of the word choices. Check it out. Consider it. Heck, take it out for a burger. And then please feel free to post your thoughts, reactions, feedback.
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Soomo's Vision (draft):
To be the world's most trusted educational resource, providing life changing learning experiences, freeing teachers to ignite their students passions for learning, for the world around them and their role in it.</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/05/breakdown1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-1521" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/05/breakdown1.jpg" alt="" /></a></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1518</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-05-05 02:10:38</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-05-05 06:10:38</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[i am a bit cynical about the cynicism of instructors... for external consumption what do folks think about defining ourselves as a service group, more than as makers of wonder?

they want:

us "to be a trustworthy" not the most trusted in their world, perhaps...

us to provide needed help to instructors who themselves want to help change lives. But this is tough sledding for the devoted instructor, right? Few instructors are hoping to "ignite," but want to foster meaningful change as they can...

I suppose these thoughts are about projecting the seasoned deliberation and diligence of a dedicated gorup who don't kid themselves about what profs need?

They need serious help with excellent tools crafted by serious professionals...

as for our internal vision, yes, this is super, but we still sell a service more than a resource set i think.  but that's just me and i rarely share my opinions... ;^)

good work, dawn]]></wp:comment_content>

Nowhere in our vision statement is there a reference to the web or webtext.  Is that intentional?

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Though we all feel the passion that's expressed in this statement, it doesn't really distinguish us from other publishers.  Houghton Mifflin wanted to be the most trusted educational resource too.....so does Pearson, MH, etc. etc.  To both Kevin's and Dan's points, the level of service we offer and the creation of webtexts separate us from the pack.  I love what you're saying and I believe it, but many of our competitors could say the same thing.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
		</wp:comment>
		<wp:comment>
			<wp:comment_id>124</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[DawnHagen]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>dawn@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>99.162.155.181</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-05-05 13:01:35</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-05-05 17:01:35</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[WOW- thanks for the feedback! Great points and ones I've thought about too.  It might be most helpful to share the process and thinking behind the specific words you raised.

 First, Dan's - any mention of the web was left out intentionally. Soomo seems about something much bigger than the vehicle around which the learning is channelled, it's about the learning. Someone said to me early on: "All of us are passionate about education.", not the web. And one person rocked my view when she explained to me that the web is the vehicle of choice now, but in five years the 'best way to deliver education' may not be the web, there may be something new. How we get there (the mission) can change, but where we're headed shouldn't.

Kathi, I'm so glad you brought up 'trust'. It's what first struck David as well. Trust was the choice for a few reasons:
-Soomo wants 1. to change student's lives through education 2. and to do so by providing profs the best means of doing that (all that Soomo offers). After looking at the research, one sticking point for profs is the credibility of something web based.  Online gets high marks for accessibility and ease of use, but it does not get high marks for 'trustworthy content' (a stated priority) and certainly not compared  textbooks. So shooting for trust in that regard seemed important.
-On having a similar vision to a trad. publisher, to some degree that is not a bad thing. I've been compiling verbiage used by other publishers and online competitors. What I found encouraging was that where we netted out was in direct head to head competition against the very people that David first said Soomo was competing against (trad. pubs), and not the ones it looks like we are (other digital offerings).  Our vision doesn't have to be our differentiating factor (though ours goes much farther than the others). It's how we get there that sets us apart.

OK, last but not least, Kevin. Yes, woven into this statement is an optimism that teachers do want to ignite. That when they decided to teach, igniting was the dream. That in an ideal world 'meaningful exchanges' would ignite. Idealistic is a word that came up a few times when I asked for Soomo's characteristics. Not an entirely bad thing and in fact an appropriate thing for a vision statement.

As far as being a service, that goes back to the 'how we get there' part and less to the where we're going. It's a truly interesting point though...I'm looking forward to discussing this one more!

Please let me know if that helped or prompted more questions or if you're just not feeling it.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I agree that service can set us apart... why not change the world, one cynical professor at a time?

To me, there is definitely market value in being a group of people who instigate reliable relationships and help teachers actually teach, but who also serve as educational spark plugs...
for example none of my Polisci classes have presented the tension and important questions of civil disobedience the way AGs Weather Underground assignment does.  But wow, what if they did?

We do serve professors. But we also find/create/collect/morph stellar content, and our vision for how our content is presented is sneaky-important because it has the power to be transformative. (More than meets the eye!)]]></wp:comment_content>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Getting there - Soomo&#039;s mission</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/05/getting-there/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 06 May 2010 18:49:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dawnhagen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1532</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[If Soomo's vision is (something like): <em>to be the most trusted educational resource, freeing teachers to ignite their studentss passions for learning, for the world around them and for their role in it</em>, how do we get there?

Yesterday an important question was raised about what sets Soomo apart from the other publishers who are headed in a similar direction? Soomos mission statement should answer that question in a way that is clear, concise and supports Soomo's business strategy.  The below drafted mission statement attempts to address those things in terms of what Soomo believes about educational needs, market desires and Soomos unique offerings.
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Mission (draft):
To offer educators and students the most engaging, easy to use, effective and delightfully unexpected educational experience by combining smart technology, peer reviewed content, proven learning interactions and hands down unparalleled one-on-one service.</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>
</strong></p>
Youll notice that, once again, rather than citing a specific technology, the focus is on using the best technology to provide the needed results for professors and students and the academic discipline applied to that process, which in turn builds the kind of the trust mentioned in the vision.
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/05/missiony.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-1537" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/05/missiony.jpg" alt="" /></a></p>
Some things I'm wondering:

Does 'engaging, effective, easy to use and delightfully unexpected' cover what you think Soomo does and what the market needs/wants? How does it feel to not mention the web? What do you think of the term 'learning interactions'? Is it intuitive or a little too clinical? Questions and comments welcome.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

"...the most engaging, clear, and effective educational experiences by combining smart technology, peer reviewed content, proven instructional strategies, and unparalleled care and support." Sometimes less is more.]]></wp:comment_content>

All the more reason to build validation and trust.]]></wp:comment_content>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Clap your hands if you believe.</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/05/clap-your-hands-if-you-believe/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 10 May 2010 03:43:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dawnhagen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1554</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Now that we're close to defining what Soomo wants to be (vision) and how best to make that happen (mission), were ready for the last part of the brand building equation: what does Soomo believe?

An organization's values are generally viewed as their guiding principles.  When I asked about Soomo's values, everyone was pretty clear about what they thought they were. The words differed a bit, but when combined, clear categories emerged. Four to be exact. Four really good ones.

But asking what Soomos values are, is not the same as asking what they should be. The good news, no great news, is that when I lined the responses up against the ideals espoused, they were darn close!

The following list is the result of discussions, interviews, observations and picking the brain of head believer, Mr. Lindrum. Spread sheets were involved, long division was used and a value pie chart was constructed. OK, there was no long division, but the rest is true.

<strong>SOOMO BELIEVES IN: </strong>

<strong>PEOPLE. We believe that caring for people should be the starting point for everything we do. We apply this belief to our own culture and to those we collectively serve. By partnering with educators to engage, equip and inspire future generations to participate in the world around them, we believe we can change the world, one student at a time.</strong>

<strong>INNOVATION. We believe in trying new things. In learning all we can about technology, design and education, and then partnering with professors to create something that has never existed before. And then doing it again. </strong>

<strong>ACTION. We believe in getting things done. We operate with flexibility that allows for quick idea implementation and course correction. Our effectiveness comes from appropriate, intelligent, responsiveness and proactive solutions.</strong>

<strong>TRUST. We believe trust is earned through consistent display of attentive consideration and delivery of effective solutions. By truly listening to customers, we show we care. By responding effectively, acting with integrity, by creating the best solutions, we become trustworthy. </strong>

Does this list seem like an accurate list of Soomos priorities? As a new employee, would knowing the core values of the company you work for be helpful? Would welcome thoughts and reflections...

Next stop: Soomos brand promise!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Cross My Heart.</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/05/cross-my-heart/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 11 May 2010 03:05:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dawnhagen</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1587</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[We started these discussions with the question, what is a brand? The answer can be complex (a brand is everything that a company makes, is and does), or very simple (a brand is a promise).We explored how a brand promise should align with an organization's core values and support its mission, which in turn supports the vision. And how when this is the case, other things like product development and strategic decisions, are more likely to be in alignment as well (a good book on this subject is <em>Taking Brand Initiative </em>by Hatch and Schultz).

At the end of the day, a brand is Soomo's pledge to every professor Soomo serves and all those Soomo hopes to serve.A quick review:

<strong>What does Soomo want to be</strong><strong>?</strong> (Vision)

The most trusted educational resource; providing life-changing learning experiences; freeing teachers to ignite their students passions for learning, for the world around them and their role in it.

<strong>How will Soomo get there?</strong> (Mission)

By Offering educators and students the most engaging, easy to use, effective and delightfully unexpected educational experience by combining peer reviewed content, proven learning strategies, the right technology and unparalleled one-on-one service.

<strong>What does Soomo believe in?</strong> (Values)
<ul>
	<li>PEOPLE</li>
	<li>INNOVATION</li>
	<li>ACTION</li>
	<li>TRUST</li>
</ul>
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>What is Soomo's (brand) promise? </strong>
<a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/05/tagline.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-1586" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/05/tagline.jpg" alt="" /></a></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/05/tag2.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-1610" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/05/tag2.jpg" alt="" /></a></p>
Whatcha think?]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>

			<wp:comment_id>144</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[PaigeRagan]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>paige@soomopublishing.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url></wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>99.10.254.210</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2010-05-12 12:02:06</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2010-05-12 16:02:06</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[I've been thinking for a couple of days about this one - the brand promise specifically. Why not say, "We innovate. You educate." ? That is after all, the simplest way to create action around what we do.

But after two days of thinking about it, I think the "can" is so much more important than we realize. We don't simple innovate. We create a relationship between innovation and education. Between great ways of learning, and teachers. The "can" is an inexorable link, our linchpin. And the great part is, it is the perfect expression of our attitude: not just a "can do" attitude, but a "can fix" and a "can create" and a "can change" attitude.

If we don't have "can" we're just another company telling profs what they need and hoping it sticks.
With "can" we are partners. With "can" we equip them with something trustworthy and better.]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[This is all good stuff. I think the word innovate gets tossed around a lot these days by companies doing very little innovation  My K-12 company, HMH,  claimed to be innovative but all they did was print. Nothing new.  Innovate can be a scary word too.  Our customers are notoriously skittish about change.  We tend to find the true believers first and then struggle to get to the next level.  As long as we can back up innovate with concrete examples that proves the point then the message will ring true.]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>1</wp:comment_approved>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Wow! Dawn - bravo. Seriously man, well done!

And I think Paige hit the nail on the head, the whole "can" idea and that she interprets it to mean "creat[ing] a relationship," is simply it.

But I also think the "you" is something to fully grasp. As a member of the Fix Force, I try to exhibit that I fully understand the "you" in our brand promise. There is a strict dichotomy that even though I help to customize, along with Tom and Z, we are not doing the actual educating, merely we are being used to make the prof look good and feel great.

After all, I never want to tell a prof how to teach or what to teach, but simply show them to the magician's box of goods and encourage them to put on their own show.

Bottom line -- thanks Dawn for putting what I think, into words!]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
		<title>Leading with Marketing</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/05/leading-with-marketing/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 May 2010 14:45:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1627</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[At times, Seth might lead you to believe that he's only talking about marketing. So it's good to know that when Seth talks about marketing, he really means almost everything:
<a href="http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2010/05/good-at-talking-vs-good-at-doing.html">Good at Talking vs. Good at Doing</a>

And he's in good company. Peter Drucker explains that marketing begins with researching the needs of the market and ends with fulfilling them. It's about adapting an organizations capabilities to what the market wants and needs. Given this, it's probably more appropriate to use the phrase "marketing the company" in the same way you might say "weaponizing the robot" -- that is, marketing is often about company changing.

But not entirely. There's also a story-telling component. Drucker is, as usual, the best-thought out ground. Marketing begins with understanding market needs, and ends with fulfilling them.

So, what kind of market needs does your position address? How you could you better address them? Does it require you to do something more? Something less? Something differently? A need to make the market more aware of what it is you can do or provide to help them?

These questions help me to figure out why I'm doing what I'm doing, what I should stop or start, and why it's important to tell the story until it's heard and making a difference for other people.

At its most crass, this could be characterized as coming up with a pitch they will love and then building to make it true. Which sounds a bit crass, without direction or values. But with direction and values firmly in place, it turns out to be a pretty good place to start because of the emphasis it puts on the person we want to benefit from our efforts. Figure out what that person really wants and needs first and let that "marketing" lead your efforts.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1627</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-05-20 07:45:17</wp:post_date>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<title>and now with emphasis..</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/05/and-now-with-emphasis/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 May 2010 18:06:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1629</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[New today, the capacity to set assignments titles to italic. This is an important feature when the title is a court case - style consistency, you understand. As with many things, the italics is good in the right place but bad out of place. Matt has built this seemingly simple feature to display italics in the chapter title, where it belongs, but nowhere else. Very nice.

	<item>
		<title>18 to 4</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/05/18-to-4/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 24 May 2010 18:40:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1661</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Matt did a little tuning on the admin tools page last week. Doing a basic user search was taking 18 seconds. With a little diagnosis and wrench turning, he was able to save 14 seconds. Now the page loads in only 4 seconds.

Doesn't seem like a lot? Try holding your breath for 18 seconds. Try looking at somebody without speaking for 18 seconds. Try waiting patiently while your tools load up for 18 seconds.

Thanks Matt!]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1661</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2010-05-24 11:40:59</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-05-24 18:40:59</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>18-to-4</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>

	<item>
		<title>Any friends?</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/05/any-friends/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 26 May 2010 03:09:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>lindrum</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1666</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Increasingly, I show up at <a href="http://www.livestream.com/disrupt/video?clipId=pla_b33c8216-714f-4b37-8b04-767303f4438f">some site</a> and it knows who I am and who my friends are, at least according to facebook. And it invites me to start a conversation among my friends about a given page.

This might be the most compelling potential mashup yet for FaceBook and Soomo. Not Soomo invading your FaceBook space, but instead, fb friends conversing with you in your homework space.

Hmmm. Any reactions? What would be a likely outcome if that were enabled?
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://backstage.soomolearning.com/files/2010/05/Disrupt-2010_-New-York-City-Mayor-Bloomberg-on-Techcrunch-Disrupt-live-streaming-video-powered-by-Livestream.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-1667" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/05/Disrupt-2010_-New-York-City-Mayor-Bloomberg-on-Techcrunch-Disrupt-live-streaming-video-powered-by-Livestream.jpg" alt="" /></a></p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>HighRise Functionality - Tags</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/07/highrise-functionality-tags/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 07 Jul 2010 19:54:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>jonathangermann</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1826</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I have been working with HighRise to make it a more useful sales tool. I will attempt to communicate some useful knowledge.

New tags:

VL2s and M4s (10,000 plus 2 years and 4 years) have been tagged in Highrise as <strong>Large</strong> and have had their corresponding state code tagged. Joining the 2 will allow you to sort large schools by state.

4 year medium sized schools tagged <strong>Medium</strong> with State codes as well.

<strong>Department Target Sp11</strong> New users this fall that could lead to departmental growth.

<strong>Target Sp11</strong>-Previous users, reviewers, or professors with some relationship that are targeted for a Spring 2011 adoption.

<strong>Soomo User in School FA10</strong> Individual schools tagged if there is a user summer or fall 2010.

<strong>Closed Target FA10</strong>  Summer and Fall 2010 closed leads.

<strong>History Chair </strong>

<strong>English Chair</strong>

<strong>Political Science Chair</strong>

Under each department chair, if available, there is a phone, email, mailing address, and link to the department faculty page.

Putting tags together with multi tags can make the above a powerful sorting tool.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1826</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-07-07 19:54:46</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>highrise-functionality-tags</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>

	<item>
		<title>Confirm Delete</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/07/confirm-delete/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 15 Jul 2010 18:13:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1857</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[This one will save some angst, I am sure. Now, when deleting any element via the editor, a confirmation dialog will be presented. This applies to everything that can be deleted by a prof or editor. Chapter, assignment, reference link, handout, quiz response.

<a href="http://soomolearning.com/html/wp-content/blogs.dir/3/files/2010/07/Google-Chrome.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1858" src="http://soomopub.com/files/2010/07/Google-Chrome.jpg" alt="" /></a><a rel="attachment wp-att-1858" href="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/07/confirm-delete/google-chrome/"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1858" title="Google Chrome" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/07/Google-Chrome.jpg" alt="" width="534" height="536" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Thwarting Robots</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/07/thwarting-robots/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 14 Jul 2010 20:44:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1832</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[So we have been getting a lot of dummy support requests via our online help form. Turns out that bad robots roam the internet looking to do harm with online forms. As you know, robots are pretty limited in their logical reasoning. They are easy to stump even with the easiest of questions. To that end, we have added a one question quiz to the end of our help form to ensure that all evil robots will be thwarted.

<a href="http://soomopub.com/files/2010/07/Soomo-Publishing-12.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1833" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/07/Soomo-Publishing-12.jpg" alt="" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Quiz Reset</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/07/quiz-reset/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 14 Jul 2010 20:55:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1836</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Since the introduction of multiple choice quizzes, both students and professors have asked us to remove quiz responses enabling a collegiate 'do-over'. Matt has released a new button that makes it super easy for administrators to accomplish. While not visible to students or instructors, we support minions are now able to solve the problem without tech group intervention.

After navigating to the professor's notebook and locating the errant quiz response, we can return it to an unanswered state with a click of the button marked "Reset Quiz".

<a href="http://soomopub.com/files/2010/07/Notebook-12.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1837" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/07/Notebook-12.jpg" alt="" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Small but deadly admin changes</title>
		<link>http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/2010/07/small-but-deadly-admin-changes/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 14 Jul 2010 21:39:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>soomotom</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/?p=1842</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Admin Ninja's love new weapons. Matt is like Q from the James Bond movies - hooking us up!
<p style="text-align: center;"><a href="http://soomopub.com/files/2010/07/q-james-bond.jpg"><img class="size-medium wp-image-1843 aligncenter" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/07/q-james-bond-300x198.jpg" alt="" /></a></p>
<strong>The dreaded Delete button and notebook links have been removed from the Admin/Users page. Much cleaner!</strong>

<a href="http://soomopub.com/files/2010/07/http___staging.soomopublishing.com_admin_users.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1844" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/07/http___staging.soomopublishing.com_admin_users.jpg" alt="" width="650" height="348" /></a>

<strong>From the student admin page, we can link directly to their purchase history.</strong>

<a href="http://soomopub.com/files/2010/07/view-order.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1847" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/07/view-order.jpg" alt="" /></a>

<strong>Viewing a students order is really helpful in the event of a refund or payment question. </strong>

<a href="http://soomopub.com/files/2010/07/order.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1846" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/07/order.jpg" alt="" /></a>

<strong>Now they are super easy to find with this lookup tool - thanks for the great tools, Matt!</strong>

<a href="http://soomopub.com/files/2010/07/order-lookup.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1845" src="http://backstage.soomopublishing.com/files/2010/07/order-lookup.jpg" alt="" /></a>]]></content:encoded>
